([[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]]) | follows = [[1957 Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference|1957]] | precedes = [[1961 Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference|1961]] | website = | keypoints = [[Apartheid in South Africa]]}} The '''1960 Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference''' was the tenth [[Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference|Meeting]] of the [[List of Commonwealth Heads of Government|Heads of Government]] of the [[Commonwealth of Nations]]. It was held in the [[United Kingdom]] in May 1960, and was hosted by that country's [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]], [[Harold Macmillan]]. This was the first Commonwealth conference since [[Federation of Malaya|Malayan]] independence in August 1957 and saw the growing importance of the non-white "[[New Commonwealth]]" countries. Malaya's prime minister, [[Tunku Abdul Rahman]] and his government vigorously opposed the [[apartheid]] policies of [[South Africa]] and, with the support of Pakistan, India and Ghana, demanded that the issue be addressed by the Commonwealth. However, Macmillan insisted that the final communique could only include matters on which the leaders were unanimous.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=n2pYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7DsNAAAAIBAJ&pg=5117,2623971&dq=commonwealth+prime+ministers+malaya&hl=en] [[Ghana]] advised the meeting that it would be becoming a republic and South Africa advised that it would be holding a [[South African republic referendum, 1960|referendum]] on the issue. Ghana was advised that its continued membership in the Commonwealth as a republic was recognised, however, South Africa was advised that it would need to seek consent of other Commonwealth governments for its membership to continue.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vciLoneE8GYC&lpg=PA57&ots=WJHfUWpEAq&dq=commonwealth%20prime%20ministers%201960&pg=PA59#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=The Commonwealth at the Summit: Communiqu√©s of Commonwealth Heads of ... - Google Books |via=[[Google Books]]|date= |accessdate=2013-11-11}} ==Participants== {| class="wikitable" |- ! The '''Ark of Taste''' is an international catalogue of endangered [[Food heritage|heritage]] [[food]]s which is maintained by the global [[Slow Food]] movement. The Ark is designed to preserve at-risk foods that are [[Sustainable farming|sustainably produced]], unique in [[taste]], and part of a distinct [[ecoregion]]. Contrary to the most literal definition of plant and animal [[conservation ethic|conservation]], the Ark of Taste aims to maintain edibles in its purview by actively encouraging their cultivation for consumption.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/30/dining/30come.html?sq=&pagewanted=all |title=An Unlikely Way to Save a Species: Serve It for Dinner |last=Severson |first=Kim |date=April 30, 2008 |work=[[The New York Times]] }}</ref> By doing so, Slow Food hopes to promote the growing and eating of foods which are sustainable and preserve [[biodiversity]] in the human food chain.
Foods included in the list are intended to be "culturally or historically linked to a specific region, locality, ethnicity or traditional production practice",<ref>Ark of Taste, slowfoodusa.org</ref> in addition to being rare. Which foods meet these criteria is decided by an adjudicating committee made up of members of the Slow Food nonprofit organization; all candidates go through a formal nomination process which includes tastings and identification of producers within the region.<ref>Washington Post, Nov. 2004</ref>
Since the foundation of the Ark in 1996, 4866 products (October 2018) from over 149 countries have been included and growing daily. The list includes not only prepared foods and food products, but also a great many [[livestock]] breeds, as well as vegetable and fruit [[cultivar]]s. All foods in the catalogue are accompanied by a list of resources for those wishing to grow or buy them.

{{Property law}} '''Blackacre''', '''Whiteacre''', '''Greenacre''', '''Brownacre''', and variations are the [[placeholder name]]s used for fictitious [[estate (law)|estates in land]].
The names are used by professors of [[law]] in [[common law]] jurisdictions, particularly in the area of [[real property]] and occasionally in [[contracts]], to discuss the rights of various parties to a piece of land. A typical [[law school]] or [[bar exam]] question on real property might say:
{{quotation|Adam, owner of a [[fee simple]] in Blackacre, conveyed the property "to Bill for life, [[future interest|remainder]] to Charles, provided that if any person should consume alcohol on the property before the first born son of Charles turns twenty-one, then the property shall go to Dwight in fee simple." Assume that neither Bill, Charles, nor Dwight is an heir of Adam, and that Adam's only heir is his son, Edward. Discuss the ownership interests in Blackacre of Adam, Bill, Charles, Dwight and Edward.}}
Where more than one estate is needed to demonstrate a point{{spaced ndash}}perhaps relating to a dispute over boundaries, [[easement]]s or [[riparian rights]]{{spaced ndash}}a second estate will usually be called Whiteacre,<ref>''Black‚Äôs Law Dictionary'', ‚Äúblackacre‚Äù{{page needed|date=January 2014}}</ref> a third, Greenacre, and a fourth, Brownacre.
==Origin== [[Jesse Dukeminier]], author of one of the leading series of [[textbook]]s on property, traces the use of Blackacre and Whiteacre for this purpose to a 1628 treatise by Sir [[Edward Coke]]. Dukeminier suggests that the term might originate with references to colors associated with certain [[agriculture|crops]] ("[[peas]] and [[beans]] are black, [[cereal|corn]] and [[potatoes]] are white, [[hay]] is green"), or with the means by which rents were to be paid, with black rents payable in [[produce]] and white rents in [[silver]].<ref>[[Jesse Dukeminier]] and [[James E. Krier]]. ''Property, 5th Ed.''  Aspen Law and Business, 2002, p. 160n.</ref> A 1790 treatise by [[Sir Francis Buller, 1st Baronet|Francis Buller]] similarly uses these placeholder names, stating: "If A. have Black Acre and C. have White Acre, and A. has a way over White Acre to Black Acre, and then purchases White Acre, the way will be extinct; and if A. afterwards enfeoff C. of White Acre without excepting the road, it is gone".<ref>[[Sir Francis Buller, 1st Baronet|Francis Buller]], ''An Introduction to the Law Relative to Trials at Nisi Prius'' (1790), page 74.</ref>
An alternate theory is that the term arises from [[American Civil War|Civil War]] policy in which plots of [[plantations in the American South|plantation]] land given to recently [[Abolitionism in the United States|emancipated]] [[African-American]] [[freedmen]] (freed [[slaves]]) during the [[Reconstruction Era of the United States|Reconstruction]] period under [[William Tecumseh Sherman|Sherman]]'s "[[forty acres and a mule]]" policy. Such plots were colloquially called "Blackacres". Since most of the freed slaves were illiterate, many were cheated out of their land through shady loan contracts with former plantation owners.<ref>[[James M. McPherson]] The Struggle for Equality: Abolitionists and the Negro in the Civil War and Reconstruction. Vol. 72. Princeton University Press, 1967.</ref> These disputes, along with questions of the proper contractual entitlement of the slaves to the land in the first place, provided the basis for the development of modern American [[contract]] and [[property law]] and has come to refer to situations where there exists some contention or ambiguity surrounding the rightful owner or respective rights of the parties.<ref>[[Paul Collier]]. ''On the economic consequences of civil war'' Oxf. Econ. Pap. 1999. [168‚Äì183].</ref>
In various law journals and treatises in Louisiana, which uses a [[Law of Louisiana|unique form]] of the [[civil law (legal system)|civil law]] influenced by but not identical to the [[Napoleonic Code]], authors have used the term "[[arpent]] noir" as a placeholder name for the purpose of discussing rights concerning immovables.
==In popular culture==
Because of its association with legal education, a number of legal publications and events utilize the name. For example, ''Blackacre'' was adopted as the name of the literary journal at the [[University of Texas School of Law]]. ''Blackacre'' is also the name of a journal at the [[Sydney Law School|University of Sydney Law School]], published annually by the Sydney University Law Society, the name of the open-air courtyard and weekly student social at [[Vanderbilt Law School]], and the name of a [[William Mitchell College of Law]] formal.
The [[Blackacre Nature Preserve and Historic Homestead]] in [[Kentucky]] was so named by the donor of the land, [[Macauley Smith]], who had been a judge on the [[Kentucky Court of Appeals]].<ref>[http://www.blackacrefoundation.org/history.html Blackacre Foundation website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070202071832/http://www.blackacrefoundation.org/history.html |date=February 2, 2007 }}</ref> In July 2010, a legal humor website wrote an article chronicling the foreclosure sale of Blackacre.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120310053314/http://lawsforattorneys.com/2010/07/22/blackacre-sold-in-courthouse-foreclosure-auction Blackacre sold in courthouse foreclosure auction] at LawsForAttorneys (via [[archive.org]]); published July 22, 2010; archived March 10 2012</ref> A group of law students in Indianapolis founded a brewery named [[Black Acre Brewing Co.]] in late 2010 as a homage to their legal schooling.<ref>[http://blackacrebrewing.com/ BlackAcreBrewing.com]</ref> [[Monica Youn]]'s 2016 book of poetry from [[Graywolf Press]] is titled ''Blackacre'', in reference to the legal concept (Youn has a law degree from Yale).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.graywolfpress.org/books/blackacre|title=Blackacre {{!}} Graywolf Press|website=www.graywolfpress.org|access-date=2016-09-21}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Dewey, Cheatem & Howe]], another legal placeholder name

Service of the Federal Security Service of the Russian Federation''' ({{lang-ru|–ü–æ–≥—Ä–∞–Ω–∏—á–Ω–∞—è —Å–ª—É–∂–±–∞ –§–µ–¥–µ—Ä–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–π —Å–ª—É–∂–±—ã –±–µ–∑–æ–ø–∞—Å–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏ –†–æ—Å—Å–∏–π—Å–∫–æ–π –§–µ–¥–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏}}) is a branch of [[FSB (Russia)|Federal Security Service]] of [[Russia]] tasked with patrol of the Russian border. The terms '''Border Service of Russia''' ({{lang-ru|–ü–æ–≥—Ä–∞–Ω–∏—á–Ω–∞—è —Å–ª—É–∂–±–∞ –†–æ—Å—Å–∏–∏}}) and '''Border Force of Russia''' ({{lang-ru|–ü–æ–≥—Ä–∞–Ω–∏—á–Ω—ã–µ –≤–æ–π—Å–∫–∞ –†–æ—Å—Å–∏–∏}}) are also common, while in English, the terms "Border Guards" and "Border Troops" are frequently used to designate this service. The Border service numbers around 170,000 active members,{{cite web|url=https://info.publicintelligence.net/DIA-RussiaMilitaryPower2017.pdf |title=Paper |date=2017 |website=info.publicintelligence.net |format=PDF}} which includes the [[Russian FSB Coast Guard|Russian maritime border guard units]] (i.e., the [[coast guard]]). ==History== ===Tsarist and Imperial Russia=== One can trace the origin of the Russian border service to 1571 and the work of Prince [[Mikhail Vorotynsky]] (died 1573) and his [[Great Abatis Border]] built along the southern boundaries of the [[Tsardom of Russia]] in the 16th century. In 1782 the Empress [[Catherine II of Russia]] established Border Customs Guard units, originally manned by Russian [[Cossacks]] as well as by low-ranking [[cavalry]] troops. In 1810 General [[Michael Andreas Barclay de Tolly|Mikhail Barklay de Tolly]] organized numerous border posts along the entire western Russian border, manned by 11 regiments of [[Don Cossacks|Don]] and [[Bug Cossacks]] . Within two years Russian Border Guards became the first to oppose [[Napoleon's invasion of Russia]] (June 1812). In 1832 Cossacks and cavalry were replaced by armed customs officials subordinate to the [[Ministry of Finance]] in peacetime (in wartime the border guards were automatically transferred to the army). In the same year the government of [[Nicholas I of Russia|Emperor Nicholas I]] established a [[coast guard]] - originally to observe coasts of the [[Black Sea]] and of the [[Sea of Azov]]. Count [[Sergei Witte]], the Russian Minister of Finance (1892-1903) in the government of [[Alexander III of Russia|Alexander III]] (reigned 1881-1894), reformed the service on 13 October 1893 into the Independent Border Guards Corps (IBGC - a para-military rather than a civilian organization) headed by an army general and reporting directly to the ministry. In 1906 about 40,000 soldiers and officers served in the IBGC - maintaining the defence of the lengthy Imperial border. They served in 8 division-sized districts as well as in the Saint Petersburg headquarters unit. ===Soviet period=== {{main|USSR Border Troops}} '''Soviet Border Troops''', ({{lang-ru|–ü–æ–≥—Ä–∞–Ω–∏—á–Ω—ã–µ –≤–æ–π—Å–∫–∞ –°–°–°–†, Pogranichnyie Voiska SSSR}}) were the [[military|militarized]] [[border guard]] of the [[Soviet Union]], subordinated to its subsequently reorganized [[state security]] agency: first to ''[[Cheka]]''/[[State Political Directorate|OGPU]], then to [[NKVD]]/[[Ministry for State Security (USSR)|MGB]] and, finally, to [[KGB]]. Accordingly, they were known as '''NKVD Border Troops''' and '''KGB Border Troops''' (with [[Russian language|Russian]] abbreviations - ''–ù–ö–í–î –°–°–°–†''/- ''–ö–ì–ë –°–°–°–†'' added on the end of official names). Unlike border guards of many other countries, Soviet Border Troops were a centralized force including also the [[sea|maritime]] border guard units (i.e., a [[coast guard]]). ===Modern period=== [[Image:RIAN archive 942200 Border guards of the Federal Security Service pursuing trespassers of the maritime boundary during exercises in Kaliningrad region.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Border guards of the Federal Security Service in Kaliningrad region, 2011]] Following the collapse of the [[Soviet Union]], Federal Border Guard Service of Russia was created on December 30, 1993 as a separate government agency. The agency retained some old traditions, most notably the dark green-colored uniform and "[[Public holidays in Russia|Border Guarder's Day]]" (an official holiday commemorated by celebrations of ex-servicemen). First minister of FBS (Federal Border Service) was [[Andrei Nikolayev (politician)|Andrei Nikolayev]], young and outspoken general who later became deputy of the [[State Duma]]. Russian Border Guards were also stationed outside of Russia most notably in southern [[Tajikistan]], in order to guard the border with [[Afghanistan]], until summer 2005. On Afghan-Tajik border on many occasions they were engaged in heavy fighting with [[Illegal drug trade|drug-traffickers]] and [[Islamic extremists]]. [[Armenia]]'s closed border with [[Turkey]] and open border with [[Iran]] is also still guarded by the Russians. On March 11, 2003, Russian president [[Vladimir Putin]] changed the status of Border Guard Service from a separate agency into a branch of Russian [[Federal Security Service]]. The current head of Border Guard Service of Russia is General [[Vladimir Pronichev]]. Border Guard Service of Russia is tasked with a defence of the [[List of countries and territories by land borders|longest national border in the world]]. In April 2012 Vladimir Pronichev announced that the country was planning to build 20 frontier posts in the Arctic region. Reasons for this development can be found in the increased abilities to explore hydrocarbon deposits in the north. It will also give Russia an ability to patrol and service the [[Northern Sea Route]].{{Cite news |title= Russia to create 20 frontier posts in Arctic |url= http://indrus.in/articles/2012/04/16/russia_to_create_20_frontier_posts_in_arctic_15475.html |publisher= Russia & India Report |date= 16 April 2012 |accessdate= 29 April 2012}} In July 2014 [[Ukraine]] opened a criminal case against the head of the Border Guard Service [[Vladimir Kulishov]]; he was accused of financing ‚Äúillegal military groups‚Äù in [[Eastern Ukraine]] [[2014 insurgency in Donbass|who at the time fought against the]] [[Ukrainian army]].{{cite web|url=http://wqad.com/2014/07/22/ukraine-calls-businessman-and-russian-defense-minister-accomplices-of-terrorists/|title=Ukraine calls businessman and Russian defense minister ‚Äòaccomplices of terrorists‚Äô|date=22 July 2014|publisher=wqad.com }}{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2014-07/05/c_126712597.htm|title=Ukraine opens criminal case against Russian Border Service chief - Xinhua - English.news.cn|publisher=[[Xinhua News Agency]] }}{{Cite web |url=http://rupaper.com/post/30752 |title=Archived copy |access-date=2014-07-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140728224641/http://rupaper.com/post/30752 |archive-date=2014-07-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ==Mission== Responsibilities of Border Guard Service of Russia include: * Defence of the Russian national border, prevention of illegal crossing of the land and sea border by people and goods ([[smuggling]]). * Protection of economic interests of the Russian Federation and its natural resources within land and sea border areas, [[territorial waters]] and internal seas, including prevention of [[poaching]] and illegal fishing. * Combat any threats to [[national security]] in the border area, including [[terrorism]] and foreign infiltration. ==Organization== ===Command=== * The head of the Border Service - Army General Vladimir Kulishov (Deputy Director of Russia's FSB) * First Deputy Head of the Border Service - Lieutenant-General Vladimir Rozhkov * First Deputy Head of the Border Service - the head of the Organizational Department, Colonel-General Mansur Masgutovich Valiev * Deputy head of Russia's FSB Border Service - the chief international treaty management Lieutenant-General Alexander L. Manilov * Deputy Chief of the Border Service - Lieutenant-General Victor Trofimovich Trufanov * Deputy Chief of the Border Service - Maj. Gen. Alexander O. Mizon * Deputy Chief of the Border Service - Maj. Gen. Nikolai Nikolaevich Rybalkin * Deputy Chief of the Border Service - Lieutenant General Gennady Semenovich Simuhin ==Old FPS structure== [[File:–≠–º–±–ª–µ–º–∞ –ø–æ–≥—Ä–∞–Ω–≤–æ–π—Å–∫ –†–æ—Å—Å–∏–∏.jpg|thumb|220px|1990s emblem]] '''FPS Russia''', the '''Federal Border Service''' ({{lang-ru|–§–µ–¥–µ—Ä–∞–ª—å–Ω–∞—è –ø–æ–≥—Ä–∞–Ω–∏—á–Ω–∞—è —Å–ª—É–∂–±–∞}}, Federal'naya Pogranichnaya Sluzhba), active from 30 December 1994 to 30 June 2003, was headed by a single centralized system, which included: * Border control; * Foreign intelligence corps; * Operational entities engaged in intelligence, counter, operational investigative activities, to ensure its own security system; * Border guards and other organs of the Border Service, provided by federal law; * FPS Russia border troops; * Military educational institutions, vocational education, * Companies, institutions, and organizations in Russia under the FPS (hereinafter referred to authorities and troops as FPS Russia), according to federal law ==Lineup== Changes in the regional structure of the Border Service, instead of ten regional border (see the old structures FPS) for the new scheme includes regional offices of the border (in the federal districts) and 30 border offices. Includes the Maritime Border Guard. E227 |Section1={{Chembox Identifiers | CASNo_Ref = {{cascite|correct|??}} | CASNo=13780-03-5 | PubChem=26268 | RTECS = EV9294500 | SMILES=OS(=O)[O-].OS(=O)[O-].[Ca+2] | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|correct|chemspider}} | ChemSpiderID = 24475 | InChI = 1/Ca.2H2O3S/c;2*1-4(2)3/h;2*(H2,1,2,3)/q+2;;/p-2 | InChIKey = LVGQIQHJMRUCRM-NUQVWONBAX | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChI = 1S/Ca.2H2O3S/c;2*1-4(2)3/h;2*(H2,1,2,3)/q+2;;/p-2 | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = LVGQIQHJMRUCRM-UHFFFAOYSA-L }} |Section2={{Chembox Properties | Formula=Ca(HSO3)2 | MolarMass=202.22 g/mol | Appearance= | Density= | MeltingPt= | BoilingPt= | Solubility= }} |Section3={{Chembox Hazards | MainHazards= | FlashPt= | AutoignitionPt = }} }} '''Calcium bisulfite''' ('''calcium bisulphite''') is an [[inorganic compound]] which is the [[salt (chemistry)|salt]] of a [[calcium]] cation and a [[bisulfite]] anion. It may be prepared by reacting lime with an excess of [[sulfurous acid]]{{Citation needed|date=September 2013}}, essentially a mixture of [[sulfur dioxide]] and water. It is a weak reducing agent, as is sulfur dioxide, [[sulfite]]s, and any other compound containing sulfur in the +4 oxidation state. As a [[food additive]] it is used as a [[preservative]] under the [[E number]] E227. Calcium bisulfite is an [[acid salt]] and behaves like an acid in aqueous solution. ==See also== * [[Pulp (paper)#History|Pulp (paper)]] * [[Potassium bisulfite]] * [[Sodium bisulfite]] {{Calcium compounds}} [[Category:Food additives]] [[Category:Calcium compounds]] [[Category:Bisulfites]] [[Category:E-number additive]] {{inorganic-compound-stub}}

'''Class traitor''' is a term used mostly in [[Socialism|socialist]] discourse to refer to a member of the [[proletariat]] class who works directly or indirectly against their class interest, or what is against their economic benefit as opposed to that of the [[bourgeoisie]]. It applies particularly to [[soldier]]s, [[police officer]]s, [[Strikebreaker|workers]] who refuse to respect [[Picketing|picket lines]] during a [[Strike action|strike]] and basically anyone [[Wage labour|paid a wage]] who actively facilitates the ''[[status quo]]''. According to [[Barbara Ehrenreich]]: "Class treason is an option at all socioeconomic levels: from the blue-collar man who becomes a security guard employed to harass striking workers, to the heirs of capitalist fortunes who become donors to left-wing causes".<ref>{{cite book|author=Ehrenreich, Barbara|title=Fear of Falling: The Inner Life of the Middle Class|year=1989|pages=154}}</ref>
In Russia before and during the [[Russian Revolution]], the [[Bolsheviks]] and other socialist revolutionary organizations used it to describe the [[White movement|Czarist Army]] and basically any working class citizen who directly opposed their notion of the "[[dictatorship of the proletariat]]". The term was later extended to include the [[Menshevik|Menshevik Russians]] and other supposedly [[counter-revolutionary]] socialist organizations under [[Joseph Stalin]].
The motives behind becoming a traitor to one's class can include the necessity of survival (taking up whatever wage is available), the belief that the person is of a higher class and so has political views that work against the working class, the pressure of conformity, or a rejection of the view that society is divided up into antagonistic classes.

{{refimprove|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox video game |title=Commander in Chief |image=Commander in Chief.jpg |caption=PAL boxart, featuring a stylized derivative of the [[Barack Obama]] [[Barack Obama "Hope" poster|"Hope" poster]] |developer = [[Eversim]] |publisher = Interactive Gaming Software (IGS) |series = |engine = |platforms = [[Personal computer|PC]] |released = July 25, 2008 |genre = [[Government simulation game]]
[[Real-time Strategy]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|Multiplayer]] }} '''''Commander in Chief''''', also known as '''''Geo-Political-Simulator''''' is a [[government simulation game]] that allows a player to simulate being a nation's [[head of state]]. Players have a large amount of control over their nation{{Weasel inline|date=May 2017}}, although this varies based on the form of government the player's nation has. The English version was released on July 25, 2008, and has also been released in French, German, Spanish and Russian versions. The French version has been named Mission-Pr√©sident.https://www.amazon.com/Mission-Pr%C3%A9sident-Geopolitical-Simulator-French-Pc/dp/B0031MC40I ==Gameplay== When starting a new game, players may choose between various scenarios, some of which have set objectives while others are more akin to a "sandbox" mode. Similarly to other government simulation games like [[Democracy (video game)|Democracy]], the player assumes the role of the chief executive of their chosen nation such as the President of the United States of America or the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom. Unlike in the Democracy series the player may amend the constitution of their chosen state and run it as a dictatorship. ==Inaccuracies== The game refers to the position of chief executive as "Head of State" which is not true for all states‚Äîfor example, the [[President of the United States]] is the [[Head of State]], but the [[British Prime Minister]] or [[German Chancellor]] are not‚Äîand in the game, the player plays as the chief executive. In many states there is a distinction between the [[Head of Government]] and the [[Head of State]], with the Head of State often being a ceremonial president or monarch. There is also no distinction in the game between any [[upper house|upper]] and [[lower house|lower]] houses of the [[parliament]]. There are also inaccuracies relating to nations in the game, as many nations are misrepresented. For example, the [[Finnish people|Finnish]] are inaccurately portrayed as being culturally Scandinavian, all Finnish have Swedish names when [[Swedish language|Swedish speakers]] only constitute 5.5% of the population. Other inaccuracies relate to the religion. Certain minority religions, such as the Baha'i faith in India, are not represented in the game, nor are pagans of any kind. There are also mistakes relating to ethnicity. For example, all the people of [[Kyrgyzstan]], as opposed to a sizable minority, are represented as being [[Caucasian race|Caucasian]] rather than east Asian and also all have Russian names. Similarly, most [[Filipino people|Filipinos]] have Indian names.{{citation needed|date = April 2016}} == Reception == {{Video game reviews |state = |IGN = 4.5/10{{cite web|title=Commander in Chief Review - IGN|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2009/01/29/commander-in-chief-geo-political-simulator-2009-review|website=IGN|accessdate=19 April 2016}} |GameZone = 5.0/10{{cite web|title=Commander in Chief - PC - Review|url=http://www.gamezone.com/reviews/commander_in_chief_pc_review|website=GameZone|accessdate=19 April 2016}} | }} The game received mixed to negative reviews.{{cite web|title=Commander in Chief Reviews|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/commander-in-chief|website=Metacritic|accessdate=19 April 2016}} Jason Ocampo of ''IGN'' remarked that the game was "difficult to take as a serious simulation of global politics." A reviewer for GameZone stated that the game was "a pretty hollow attempt to cash in on the recent Presidential elections." ==See also== * [[Rulers of Nations]] * [[Masters of the World]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.commander-in-chief.net/}} * [http://eregime.org/index.php?showforum=12 English forum] * [http://gps-forum.fr/ French forum] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Windows-only games]] [[Category:Real-time strategy video games]] [[Category:Government simulation video games]] [[Category:2008 video games]] [[Category:2009 video games]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in France]]

[[Marxism-leninism]] |youth_wing = |membership_year = |membership = |position = [[Far-left politics|Radical left]] |national = None (2012-today). Close to the [[Galician Nationalist Bloc]][http://bng.gal/blog/2015/09/02/concordancia-entre-bng-e-pcpg-en-traballar-por-unha-candidatura-galega-de-unidade-para-as-xerais/ Concordancia entre BNG e PCPG en traballar por unha candidatura galega de unidade para as xerais.][http://www.sermosgaliza.gal/articulo/politica/bng-pcpg-partillan-necesidade-obter-gripor-parlamentar-galego/20150902171042040360.html BNG e PCPG partillan a necesidade de obter un grupo parlamentar galego.]
Forum for the Galician Communist Unity (2011-2012)[http://www.galiciaconfidencial.com/nova/8854-procuran-union-comunismo-independentista Procuran a uni√≥n do comunismo independentista.]
[[Communist Party of the Peoples of Spain]] (1984-2008) |international = |european = |europarl = |affiliation1_title = Trade union affiliation |affiliation1 = [[Confederaci√≥n Intersindical Galega]] (CIG) |student_wing = |colors = |seats1_title = |seats1 = |symbol = |website = [http://pcdopg.blogspot.com.es/ pcpg.gal] |country = Spain |state = Galicia }} The '''Communist Party of the Galician People''' ({{lang-gl|Partido Comunista do Pobo Galego}}, '''PCPG''') is a [[Galicia (Spain)|Galician]] political organization with a [[Communism|communist]] and [[Galician nationalism|independentist]] ideology founded in 1984. ==History== The PCPG was established in 1984, in parallel to the process of rebuilding unity of the [[pro-soviet]] Spanish communists that was happening across Spain, with the participation of various communist parties, like the [[Party of Communists of Catalonia]] or the [[Unified Communist Party of Spain]], against the prevailing [[eurocommunism]] in the direction of the [[Communist Party of Spain|PCE]] and [[Communist Party of Galicia|PCG]]. This process led to the founding of the Communist Party (PC), the predecessor of which was then [[Communist Party of the Peoples of Spain]] (PCPE). The PCPG has participated in many elections. Its last participation was in the [[Spanish general election, 2008|general elections 2008]], presenting 3 candidates for the [[Spanish Senate]] in the [[province of Ourense]], obtaining 4,243 (1.04% of the total), 3,428 (0.86%) and 3,413 votes (0.83%) respectively. The party also got 507 votes for the [[Congreso de los Diputados]] (188 in the [[Province of Lugo]] and 319 in the [[Province of Ourense]]). In 2008 the PCPG broke with the [[Communist Party of the Peoples of Spain|PCPE]] due to their different view of the [[Galician nationalism|Galician national question]]. Since 2007 the PCPG has participated in the [[Cangas Left Alternative]] coalition in [[Cangas do Morrazo]], which since [[Spanish municipal elections, 2015|2015]] governs that municipality. In 2011 and 2012 the PCPG participated in the Forum for the Galician Communist Unity (FUCG), trying to find the unity of the [[Galician independence|Galician independentist communism]], along with the [[Maoism|maoist]] collective [[Ateneu Prolet√°rio Galego]] and the [[Leninism|classical leninist]] organization [[Forxa]].[http://www.galiciaconfidencial.com/nova/8854-procuran-union-comunismo-independentista Procuran a uni√≥n do comunismo independentista.] Since 2014 the party has become closer to the [[Galician Nationalist Bloc]] (BNG). In the [[European Parliament election, 2014 (Spain)|European elections of 2014]] the party called to vote for The Peoples Decide (a coalition of the [[Galician Nationalist Bloc|BNG]] and various independentist parties from the rest of [[Spain]]).[http://bng.gal/blog/2014/05/23/o-bng-quere-agradecer-o-apoio-recibido-a-candidatura-as-eleccions-europeas/ O BNG quere agradecer o apoio recibido √° candidatura √°s Elecci√≥ns europeas.][http://www.sermosgaliza.gal/articulo/politica/xose-collazo-pobo-galego-ten-ter-forza-represente-europa-forza-bng/20140520211145027511.html Xos√© Collazo, do PCPG: ‚ÄúO pobo galego ten que ter unha forza que o represente en Europa e esa forza √© o BNG‚Äù.] In the [[Spanish municipal elections, 2015|2015 local elections]] the PCPG called to vote the [[Galician Nationalist Bloc|BNG]] candidatures. Various PCPG members joined some lists of the [[Galician Nationalist Bloc|BNG]].[http://pcdopg.blogspot.com.es/2015/05/o-pcpg-sobre-as-proximas-eleicions.html O PCPG SOBRE AS PR√ìXIMAS ELEICI√ìNS MUNICIPAIS DO 24 DE MAIO.] In the [[Spanish general election, 2015|general elections of 2015]] the party joined Us-Galician Candidacy, a coalition led by the [[Galician Nationalist Bloc]], that got the 4.32% of the vote. In the same elections the general secretary of the party run as a candidate for the [[Spanish senate]] in the [[Province of Pontevedra]], getting 31,375 votes (2.08% of the total), failing to win a seat. ==Elections== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! bgcolor="#BFCFFF" | Election ! bgcolor="#BFCFFF" | Votes ! bgcolor="#BFCFFF" | % ! bgcolor="#BFCFFF" | Seats |- | align="right" | [[Galician regional election, 1989]] | align="right" | 989 | align="right" | 0.07 | align="center" | {{Composition bar|0|75|hex={{Communist Party of the Galician People/meta/color}}}} |- | align="right" | [[Spanish general election, 2008#Congress_of_Deputies|Congress of Deputies, 2008]]Lists in [[Ourense (Spanish Congress Electoral District)|Ourense]] and [[Lugo (Spanish Congress Electoral District)|Lugo]]. | align="right" | 507 | align="right" | 0.11 | align="center" | {{Composition bar|0|350|hex={{Communist Party of the Galician People/meta/color}}}} |- |} ===Spanish Senate elections=== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! bgcolor="#BFCFFF" | Year ! bgcolor="#BFCFFF" | Votes ! bgcolor="#BFCFFF" | Percentage ! bgcolor="#BFCFFF" | Elected |- ! {{EngvarB|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Political corruption sidebar|image=[[File:Flag of Kenya.svg|150 px]]}} '''Corruption in the post-colonial [[politics of Kenya|government of Kenya]]''' has a history which spans the era of the [[Jomo Kenyatta]] and [[Daniel arap Moi]]'s [[Kenya African National Union|KANU]] governments, [[Mwai Kibaki]]'s [[Party of National Unity (Kenya)|PNU]] government and the current [[Uhuru Kenyatta]]'s [[Jubillee Party]] government. In the [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] 2012 [[Kenya]] is ranked 139th out of 176 countries for corruption, tied with [[Azerbaijan]], [[Nepal]], [[Nigeria]], and [[Pakistan]] (least corrupt countries are at the top of the list).<ref name="Frequently Asked Questions">[[Transparency International|Transparency International Kenya]], ''[http://www.tikenya.org/faqs.asp Frequently Asked Questions] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060219102648/http://www.tikenya.org/faqs.asp |date=19 February 2006 }}''. Accessed 1 March 2006.</ref>
Most bribes paid by urban residents in Kenya are fairly small but large ones are also taken ‚Äì bribes worth over 50,000 [[Kenyan shilling]]s ([[Euro|‚Ç¨600]], US$700) account for 41% of the total value. There is also corruption on a larger scale with each of the last two regimes being criticised for their involvement.<ref name="Frequently Asked Questions"/>
Despite market reforms, several business surveys reveal that business corruption is still widespread and that companies frequently encounter demands for bribes and informal payments to 'get things done' in Kenya. The public procurement sector in Kenya suffers widespread corruption. The use of agents to facilitate business operations and transactions in Kenya is widespread and poses a risk for companies, particularly at the market entry and business start-up stage.<ref>{{cite web|title=Keny Corruption Profile|url=http://www.business-anti-corruption.com/country-profiles/sub-saharan-africa/kenya/show-all.aspx|publisher=Business Anti-Corruption Portal|accessdate=14 July 2015}}</ref>
Despite positive developments, the Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission (KACC) was disbanded in 2011 and replaced by the newly instated Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission. Observers describe the new agency as superficial.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kenya Corruptiony Profile|url=http://www.business-anti-corruption.com/country-profiles/sub-saharan-africa/kenya/show-all.aspx|publisher=Business Anti-Corruption Portal|accessdate= 14 July 2015}}</ref>
==Corruption scandals==
===Before 1990=== * The first corruption incident in Kenya is widely regarded as the Ngei maize scandal of 1965.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.standardmedia.co.ke/article/1144005108/maize-scandals-a-sign-of-immaturity|title=Maize scandals a sign of immaturity|last=Standard|first=The|work=The Standard|access-date=2017-12-16|language=en}}</ref> [[Paul Ngei]], an independence hero and at the time the Minister for Marketing and Cooperatives, was involved in a maize scandal that caused a national maize shortage.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nation.co.ke/lifestyle/dn2/Ngei-suspended-over-maize-scam/957860-1922204-f7io0tz/index.html|title=Ngei suspended over maize scam|work=Daily Nation|access-date=2017-12-16|language=en-UK}}</ref> The Commission of Maize Inquiry, the first of its kind in independent Kenya, found that Ngei's wife, Emma was getting preferential treatment for her business, Emma Stores (Uhuru Millers of Kangundo) through which she bought maize directly from farmers, which was illegal at the time. * Between 1986 and 1991 the construction of the [[Turkwel Hydroelectric Power Station]] was riddled with claims of corruption. The dam was eventually built at three times the estimated cost, twice the allocated amount and producing energy significantly below capacity.<ref>http://www.thecornerhouse.org.uk/resource/turning-blind-eye#index-02-03-01-00</ref>
===1990‚Äì1999=== * The longest-running scandal is the [[Goldenberg scandal]],<ref name=corpwatch>[http://www.corpwatch.org/article.php?id=9429 Forensic accountants trace Goldenburg transaction] (Corpwatch)</ref> where the Kenyan government subsidised exports of gold, paying exporters in Kenyan Shillings (Sh) 35% over their foreign currency earnings. In this case, the gold was smuggled from Congo. The Goldenberg scandal cost Kenya the equivalent of more than 10% of the country's annual GDP. * In 1998, political scientist Mutahi Ngunyi's NGO ‚Äì Series for Alternative Research in East Africa (SAREAT) engaged [[John Githongo]] to edit a regional political economy magazine, East African Alternatives.<ref name=githongo>[http://www.eastandard.net/archives/InsidePage.php?id=35621 It‚Äôs high treason for Githongo]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (East African Standard)</ref> The magazine folded after an audit instigated by the lead donor [[Ford Foundation]] found suspected misappropriation and collusion on the part of Ngunyi, who was executive director of SAREAT and Dr [[Jonathan Moyo]], who was the programme officer at the Ford Foundation in charge of disbursing the resources to the NGO. They have both been sued and the matter is still in court. It is known that the Ford Foundation has accepted Githongo's offer to be a prosecution witness in the case. * A Sh360 million helicopter servicing contract in South Africa.<ref name=eastandard>[http://www.eastandard.net/archives/InsidePage.php?id=36253 New scandal hangs over Sh2.6b secret Army complex]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (East African Standard)</ref> Military officers had argued that the contract was too extravagant and servicing the helicopters could be done locally. Kenya Air Force (KAF) went ahead to spend Sh108 million as a down payment for servicing the Puma helicopters, whose tail number is logged as 418 at Denel Aviation, a South African firm.
===2000‚Äì2009=== * In 2003, military was split over plans to buy new Czech fighter jets.<ref name=eastandard/> The plan to buy the jet fighters would have cost taxpayers Sh12.3 billion. * A Sh4.1 billion Navy ship deal.<ref name=eastandard/> A Navy project was given to Euromarine, a company associated with Anura Pereira, the tender awarded in a process that has been criticised as irregular. The tender was worth Sh4.1 billion. Military analysts say a similar vessel could have been built for Sh1.8 billion. * [[Chamanlal Kamani]] had been involved in a supply contract, as Kamsons Motors.<ref name=nationaudio>[http://www.nationaudio.com/News/EastAfrican/08102000/Regional/Regional22.html Kenya Graft Watchdog Set to Charge More Suspects]</ref> Kampsons tendered for the supply of Mahindra Jeeps to the Police Department in the mid 1990s for close to Sh1 million (US$13,000) each, at a time when showrooms would have charged customers a sixth of the price. Moreover, the vehicles were being bought for a government department and were therefore imported duty-free. Few of the more than 1,000 units that were imported over several years are in service today. * The Kamanis were also involved in a deal to build a [[Criminal Investigation Department|CID]] forensic laboratory. On 7 June 2004 an amount of $4.7 million was wired back. The payment was a refund against the money paid for the Criminal Investigations Department forensic laboratory.<ref name=nation>[http://www.africafiles.org/article.asp?ID=10731&ThisURL=./kenya.asp&URLName=Kenya When bogus firms wired back Sh1bn] (Daily Nation)</ref> Another euro 5.2 million was paid back in respect of the E-cop project, which involved computerisation of the police force and the installation of spy cameras in Nairobi by Infotalent Systems Private Limited.<ref name=nation /> * The Prisons department lost $3 million after contracting Hallmark International, a company associated with [[Deepak Kamani]] of Kamsons Motors, for the supply of 30 boilers.<ref name=nationaudio/> Only half of the boilers were delivered ‚Äì from India and not the United States as had been agreed. * The construction of Nexus, a secret military communication centre in Karen, Nairobi.<ref name=eastandard /> The Government spent Sh2.6 billion (US$36.9 million) to construct the complex. Three years later, military personnel have not moved into the centre. A phantom company, Nedermar BV Technologies, which is said to have its headquarters in the Netherlands, implemented the secret project situated along Karen South Road. Nedermar is linked to businessman Anura Pereira. However, Pereira has denied this. The tendering process for the Nexus project was circumvented as DoD's Departmental Tender Committee. Funding for the project was made through the Ministry of Transport and Communications. The complex is currently headed by Colonel Philip Kameru. Nexus was first meant to be an ammunition dumpsite before it was turned into a military communication and operations centre. Construction continued without any site visits by either the DoD staff or Ministry of Public Works officials. The Nexus project was implemented during the tenure of General Joseph Kibwana. * In 2005 plans to buy a sophisticated ¬£20 million passport equipment system from France,<ref name=guardian>[https://www.theguardian.com/kenya/story/0,12689,1254928,00.html report on the Anglo Leasing scandal] (Guardian)</ref><ref name=TI>[http://www.transparency.org/news_room/latest_news/press_releases_nc/2006/2006_01_23_kenya_githongo It's time to tell the Kenyan people the truth about the anglo-leasing corruption scandal] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060215231426/http://www.transparency.org/news_room/latest_news/press_releases_nc/2006/2006_01_23_kenya_githongo |date=15 February 2006}} (Transparency International)</ref> as government wanted to replace its passport printing system, created conditions for [[Anglo Leasing Scandal|corruption scandal]]. The transaction was originally quoted at 6 million euros from Fran√ßois Charles Oberthur of Paris (a supplier of Visa and MasterCards) but was awarded to a British firm, the Anglo-Leasing and Finance Company Limited, at 30 million euros, who would have sub-contracted the same French firm to do the work. Despite the lack of competitive tendering Anglo Leasing was paid a "commitment fee" of more than ¬£600,000. Anglo Leasing's agent is a Liverpool-based firm, Saagar Associates, owned by a woman whose family has enjoyed close links with senior officials in the Moi regime. Company records show Saagar Associates is owned by Mrs [[Sudha Ruparell]], a 47-year-old Kenyan woman. Ruparell is the daughter of [[Chamanlal Kamani]], the multimillionaire patriarch of a business family that enjoyed close links with senior officials in the Moi regime. Anglo Leasing made a repayment of euro 956,700 through a telegraphic transfer from Schroeder & Co Bank AG, Switzerland on 17 May 2004.<ref name=nation /> * The local chapter of [[Transparency International]] and the Kenya National Commission on Human Rights (KNCHR), a government body released a report in February 2006, stating that between January 2003 and September 2004, the [[National Rainbow Coalition]] government spent about $12-million on cars that were mostly for the personal use of senior government officials.<ref name=ips>[http://www.ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=32054 Vehicle Saga Shows Parliament Has Few Budgetary Teeth] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060207074302/http://www.ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=32054 |date=7 February 2006}} (Inter Press Service News Agency)</ref> The vehicles included 57 [[Mercedes-Benz]], as well as [[Toyota Land Cruiser|Land Cruiser]]s, [[Mitsubishi Pajero]]s, [[Range Rover]]s, [[Nissan Terrano]]s and [[Nissan Patrol]]s. The $12-million substantially exceeded what the government spent over the 2003/04 financial year on controlling malaria ‚Äì "the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in Kenya", says the report. * In late February 2006, the newspaper ''[[The Standard (Kenya)|The Standard]]'' ran a story claiming that president [[Mwai Kibaki]] and senior opposition figure [[Kalonzo Musyoka]] had been holding secret meetings. On 2 March at 1:00 am local time (2200 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]] on the 1st), masked gunmen carrying [[AK-47]]s raided multiple editorial offices of ''The Standard'', and of its television station [[Kenya Television Network|KTN]]. They kicked and beat staff members, forcibly took computers and transmission equipment, burned all the copies of the 2 March edition of the newspaper, and damaged the [[Printing press|press]]es. At KTN, they shut down the power, putting the station off the air. Initially, the Kenyan information minister claimed no knowledge of the raid, but it has since revealed that Kenyan police were responsible. The Ministry of the Internal Security later stated that the incident was to safeguard state security. "If you rattle a snake you must be prepared to be bitten by it," [[John Michuki]] said. Three journalists at ''The Standard'', arrested after the critical story was printed, are still being held without charge.<ref>[[BBC]]: [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/4765250.stm Kenya admits armed raids on paper]</ref><ref>[[Reuters]]: [http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/594f371980df55020e96a8268a9aa506.htm Leading media house shut down by armed men]</ref> The story now also features the bizarre case of two Armenian businessmen, mocked in the press for their taste for heavy gold chains, watches and rings, referred to as [[Mercenaries]], who the opposition says led the raid and had shady dealings with Kibaki's government.<ref>[[Independent Online (South Africa)|IOL]] [http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=68&art_id=qw1142947800430B251 Kibaki in trouble as parliament re-opens]</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Revealed: All about Arturs |url=http://www.eastandard.net/archives/InsidePage.php?id=1143975198 |work=[[The Standard (Kenya)|The Standard]] |date=28 September 2007 |accessdate=2008-12-12 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Artur brothers were drug traffickers who enjoyed state security: Report |url=http://www.nationmedia.com/dailynation/nmgcontententry.asp?category_id=1&newsid=107377|work=[[Daily Nation (Kenya)|Daily Nation]] |date=28 September 2007 |accessdate=2007-09-28 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080119215417/http://www.nationmedia.com/dailynation/nmgcontententry.asp?category_id=1&newsid=107377 |archivedate=19 January 2008}}</ref> * In November 2006, the government was accused of failing to act on a banking fraud scam worth $1.5bn involving [[money laundering]] and [[tax evasion]], reported by whistle-blowers as early as 2004. Investigators believe sums worth 10% of Kenya's national income are involved. A recent auditor's report says the scale of the operations "threatens the stability of the Kenyan economy".<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/low/africa/6123832.stm Bank scam threatens Kenya economy] [[BBC]]</ref> * In November 2006, British Foreign Office minister [[Kim Howells]] warned, that corruption in Kenya is increasing the UK's exposure to drug trafficking and terrorism. "People can be bought, right from the person who works at the docks in Mombasa up to the government. (...) This weakness has been recognised by drug-traffickers and probably by terrorists too." Said Howells for the [[BBC]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/6135244.stm Kenya corruption 'threatening UK'] [[BBC]]</ref> *On 31 August 2007, ''[[The Guardian]]'' newspaper featured on its front page a story about more than [[Pound sterling|GBP]] 1 billion transferred out of Kenya by the family and associates of former Kenyan leader Daniel arap Moi. The Guardian sourced the information from the [[WikiLeaks]] article ''The looting of Kenya under President Moi'' and its analysis of a leaked investigative document ("the [[Kroll Inc.|Kroll]] report") prepared for the [[Mwai Kibaki|Kibaki]] government in 2004 to try to recover money stolen during Moi's rule.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/aug/31/kenya.topstories3 |title=The looting of Kenya |date=31 August 2007 |author=Xan Rice |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=2008-02-29}}</ref> * On 2007-09-06 parliament passed the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, restricting investigations by the [[Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission]] to offences committed prior to May 2003, excluding the Goldenberg and Anglo-Leasing scandals and other major cases. The move was condemned by anti-corruption campaigners; [[Mwalimu Mati]], former chief executive of the [[Transparency International]] Kenya Chapter, declared that "grand corruption has swallowed the government and parliament that Kenyans elected to fight it in 2002".<ref>{{cite news|title=Uproar over move on economic crimes |url=http://www.eastandard.net/archives/InsidePage.php?id=1143974522 |work=[[The Standard (Kenya)|The Standard]] |date=12 December 2008 |accessdate=2007-09-14 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> In response to public outrage generated by the move, President Kibaki announced that he would veto the bill. * In September 2007, [[WikiLeaks]] released documents exposing a 500 million Kenyan shilling payroll fraud at Egerton University] and subsequent cover up, now the subject of ongoing legal dispute in the High Court.{{Citation needed|date=November 2007}} * On 28 September 2007, [[WikiLeaks]] released 28 investigative documents] exposing a US$1.5 billion money laundering fraud by [[Charter House Bank Ltd]]. Re-reported in the Kenyan Standard newspaper.{{Citation needed|date=November 2007}} * In June 2008, the [[Grand Regency Scandal]] broke, wherein the Central Bank of Kenya is alleged to have secretly sold a luxury hotel in Nairobi to an unidentified group of Libyan investors for more than 4 billion Kenyan Shillings (approx US $60 million) below the appraised market value. Finance Minister [[Amos Kimunya]] negotiated the sale, and was censured in a near-unanimous motion by the Kenyan Parliament, though he vehemently denies the charges. This follows on the heels of the [[Safaricom IPO]], overseen by Kimunya, which has been alternatively praised and questioned for possible corruption in the execution of the sale. [[Safaricom]] is the largest mobile phone service provider in Kenya, having operated with a near-government monopoly for many years. The government of Kenya sold its 50% stake in Safaricom in the IPO. * In January 2009, a scandal became public over the [[2009 Kenyan Maize Scandal|sale of imported maize]]. * The [[2009 Triton Oil Scandal]] regarding the unauthorised releasing of oil by [[Kenya Pipeline Company]] (KPC) without informing financiers became public in January 2009.
===2010‚Äìpresent=== * In October 2012, allegations surfaced that top Foreign Affairs ministry officials ignored land offered by Japan that could have saved the country loss of Sh1.1 billion.<ref>http://www.nation.co.ke/News/Shame%20of%20graft%20that%20is%20the%20Tokyo%20embassy%20report%20/-/1056/1033292/-/10xk82kz/-/index.html</ref> The scandal led to the resignation of the then Foreign Affairs Minister [[Moses Wetangula]]. * In October 2010, the Department of Defence uncovered a bribery scandal involving senior Kenya Defence Force Officers in the corrupt Sh1.6 billion purchase of armoured personnel carriers from South African company OTT Technologies (Pty) Ltd. Minister of Defence Yusuf Haji retired several high-ranking officers in January 2011 <ref name=standardmedia>[https://archive.is/20120910153835/http://www.standardmedia.co.ke/InsidePage.php?id=2000020947&catid=4&a=1 25 October 2010: DoD Uncovers Tender Corruption]</ref> accused of taking bribes by OTT Technologies (Pty) Ltd, and the matter was referred for further investigation to Parliament.<ref name=nairobistar>[https://archive.is/20131009065158/http://www.nairobistar.com/national/national/11250-mps-grill-haji-over-military-hardware-deals- 19 January 2011: Min/Def retires KDF officers Involved in APC Corruption]</ref> The September 2012 Report on Military Modernization Programmes by the Departmental Committee on Defence and Foreign Relations found that the irregular procurement of the [[PUMA M26-15|PUMA M26]] armoured carriers had violated multiple sections of the Public Procurement Act 2005, that OTT Technologies (Pty) Ltd's business partners in Kenya had been identified by the US Government as being involved in international crime and drugs smuggling, and recommended that OTT Technologies (Pty) Ltd be barred from doing any business with the Government of Kenya in the future.<ref name=nairobistar.com>[https://archive.is/20131009065151/http://www.nairobistar.com/national/national/21417-military-mps-probe-purchase-of-military-carriers 19 April 2011: Launch of Parliamentary Committee to investigate APC Bribery]</ref> In 2014, the same company was accused by the government of Mozambique of irregular tax and export control activities in the transport of similar armoured carriers through Mozambique for onward trafficking into Africa.<ref name=verfade.co.mz>[http://www.verdade.co.mz/destaques/democracia/45012-empresa-que-monta-veiculos-blindados-em-mocambique-e-ilegalq Company that Mounted Armored Vehicles to the United Nations Operates Illegally in Mozambique (Portuguese)]</ref>
==Security contracts==
Listed in Githongo's dossier<ref>[http://www.africafocus.org/docs06/git0602.php Githongo's dossier]</ref> are a number of companies that won security-related contracts :- {|class="wikitable" |- !Payee !! Purpose !! Amount (millions) !! Signatories !! Date signed |- |Anglo Leasing || Forensic LAB ‚Äì CID || US$54.56 || PS-Treasury<br>PS-Internal Security OP ||align=right| 16 August 2001 |- |Silverson Establishment || Security Vehicles || USD 90 || PS-Treasury<br>PS-Internal Security OP ||align=right| 16 August 2001 |- | Apex Finance || Police Security || USD 30 || PS-Treasury<br>PS-Internal Security OP ||align=right| 9 February 2002 |- |LBA Systems || Security-MET || USD 35 || PS-Treasury ||align=right| 7 June 2002 |- | Apex Finance || Police Security || USD 31.8 || PS-Treasury<br>PS-Internal Security OP ||align=right| 14 June 2002 |- |Universal Satspace || Satellite Services || USD 28.11 || PS-Treasury<br>PS-Transport ||align=right| 11 July 2002 |- |First Mechantile || Police Security || USD 11.8 || PS-Treasury<br>PS-Transport ||align=right| 11 July 2002 |- |Apex Finance Corp || Police Security || USD 12.8 || PS-Treasury<br>PS-Internal Security OP ||align=right| 12 July 2002 |- |LBA Systems || Prison security || USD 29.7 || PS-Treasury ||align=right| 19 November 2002 |- |Nedemar || Security || USD 36.9 || PS-Treasury<br>PS-Transport ||align=right| 19 November 2002 |- |Midland Bank || Police security || USD 49.65 || PS-Treasury ||align=right| 29 May 2003 |- |Naviga Capital || Oceanographic vessel || EUR 26.6 || PS-Treasury ||align=right| 15 July 2003 |- |Empressa || Oceanographic vessel || EUR 15 || PS-Treasury ||align=right| 15 July 2003 |- |Euromarine || Oceanographic vessel || EUR 10.4 || PS-Treasury ||align=right| 15 July 2003 |- |Infotalent || Police security || EUR 59.7 || PS-Treasury<br>PS-Internal Security OP ||align=right| 19 November 2003 |- |Apex Finance Corp || Police security || EUR 40 || PS-Treasury<br>PS-Internal Security OP ||align=right| 17 December 2003 |- |Ciaria Systems Inc || Design, maintain satellite NSIS || USD 44.56 || PS Treasury<br>Director NSIS ||align=right| 20 January 2004 |}
==Anti-corruption authorities== {{Further|Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission}}
The [[Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission]] (EACC) was established after [[Kenya]]‚Äôs President [[Mwai Kibaki]] signed the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Act on 29 August 2011. The EACC replaced the [[Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission]] (KACC).<ref name="eacc.go.ke">{{cite web |url=http://www.eacc.go.ke/default.asp?pageid=2 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-03-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130704061611/http://www.eacc.go.ke/default.asp?pageid=2 |archivedate=4 July 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Previously, the Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission (KACC) was established in April 2003 to replace the [[Kenya Anti-Corruption Authority]], after Parliament enacted new legislation.<ref name="eacc.go.ke"/>

The '''Defence Force Discipline Act''' of 1982 is the foundation of military law in [[Australia]]. It is legislation that governs the Australian military. Main points of reference is discipline of defence members, powers of service police, rights of defence members, punishment and the Jurisdiction of the DFDA in regard to state territory and commonwealth law. Section 114, added to the Act in 2007, created the [[Australian Military Court]], later deemed constitutionally invalid.
==External links== * [http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/cth/consol_act/dfda1982188/ Defence Force Discipline Act 1982]

{{Multiple issues| {{expert| Economics |date=January 2013}} {{Disputed|date=January 2013}} {{Onesource|date=January 2013}} }}
'''Dollar voting''' is an analogy that has been used to refer to the impact of consumer choice on producers' actions through the flow of consumer payments to producers for their goods and services.
==Overview== In some Principles of Economics textbooks of the mid-20th Century, the term was used to describe the process by which consumers' choices influence firms' production decisions. Products that consumers buy will tend to be produced in the future. Products that do not sell as well as expected will receive fewer productive resources in the future. Effectively, according to this analogy, consumers are voting for "winners" and "losers" with their purchases. This argument was used to explain and justify market allocations of goods and services under the catchphrase "consumer sovereignty".
Consumer boycotts have from time to time been proposed as a useful approach to change producers' behavior. The goals of selective boycotts, or dollar voting, have been diverse, and have included a desire to see decreased corporate revenues, removal of key executives, or reputational damage.<ref>Godfrey, Neale. "Put Your Money Where Your Mouth Is. Vote With Your Dollars." The Huffington Post. February 20, 2017. Accessed June 10, 2018. https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/put-your-money-where-your-mouth-is-vote-with-your_us_58a92d46e4b0fa149f9ac73c.</ref>
The modern idea of dollar voting can be traced back to its development by James Buchanan in ''Individual Choice in Voting and the Market''. As a public choice theorist, Buchanan equated economic participation by the individual as a form of pure democracy.<ref>Buchanan, James M. "Individual Choice in Voting and the Market." Journal of Political Economy 62, no. 4 (1954): 334-43. https://www.jstor.org/stable/1827235.</ref> Also known as political consumerism, dollar voting‚Äôs history in the United States can be followed back to the American Revolution, when colonists boycotted several British products in protest of taxation without representation.<ref>Newman, Benjamin J., and Brandon L. Bartels. "Politics at the Checkout Line: Explaining Political Consumerism in the United States." Political Research Quarterly 64, no. 4 (2011): 803-17. https://www.jstor.org/stable/23056348.</ref>
Dollar voting has been increasingly thought to be a useful tool in changing producers' behavior. If voters feel disenfranchised politically, they may turn to using their spending power to influence politics and the economy. Consumers aiming to use dollar voting ultimately hope to impact society‚Äôs values and use of resources.<ref>Newman, Benjamin J., and Brandon L. Bartels. "Politics at the Checkout Line: Explaining Political Consumerism in the United States." Political Research Quarterly 64, no. 4 (2011): 803-17. https://www.jstor.org/stable/23056348.</ref>
==Criticisms== The idea of dollar voting has faced criticism for its class implications. In modern America, dollar voting is often seen being used by middle and upper middle class consumers who spend their money at local farmers markets, community agricultural programs, and the preparation of ‚Äúslow food‚Äù.<ref>Haydu, Jeffrey. "Consumer Citizenship and Cross-Class Activism: The Case of the National Consumers' League, 1899-1918." Sociological Forum 29, no. 3 (2014): 628-49. https://www.jstor.org/stable/43653954.</ref> These purchases do not affect low-income producers and consumer in the food market.<ref>Haydu, Jeffrey. "Consumer Citizenship and Cross-Class Activism: The Case of the National Consumers' League, 1899-1918." Sociological Forum 29, no. 3 (2014): 628-49. https://www.jstor.org/stable/43653954.</ref> Moreover, dollar voting has been criticized as a form of conspicuous consumption for the well-off, serving more as a display of morality than of actual consumer preference.<ref>Haydu, Jeffrey. "Consumer Citizenship and Cross-Class Activism: The Case of the National Consumers' League, 1899-1918." Sociological Forum 29, no. 3 (2014): 628-49. https://www.jstor.org/stable/43653954.</ref>
Dollar voting has also been criticized for being a sort of consumer vigilantism, as while most economists and economic philosophers accept that consumers have a right to their personal moral choices in the market, large-scale movements to influence consumer spending could have potentially dangerous implications.<ref>HUSSAIN, WAHEED. "Is Ethical Consumerism an Impermissible Form of Vigilantism?" Philosophy & Public Affairs 40, no. 2 (2012): 111-43. https://www.jstor.org/stable/23261269.</ref>
As more consumer activists find ways to use the power of their dollar, efforts at encouraging corporations and firms to act in environmentally friendly ways have become popular. However, it is unclear whether or not a firm that creates negative environmental externalities will legitimately change its method of production to satisfy such desires.<ref>Johnston, Jos√©e. "The Citizen-Consumer Hybrid: Ideological Tensions and the Case of Whole Foods Market." Theory and Society 37, no. 3 (2008): 229-70. https://www.jstor.org/stable/40211036.</ref> It also has the potential to move citizens away from law making efforts that check unmitigated self interest in both firms and consumers, and instead shifts this responsibility almost completely over to the market.
== See also == * [[Crowd funding]] * [[Demonstrated preference]] * [[Dispersed knowledge]] * [[Ethical consumerism]] * [[Other people's money (disambiguation)|Other people's money]] * [[Tax choice]] * [[Consumer sovereignty]] * [[Buycott.com]]

[[File:Don't Just Vote, Get Active!.png|thumb|right|"Don't Just Vote" logo from CrimethInc. promotional campaign leaflet]]
'''Don't Just Vote, Get Active''', also known as '''Don't Just (Not) Vote'''<ref>{{cite journal |date=Winter 2006 |title=The Fate of the Black Pearl |journal=[[Rolling Thunder (zine)|Rolling Thunder]] |issue=2 |pages=24‚Äì27}}</ref> ('''DJV''') was an [[Openness|open]], [[decentralized]] national campaign in the [[United States of America]] initiated by the [[CrimethInc.|CrimethInc. Ex-Workers Collective]] and its allies.<ref name="rev">{{cite book |last=Andersen |first=Mark |title=All the Power : Revolution Without Illusion |publisher=Punk Planet Books |year=2004 |isbn=978-1-888451-72-6 }}</ref> DJV was publicly announced at the [[NCOR|National Conference on Organized Resistance]] (NCOR) in 2004 and was an activist-orientated propaganda initiative focused on demonstrating the effectiveness of [[direct democracy]] and [[direct action]] over [[Representation (politics)|political representation]].<ref name="dubvo">{{cite journal|date=Spring 2005 |title=The Secret World of Duvbo |journal=[[Green Anarchy]] |issue=19 |url=http://www.greenanarchy.org/index.php?action=viewwritingdetail&writingId=163 |accessdate=2008-01-13 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071110060003/http://www.greenanarchy.org/index.php?action=viewwritingdetail&writingId=163 |archivedate=2007-11-10 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The campaign was interpreted by some as a [[counterpoint]] to Punkvoter and other anti-[[George W. Bush presidential campaign, 2004|Bush]] voter participation efforts.<ref name="rev"/> However, organizers initially conceived of the campaign without knowledge of the Punkvoter campaign.
== Overview == According to one of the 20,000 voter's guides distributed by those involved with the campaign before the [[U.S. presidential election, 2004|2004 presidential election]], "Voting for people to represent your interests is the least efficient and effective means of applying political power. The alternative, broadly speaking, is acting directly to represent your interests yourself." Unlike previous projects critical of [[electoral system|electoral politics]], DJV deliberately avoided the voting vs. abstention argument that is common in the [[anarchist]] milieu.
The campaign was characterised by ''[[The American Prospect]]'' as "a clear inheritor of the spirit of [[May 1968 in France|1968]]", citing its willingness to celebrate in the street, regardless of the outcome.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Mattson |first=Kevin |date=March 2005 |title=Goodbye to All That |journal=[[American Prospect]] |url=http://www.prospect.org/cs/articles?articleId=9389 |accessdate=2008-01-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080127232809/http://www.prospect.org/cs/articles?articleId=9389 |archivedate=2008-01-27 |df= }}</ref> In the election's aftermath, Don't Just Vote, Get Active endorsed the Anarchist Resistance "call to action" against the [[United States presidential inaugurations|2005 presidential inauguration]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.anarchistresistance.org/archive/j20-anarchistcall.shtml |title=Inauguration 2005: Anarchist Resistance Call to Action |accessdate=2008-01-13 |work=Anarchist Resistance |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120211027/http://www.anarchistresistance.org/archive/j20-anarchistcall.shtml |archivedate=2008-11-20 |df= }}</ref>
== Criticism == The campaign was criticised in ''[[Green Anarchy]]'' for its credulous if qualified endorsement of voting, accusing [[CrimethInc.]] of offering "a soothing middle ground" instead of outright rejecting [[Statism|statist]] mechanisms of control.<ref name="greenarchy">{{cite journal|authorlink=CrimethInc. |vauthors= |date=Fall‚ÄìWinter 2004 |title=Don't Just Vote-Get Active: A Community Non-Partisan Voters' Guide 2004 |journal=[[Green Anarchy]] |issue=18 |url=http://www.greenanarchy.org/index.php?action=viewwritingdetail&writingId=342 |accessdate=2008-01-13 |quote= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071111064112/http://www.greenanarchy.org/index.php?action=viewwritingdetail&writingId=342 |archivedate=2007-11-11 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In a reworking of the campaign's slogan, the magazine exhorted readers "don't JUST be active, WAKE THE FUCK UP!"<ref name="greenarchy"/> [[Mark Andersen]], in ''All the Power: Revolution without Illusion'' praised the initially empowering message of the campaign but criticised it for "a slide toward insular subcultural politics", drawing note to the recurrent phrases "[[tyranny of the majority]]", "living without permission" and "autonomy" which he claimed evinced an "esoteric, self-referential approach" which would turn acolytes into "radical [[navel-gazing|navel-gazers]]".<ref name="rev"/>
==See also== {{Portal|Anarchism|Politics}} *[[Anarchism in the United States]] *[[Bl(A)ck Tea Society]], an organization created for the purpose of protesting the [[2004 Democratic National Convention]] *[[Criticisms of electoralism]]
