The front cover of a ''List of Lights'' volume. |- ! Purpose: | Provide info on navigational aids outside the U.S. |- ! Publication Frequency: | Yearly |- ! Published by: | [[National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency]] (NGA) |- ! Available Online: | Yes{{cite web|url=http://www.nga.mil/portal/site/maritime/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-03-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070307132409/http://www.nga.mil/portal/site/maritime/ |archivedate=2007-03-07 |df= }} |} A '''list of lights''' is a publication describing [[lighthouse]]s and other aids to maritime [[navigation]]. Most such lists are published by national [[hydrographic office]]s. ==United States== The United States [[National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency]] publishes a list of lights. The book is usually referred to as the ''List of Lights'', and should not be confused with the [[U.S. Coast Guard]]'s ''[[Light List]]''. The ''List of Lights'' is published in seven volumes, as Publication numbers 110 through 116. Each volume contains lights and other aids to navigation that are maintained by or under the authority of other governments. Each volume corresponds to a defined geographic region, and contains more complete information about the navigational aids than can be conveniently shown on nautical charts. New editions are published annually for every volume. In addition to information on lighted aids to navigation and sound signals in foreign waters, the NGA ''List of Lights'' provides information on storm signals, signal stations, [[racon]]s, [[radiobeacon]]s, and [[radio direction finder]] calibration stations located at or near lights. Publication number 117, [[Radio Navigational Aids]], is the primary source for details on radio navigational aids. The ''List of Lights'' does not include information on lighted buoys inside harbors. It does include certain aeronautical lights situated near the coast; however, these lights are not designed for marine navigation and are subject to unreported changes. [[Notice to Mariners|Notices to mariners]] provided by other countries are the main source for correctional information source for the ''Lists of Lights'', however other sources, such as ship reports, are also used. ==See also== Similar publications are published by the U.S. Coast Guard for U.S. civilian and commercial use, and by the Canadian Coast Guard. {{Portal|Nautical|Lighthouses}} * ''[[American Practical Navigator]]'' * [[Buoy]] * ''[[Coast Pilots]]'' * ''[[Light List]]'' * [[Local Notice to Mariners]] * [[Notice to mariners]] * ''[[Sailing Directions]]'' ==External links== * [http://msi.nga.mil/NGAPortal/MSI.portal?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=msi_portal_page_62&pubCode=0007 NGA ''List of Lights'' Online] * [http://www.notmar.gc.ca/ Notices to mariners], Canadian Coast Guard ==References== {{reflist}} '''Attribution''' {{Include-USGov|agency=National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency|article= [[s:The American Practical Navigator/Chapter 4#409. '''Lloviznando Cantos''' is a [[Venezuela]]-based artists collective founded in 2001. The collective is a contemporary heir to the historical traditions of the [[Nueva Canci√≥n]] movement of the 1960s and 1970s. Their stated reason for being is to consolidate and bring to the masses political and social message of solidarity as conceived in the "socialist revolution" promoted by former Venezuelan president [[Hugo Rafael Ch√°vez Fr√≠as]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Lloviznando Cantos: ‚ÄúSomos un movimiento que enfrenta con poes√≠a a los detractores de la revoluci√≥n‚Äù|url=http://www.noticias24.com/venezuela/noticia/131533/la-agrupacion-lloviznando-cantos-habla-sobre-su-trabajo-durante-la-campana-presidencial/|website=noticias24.com|publisher=noticias24.com|accessdate=18 June 2015}}</ref>
The collective has played in places such as Chile, Argentina, Uruguay, Bolivia, Ecuador, Panama, Nicaragua, Guatemala, El Salvador, as well as in Europe.
As heirs of the Nueva Canci√≥n movement, they are performing what they call the "Canci√≥n Socialista" (Socialist Song).

'''Sir Michael Hintze''', {{post-nominals|country=AUS|AM|size=100%}} (born 27 July 1953) is a British-Australian businessman, philanthropist and [[Conservative Party UK|Conservative Party]] patron, based in the United Kingdom.
According to the 2016 [[Forbes|''Forbes'' magazine]] list of The World's Billionaires, he was the world's 1,011th richest person, with a [[net worth]] of approximately {{USD}}1.8 billion;<ref name=Forbes2016>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/michael-hintze/ |title=Michael Hintze|work=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=9 June 2016|date=2016}}</ref><ref name=DMailBio/><ref name=Telg8821348/> and according to the Australian ''[[BRW Rich 200]]'' Hintze was Australia's 37th wealthiest individual with a net worth of {{AUD}}1.32 billion in 2016.<ref name=BRW2016>{{cite journal|url=http://www.afr.com/leadership/brw-lists/brw-rich-200-list-2016-20160526-gp4ejn|title=BRW Rich 200 list 2016 |journal=[[Financial Review]]|location=Australia|date=27 May 2016|accessdate=9 June 2016|editor=Stensholt, John}}</ref>
==Early life== After his grandparents fled from Russia after the 1917 [[Bolshevik revolution]],<ref name=Telg8821348/> he was born in the Chinese city of [[Harbin]]. After [[Mao Zedong]] and the [[Chinese Communist Party]] took over power, his refugee parents left for Australia.<ref name=DMailBio/>
Raised by his secretary mother in Sydney, he was educated at the local [[Congregation of Christian Brothers|Christian Brothers]] school. He then studied at the [[University of Sydney]] where he obtained a [[Bachelor of Science|BSc]] degree in physics in 1975 and a [[Bachelor of Engineering|BE]] degree in engineering in 1977, residing at [[St John's College, University of Sydney|St John's College]]. He also holds an [[Master of Science|MSc]] degree in Acoustics from the [[University of New South Wales]], an [[Master of Business|MBA]] degree from [[Harvard Business School]], and an Honorary Doctorate of Business from the University of New South Wales.
On graduation, he joined the [[Australian Army]] for three years, rising to the rank of [[Captain (armed forces)|captain]].<ref name=DMailBio/> Following that, he worked as an [[electrical engineering|electrical]] [[design engineer]] for Civil and Civic Pty Ltd. in Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://michael-hintze.com/bio/|website=www.michael-hintze.com|accessdate=9 January 2018}}</ref>
==Career== Moving to New York to train in financial services, he worked for [[Salomon Brothers]] as a fixed income trader and at [[Credit Suisse First Boston]]. Relocating to London with them, he then joined [[Goldman Sachs]], where his ultimate position was Co-head of the UK Shares Product. He left the firm in 1995.
In 1999 he launched his own asset management firm, [[CQS (Hedge Fund)|CQS]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cqscapital.com/ |title=CQS - CQS is a global multi-strategy asset management firm |website=Cqscapital.com |date= |accessdate=2016-06-30}}</ref> and has been cited in the press as one of the highest paid people in the [[City of London]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/news/article.html?in_article_id=404355&in_page_id=2 |title=Hedge fund boss with a '¬£60m pay packet' |work=This is money |date= |accessdate= |publisher= |author= |location= }}</ref> Hintze was ranked No. 5 on [[Financial News]]' FN100 Most Influential list in the hedge fund category.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.efinancialnews.com/fn100/2012#Hedge%20funds |title=Financial News FN100 Most Influential List |work=eFinancial News |date= |accessdate= |publisher= |author= |location= }}</ref> CQS Asset Management, which has been described as "one of the world's leading credit market players"<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/c5ddc4f4-0ab2-11df-b35f-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1xfGTDwcl |work=[[Financial Times]] |date=27 January 2010 |title=CQS warns over housing market and economy |accessdate=14 June 2012 }}</ref> has assets under management reported at $11 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hedgefundsreview.com/hedge-funds-review/interview/1899531/cqs-diversified-fund-segregated-portfolio-alpha-cqs |title=Archived copy |accessdate=14 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111223234127/http://www.hedgefundsreview.com/hedge-funds-review/interview/1899531/cqs-diversified-fund-segregated-portfolio-alpha-cqs |archivedate=23 December 2011 }}</ref> The CQS Directional Opportunities Fund, which is managed by Hintze, was ranked #3 on [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]'s list of the 100 top-performing large hedge funds for 2012.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-01-03/the-100-top-performing-large-hedge-funds.html | work=Bloomberg | title=The 100 Top-Performing Large Hedge Funds |date=3 January 2013 |accessdate=2016-06-30 |publisher= |author= |location= }}</ref>
In 2013, Hintze's CQS received awards for the "Best Hedge Fund Manager Overall," "Best Hedge Fund Manager in Credit," and "Best Multi-Hedge Fund Manager" at the [[Financial News]] Awards for Excellence in Institutional Hedge Fund Management.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.efinancialnews.com/story/2013-05-09/financial-news-hedge-fund-awards-2013-winners-michael-hintze-cqs?ref=email_41688 |work=[[Financial News]] |date=4 June 2013 |title=Hat-trick for CQS at FN Hedge Fund Awards |accessdate= |publisher= |author= |location= }}</ref> CQS was reported to be on the opposite side<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2012-05-15/news/31711565_1_jpmorgan-chase-hedge-funds-jpmorgan-trade |work=The Economic Times |date=15 May 2012 |title=Hedge funds eye further profits from JPMorgan losses |accessdate=14 June 2012 }} {{Dead link|date=April 2014|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> of the infamous [[2012 JPMorgan Chase trading loss|JPMorgan trade]] by Bruno Iksil, nicknamed the London Whale, in which JPMorgan lost an estimated $2 billion. The total gains by CQS are unknown.<ref>Fletcher, Laurence; Wilkes, Tommy. [https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-jpmorgan-hedgefunds-idUSLNE84E01T20120515 "Hedge funds eye further profits from JPMorgan losses"], ''Reuters'', 15 May 2012. Accessed 12 July 2016.</ref>
Hintze is credited by veteran economic commentator and journalist [[Alex Brummer]] with warning about the state of [[UK banking]], the outlook for the [[UK housing market]], and the scale of [[toxic-debt]] on the balance sheets of UK banks.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/news/article-2025039/ALEX-BRUMMER-Euro-banks-facing-crunch.html |work=[[This is Money]]/[[Daily Mail]]|date=11 August 2011 |author=Brummer, Alex |author-link=Alex Brummer |title=Euro banks facing a crunch |accessdate=14 June 2012}}</ref>
===Professional Appointments=== Due to his expertise in global financial markets, Hintze has been tapped to sit on a number of boards and government panels. He was appointed by the [[Department of the Treasury (Australia)|Australian Treasury]] to sit on a four-person International Advisory Panel to support the Financial Systems Inquiry (FSI), which is focused on issues impacting [[Australia's economy]] such as technological change, Australia's global competitiveness and offshore regulatory frameworks.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.financialstandard.com.au/news/view/38843954 |title=Michael Hintze to join Financial Systems Inquiry |work=Financial Standard |accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref>
Hintze was appointed by [[Pope Francis]] to the board of the Vatican Bank (officially known as the [[Institute for the Works of Religion]]).<ref name="VIS 2014">{{cite web | url=http://visnews-en.blogspot.co.at/2014/07/new-economic-framework-for-holy-see.html | title=New Economic Framework for the Holy See | publisher=[[Vatican Information Service]] | date=9 July 2014 | accessdate=13 July 2014}}</ref> According to ValueWalk, ‚ÄúThe addition of Hintze is viewed as a significant positive for the Vatican‚Äù due to the fact that he is a ‚Äúno nonsense manager with deep insight into a broad range of international finance matters.‚Äù<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.valuewalk.com/2014/07/hintze-cqs-vatican/ |title=As Hintze Tapped For "Gods Work," CQS Funds Perform |work=ValueWalk |accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref>
In the UK, Hintze was also appointed to serve on the Fair and Effective Markets Review, a joint review by the [[HM Treasury|Treasury]], the [[Bank of England]] and the [[Financial Conduct Authority]] (FCA) focused on raising standards of conduct in the financial system.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/fair-and-effective-markets-review-announced-by-chancellor-of-the-exchequer |title=Fair and Effective Markets Review announced by Chancellor of the Exchequer |website=Gov.uk |accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref> He also sits on the Finance & Audit Committee of the Duchy of Cornwall.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://michael-hintze.com/bio/|website=www.michael-hintze.com|accessdate=9 January 2018}}</ref>
==Farming== In 2007, Hintze established MH Premium Farms (MHPF)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mhpremiumfarms.com/|website=MH Premium Farms|accessdate=27 July 2017}}</ref>, a group of agriculture companies based mainly in Australia. MHPF now owns more than 20 properties<ref>{{cite web|title=Properties|url=http://mhpremiumfarms.com/properties/#|website=MH Premium Farms|accessdate=27 July 2017}}</ref> in eastern Australia, covering a total area of more than 70,000 hectares. The properties offer a broad portfolio including: fat lambs, wool and cattle; broad acre cropping of cereals and oilseeds; irrigated cotton and sugar.
MHPF is managed by a team of agricultural specialists, led by CEO Richard Taylor<ref>{{cite web|title=Team: Richard Taylor|url=http://mhpremiumfarms.com/team-view/richard-taylor/|website=MH Premium Farms|accessdate=27 July 2017}}</ref>, who graduated from Sydney University with a 1st class honours degree in Veterinary Science in 1987 and has since managed a number of agricultural companies in Australia<ref>{{cite news|title=Prime Movers: Growth Farm founders Richard and Angus Taylor see positive future|url=http://www.weeklytimesnow.com.au/agribusiness/on-farm/prime-movers-growth-farm-founders-richard-and-angus-taylor-see-positive-future/news-story/68a9b90369170d4ae65e067fab2e2a5a|accessdate=27 July 2017|publisher=The Weekly Times}}</ref>.
The group maintains sustainable production practices and places an emphasis on environmental responsibility<ref>{{cite news|title=CQS chief plows his support into sustainable farm management|url=http://www.pionline.com/article/20170206/PRINT/302069988/cqs-chief-plows-his-support-into-sustainable-farm-management|accessdate=27 July 2017|publisher=Pensions & Investments}}</ref>.
As part of its corporate social responsibility (CSR) efforts, MHPF has also launched an undergraduate scholarship aimed at addressing the shortage of agronomists, and agriculture graduates more generally who may go on to service Australian agriculture<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.une.edu.au/alumni/give-to-une/scholarships|website=University of New England|accessdate=27 July 2017}}</ref>. Offered through the University of New England, the scholarship supports a full-time, on-campus student beginning their second year of either an Agriculture or Rural Science degree with an interest in pursuing a career as an agronomist in Australia following graduation and provides recipients with an 8-week work experience placement.
==Philanthropy== With his wife Dorothy, Hintze set up the Hintze Family Charitable Foundation, which has given significant and wide-ranging philanthropic support to over 200 causes, focusing mainly on health, education, armed services, culture, and the arts.<ref name=DMailBio/>
In the area of culture and the arts, notable donations include enabling the restoration of [[Michelangelo]]'s frescoes in the [[Cappella Paolina|Pauline Chapel]] at the [[Apostolic Palace|Vatican]] and in 2014 donating ¬£5 million to the [[Natural History Museum, London]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-27319973 |title=Natural History Museum receives ¬£5m donation |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=2016-06-30}}</ref> The donation to the Natural History Museum <ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-27319973 |title=BBC, 8 May 2014 "Natural History Museum receives ¬£5m donation" |accessdate=27 June 2014}}</ref> is the biggest single donation received by the museum in 133 years (in other words, since 1881 when the Museum opened to the public for the first time). The gift will be used in part to fund programmes to study problems that threaten Earth's biodiversity such as the maintenance of delicate ecosystems and the impacts of environmental pollution, as well as the battle against diseases such as malaria.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://media.nhm.ac.uk/Press-releases/The-Natural-History-Museum-receives-5-million-donation-13a.aspx |title=Natural History Museum, 8 May 2014 "The Natural History Museum receives ¬£5 million donation" |accessdate=27 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140627120826/http://media.nhm.ac.uk/Press-releases/The-Natural-History-Museum-receives-5-million-donation-13a.aspx |archivedate=27 June 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The museum's Central Hall has since been renamed 'Hintze Hall'.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/science/dinosaurs/10814292/Dippy-the-Natural-History-Museum-diplodocus-could-be-moved.html |title=Dippy the Natural History Museum diplodocus could be moved |website=Telegraph.co.uk |accessdate=2016-06-30}}</ref>
Projects in culture and the arts have also enabled the refurbishment of the V&A's Sculpture Galleries, named the Dorothy and Michael Hintze Galleries,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/page/s/sculpture-galleries/ |title=Victoria & Albert Museum Sculpture Galleries |accessdate=2017-06-19}}</ref> and have included sponsorship of an iconic exhibition of [[Raphael]]'s Tapestries from the [[Sistine Chapel]] at the [[V&A]], and a ¬£2 million donation to the [[National Gallery]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.philanthropyuk.org/news/2011-01-28/hintze-family-charitable-foundation-donates-¬£2m-national-gallery |title=Philanthropy UK, 28 January 2011 "Hintze Family Foundation donates ¬£2m to National Gallery" |accessdate=14 June 2012}}</ref> The donation to the National Gallery has been used in part to fund refurbishment, including the installation of new technology to reduce the gallery's running costs and carbon footprint.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2011/jan/20/michael-hintze-donation-national-gallery |title=The Guardian, 20 January 2011 "Hedge fund founder Michael Hintze donates ¬£2m to National Gallery" | location=London | first=Mark |last=Brown |date=20 January 2011}}</ref> Support has also been provided to the British Museum and the National Portrait Gallery. The Hintze Family Charitable Foundation is also listed as a Life Benefactor Donor to the [[Royal National Theatre|National Theatre]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationaltheatre.org.uk/51800/information-for-current-members/life-benefactor-donors.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=29 October 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120729004752/http://www.nationaltheatre.org.uk/51800/information-for-current-members/life-benefactor-donors.html |archivedate=29 July 2012 }}</ref> Through CQS and the Hintze Family Charitable Foundation he provided funding to create a 'theatre in the round' at the [[Old Vic]] in London, amongst other significant support. He also came to the aid of [[Wandsworth Museum]], which was facing imminent closure by offering a ¬£2 million rescue package.
In the area of health, he co-chaired Clapham's [[Trinity Hospice]] campaign for a new in-patient centre which has now been completed. Hintze gave a $1 million gift to the [[University of Sydney]]'s Charles Perkins Centre, which focuses on turning medical research into viable treatments.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sydney.edu.au/news/84.html?newsstoryid=11487 |title=Three major donations take University of Sydney $16 million closer to $600 million fundraising goal|website=Sydney.edu.au |date=2013-05-04 |accessdate=2016-06-30}}</ref> He has also provided support to the Evelina Children's Hospital.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Blackhurst|first1=Chris|title=Interview: Sir Michael Hintze, CQS Hedge Fund - charity is a way of life for accomplished money-maker who enjoys giving it away|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/business/markets/interview-sir-michael-hintze-cqs-hedge-fund-charity-is-a-way-of-life-for-accomplished-money-maker-9874855.html|accessdate=9 January 2018|agency=Evening Standard}}</ref>
His support for the armed services has included donations to The Royal Navy & Royal Marines Charity. Among other initiatives, this has included providing funding to support serving personnel and their families.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fundraising.co.uk/2013/12/18/sir-michael-hintze-donate-500000-navys-charity/#.WRq6jFPytE4 |title=Sir Michael Hintze to donate ¬£500,000 to the Navy‚Äôs charity |publisher=UK Fundraising|accessdate=2017-05-16}}</ref> He has also provided support to the Black Stork Charity to help construct one of the most advanced centres for rehabilitation of injured military personnel in the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thednrc.org.uk/whats-happening-on-now/we-are-fundraising/how-have-we-got-there.aspx|website=DNRC|accessdate=9 January 2018}}</ref>
In education, among major donations, he has established the chair of International Security at the University of Sydney<ref>{{cite web|title=CENTRE FOR INTERNATIONAL SECURITY STUDIES|url=http://sydney.edu.au/arts/ciss/|website=University of Sydney|accessdate=9 January 2018}}</ref> and supported the University of Oxford Centre for Astrophysical Surveys,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www2.physics.ox.ac.uk/research/astrophysics/oxford-centre-for-astrophysical-surveys |title=Oxford Centre for Astrophysical Surveys |accessdate=2017-06-19}}</ref> where the Annual Hintze Lecture has been established.
Funding was provided for the construction of a residential wing at St. John‚Äôs College at the University of Sydney, which was named the Hintze Building.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stjohnscollege.edu.au/history/ |title=History - St John's College |website=stjohnscollege.edu.au |accessdate=2017-05-16}}</ref> Hintze has also donated $1 million to the [[University of New South Wales]] (UNSW) for a new lecture theatre.<ref>{{cite web|author=Steve Offner |url=http://newsroom.unsw.edu.au/news/science-technology/sir-michael-hintzes-1-million-gift |title=Sir Michael Hintze's $1 million gift | UNSW Newsroom |website=Newsroom.unsw.edu.au |date=2013-09-13 |accessdate=2016-06-30}}</ref> The donation was made in honour of his father, Michael Hintze senior, who is also a UNSW alumnus. Gifts have also been made to Harvard University<ref>{{cite web|title=Donors and Their Gifts|url=https://alumni.harvard.edu/college/college-giving/gift-planning/donors-and-gifts?page=1|website=Harvard}}</ref> ($10m) and Princeton University, where a Professorship for the Arts has been established in his wife's maiden name (Dorothy Krauklis)<ref>{{cite web|title=Supporters|url=http://arts.princeton.edu/people/supporters/|website=Lewis Center for the Arts - Princeton|accessdate=27 July 2017}}</ref>.
''[[The Guardian]]'' reported that Hintze is a donor to the [[Global Warming Policy Foundation]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Readfearn|first=Graham|title=Michael Hintze revealed as funder of Lord Lawson's climate thinktank|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2012/mar/27/tory-donor-climate-sceptic-thinktank|accessdate=27 March 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=27 March 2012|location=London, UK}}</ref>
===Philanthropic Positions & Recognitions=== Hintze currently serves as a trustee of the [[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Portrait Gallery]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/prime-minister-appoints-sir-michael-hintze-bjorn-saven-sir-peter-stothard-and-rachel-wang-as-trustees-of-the-national-portrait-gallery |title=Prime Minister Appoints Sir Michael Hintze, Bj√∂rn Sav√©n, Sir Peter Stothard and Rachel Wang as Trustees of the National Portrait Gallery. |website=gov.uk |accessdate=3 April 2017}}</ref> the [[Institute of Economic Affairs]], the University of Sydney Trust, as a Member of the Harvard Business School Board of Dean‚Äôs Advisors‚Äô, and as Senior Vice Patron of the Royal Navy & Royal Marines Charity.<ref>{{cite web|title=SENIOR VICE PATRON - SIR MICHAEL HINTZE AM|url=https://www.rnrmc.org.uk/senior-vice-patron-sir-michael-hintze-am|website=Royal Navy & Royal Marines Charity|accessdate=9 January 2018}}</ref> He was formerly chairman of the [[The Prince's Foundation for Building Community|Prince's Foundation for Building Community]].
Hintze was formerly a trustee of the [[National Gallery]], where he assisted in securing Titian‚Äôs [[Diana and Actaeon (Titian)|''Diana and Actaeon'']] for the nation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/titian-diana-and-actaeon |title=Diana and Actaeon |website=nationalgallery.org.uk |accessdate=2017-05-16}}</ref> He was initially appointed to the National Gallery's Board of Trustees by then [[Labour Party UK|Labour Party]] Prime Minister [[Gordon Brown]] in 2008. He was later reappointed by Conservative Party Prime Minister [[David Cameron]].
In recognition of their charitable contributions in support of the arts, Michael Hintze and his wife Dorothy received the Prince of Wales Medal for Arts Philanthropy in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://artsandbusiness.org.uk/Central/volunteering/prince-of-wales-medal/michael_and_dorothy_hintze.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=21 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120801044751/http://www.artsandbusiness.org.uk/Central/volunteering/prince-of-wales-medal/michael_and_dorothy_hintze.aspx |archivedate=1 August 2012 }}</ref>
Hintze was invited to the Chancellor's Court of Benefactors<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.campaign.ox.ac.uk/donate/recognising-your-gift |title=University of Oxford. |website=campaign.ox.ac.uk |accessdate=2017-06-19}}</ref> for his support of the University of Oxford.
He was named to the 2017 Debrett‚Äôs 500 List, in recognition of his considerable philanthropic contributions in the UK.<ref>{{cite news|title=Debrett's 500 List: Philanthropists & Activists|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/0/debretts-500-list-philanthropists-activists/|accessdate=9 January 2018|publisher=Telegraph}}</ref> He was also named to the Evening Standard‚Äôs ‚ÄúProgress 1000‚Äù list of ‚ÄúLondon‚Äôs most influential people,‚Äù citing his philanthropic contributions and business success.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Progress 1000: London's most influential people 2017 - Capitalisers: Business|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/the1000/the-progress-1000-londons-most-influential-people-2017-capitalisers-business-a3655286.html|accessdate=9 January 2018|publisher=Evening Standard}}</ref>
===Conservative Party donations=== In 2006, at the time of the [[Cash for Peerages]] allegations concerning the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]], Hintze voluntarily revealed he was one of the previously anonymous patrons who had made loans to the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://iaindale.blogspot.com/2006/03/exclusive-loan-tory-chooses-this-blog.html |title=Iain Dale'S Diary: Exclusive: Loan Tory Chooses This Blog To Go Public |website=Iaindale.blogspot.com |date=2006-03-25 |accessdate=2016-06-30}}</ref> In 2011 his known loans and donations to the party totalled around ¬£4 million.<ref name=DMailBio/> In the five months to September 2011 he donated ¬£31,000, enough to grant him membership of the Conservative Treasurers' Group, the second highest rung on the party's donor's ladder, which allows its members access to senior Conservative figures through a series of lunches, receptions and campaign launches.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thebureauinvestigates.com/2011/10/17/george-osborne-gets-almost-twice-that-of-liam-fox-from-michael-hintze/|title=George Osborne gets almost twice that of Liam Fox from Michael Hintze|date=17 October 2011 |author1=Oldroyd, Rachel |author2=McClenaghan, Maeve|accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref>
When the Conservative Party were in opposition, Hintze disclosed that he had donated to [[George Osborne]], [[David Willetts]], [[Liam Fox]], [[Theresa May]], [[David Davis (British politician)|David Davis]], [[Adam Holloway]], and [[Boris Johnson]].<ref name=DMailBio/> In addition, CQS made non-cash donations to [[William Hague]], Liam Fox, and George Osborne.<ref name=DMailBio/> In May 2008, [[David Cameron]] declared a donation from Hintze to the Conservative Party that was used to pay for drinks receptions for Tory MPs and their partners.<ref>Stratton, Allegra. [https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2008/sep/29/partyfunding.toryconference "Short-sellers are revealed as substantial party donors"], ''The Guardian'', 28 September 2008. Accessed 12 July 2016.</ref> In March 2008, Hintze paid for a private jet to ferry Cameron and Osborne from Newcastle to [[Biggin Hill]] after the Conservative Party conference.<ref name=DMailBio/>
In October 2011, it was revealed that [[Adam Werritty]], a close friend and business associate of then [[Secretary of State for Defence]] Liam Fox, was provided with a free desk by Hintze at CQS's London base as part of his ¬£29,000 donation to Fox's charity ''[[The Atlantic Bridge]]''.<ref name=Telg8821348>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/conservative/8821348/Michael-Hintze-the-millionaire-Tory-donor-who-once-said-the-more-you-give-the-more-you-get.html|title=Michael Hintze: the millionaire Tory donor who once said: the more you give, the more you get|publisher=The Telegraph|date=18 October 2011|accessdate=18 October 2011|location=London|first=Tim|last=Ross}}</ref><ref name="Mirror">{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/top-stories/2011/10/09/liam-fox-on-the-run-in-storm-over-ex-flatmate-adviser-115875-23476094/ |title=Liam Fox on the run in storm over ex-flatmate 'adviser'|publisher=Mirror |date=9 October 2011 |accessdate=11 October 2011}}</ref> Hintze also supplied a private jet for Fox and Werritty to fly from the United States to London in May 2011.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/conservative/8821209/Liam-Foxs-friend-Adam-Werritty-linked-to-Conservative-donor.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Holly | last=Watt | title=Liam Fox's friend Adam Werritty linked to Conservative donor | date=11 October 2011}}</ref> These disclosures led to the resignation of Liam Fox (who was then [[Secretary of State for Defence]]) and the dismissal of Hintze's then-charity adviser, Oliver Hylton.<ref name=Readfearn2012>{{cite news|last1=Readfearn|first1=Graham|title=Michael Hintze revealed as funder of Lord Lawson's climate thinktank|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2012/mar/27/tory-donor-climate-sceptic-thinktank|accessdate=8 June 2014|work=The Guardian|date=27 March 2012}}</ref>
==Honours== He was made a [[Order of St. Gregory|Knight Commander of the Papal Order of St. Gregory]] (KCSG) by [[Pope Benedict XVI]] in 2005<ref>{{cite web|url=http://advance.org/michael-hintze/ |title=Sir Michael Hintze AM |website=Advance.org |date= |accessdate=2016-06-30}}</ref> and was later was elevated to a Knight Grand Cross of the same Order (GCSG).
In January 2013, Hintze was appointed [[Order of Australia|Member of the Order of Australia]] (AM) for his "significant service to the community through philanthropic contributions to organisations supporting the arts, health and education."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/australia-day-honours-list/story-e6frg6n6-1226562330797|title=Australia Day Honours List 2013|work=The Australian|date=26 January 2013}}</ref>
He was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] in the United Kingdom's [[2013 Birthday Honours]] for services to the arts.<ref name=gaz31712>{{London Gazette|issue=60534|supp=y|page=1|date=15 June 2013}}</ref><ref name="HM Birthday Honours 2013">{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/206698/Birthday_Honours_List_2013.pdf|title=Birthday Honours List 2013|accessdate=14 June 2013|date=14 June 2013|format=PDF|publisher=HM Government}}</ref> He received his accolade on 23 October 2013 by [[Charles, Prince of Wales|The Prince of Wales]] at Buckingham Palace.
==Personal life== Married to American citizen Dorothy, whom he met at Harvard,<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/15/style/dorothy-e-krauklis-is-married-to-michael-hintze.html "Dorothy E. Krauklis Is Married to Michael Hintze"], ''The New York Times'', 15 July 1984. Accessed 12 July 2016.</ref> the couple have four children, partially educated at British private schools.<ref name=DMailBio>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2050331/Michael-Hintze-Hedge-fund-baron-David-Camerons-sugar-daddy.html#ixzz1b88dXKaA|title=Hedge fund baron Hintze ‚Äì sugar daddy to Cameron and Co|author1=Gladdis, Keith |author2=Martin, Arthur |author3=Pendlebury, Richard|work=[[Daily Mail]]|date=18 October 2011|accessdate=18 October 2011|location=London}}</ref> Hintze is a [[Roman Catholic]].<ref name=RC>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2568073/SEBASTIAN-SHAKESPEARE-Billionaire-Tory-donor-pulls-plug-Cameron.html|title=Billionaire Tory donor pulls plug on Cameron|work=[[Daily Mail]]|accessdate=26 February 2014|location=London|first=Sebastian|last=Shakespeare|date=26 February 2014}}</ref>

{{italic title}} [[Image:Neue Rheinische Zeitung N.jpg|thumb|right|300 px|The 19 June 1848 edition of ''Neue Rheinische Zeitung.'']] The '''''Neue Rheinische Zeitung: Organ der Demokratie''''' ("New Rhenish Newspaper: Organ of Democracy") was a [[Germany|German]] daily [[newspaper]], published by [[Karl Marx]] in [[Cologne]] between 1 June 1848 and 19 May 1849. It is recognised by historians as one of the most important dailies of the [[Revolutions of 1848 in the German states|Revolutions of 1848 in Germany]]. The paper was regarded by its editors and readers as the successor of an earlier Cologne newspaper, the ''[[Rheinische Zeitung]]'' ("Rhenish Newspaper"), also edited for a time by Karl Marx, which had been [[freedom of the press|suppressed]] by [[political censorship|state censorship]] over five years earlier. == Publication history == ===Establishment=== The ''Neue Rheinische Zeitung: Organ der Demokratie'' ("New Rhenish Newspaper: Organ of Democracy") was founded 1 June 1848 in Cologne (K√∂ln), part of [[Rhineland]]. The paper was established by Karl Marx, [[Frederick Engels]], as well as leading members of the [[Communist League]] living in Cologne immediately upon the return of Marx and Engels to Germany following the outbreak of the 1848 Revolution.Hal Draper, "Neue Rheinische Zeitung: Organ der Demokratie," in ''The Marx-Engels Glossary: Glossary to the Chronicle and Register, and Index to the Glossary: Volume 3 of the Marx-Engels Cyclopedia.'' New York: Schocken Books, 1986; pp. 150-151. The paper's editorial staff included [[Joseph Weydemeyer]], with Marx serving as editor-in-chief. The paper was named after an earlier newspaper edited by Karl Marx in Cologne from 1842 to 1843, the ''Rheinische Zeitung.'' The paper had the subtitle "Organ of Democracy," referring not to the establishment of [[liberal democracy|parliamentary]] democracy, but to the revolutionary "Democratic front" which included the progressive [[petty bourgeoisie]], the [[working class]], and the [[peasantry]]. The paper was financed through the sale of shares of stock, contributions and loans, and paid advertising. The paper was produced as a 4-page [[broadsheet]], with the use of occasional special supplements. ===Development=== Circulation of the paper ranged from 3,000 to 6,000 copies per issue,James G. Chastain, [http://www.ohio.edu/chastain/ip/nrz.htm "Neue Rheinische Zeitung,"] ''Encyclopedia of 1848 Revolutions,'' www.ohio.edu/ a number far in excess of the membership of the Communist League itself, which specialists estimate had between 200 and 300 participants.Tatyana Vasilyeva, "Preface" to Karl Marx and Frederick Engels, ''Collected Works: Volume 7: Marx and Engels, 1848.'' New York: International Publishers, 1977; pg. xviii. This effectively rendered the publication into what historian Tatyana Vasilyeva has called "the leading centre of the Communist League, directing the political activity of its members throughout Germany during the revolutionary period."Vasilyeva, "Preface" to ''Marx-Engels Collected Works: Vol. 7,'' pg. xix. A total of 301 editions of the ''Neue Rheinische Zeitung'' (NRZ) were produced during the course of its existence. To these Marx himself contributed a total of not fewer than 80 articles over the course of its existence.David McLellan, ''The Thought of Karl Marx: An Introduction.'' New York: Harper and Row, 1971; pg. 42. Since editorial contributions to the NRZ were unsigned and handwritten manuscripts have not survived, a precise count is impossible, however.Vasilyeva, "Preface" to ''Marx-Engels Collected Works: Vol. 7,'' pp. xxxii-xxxiii. ===Political line=== The ''Neue Rheinische Zeitung'' (NRZ) was outspoken in its criticism of [[Prussia]] and [[Austria]] for [[Monarchism|Monarchist]] counter-revolution, and actively agitated for their defeat. The paper was also critical of the willingness of the [[liberalism|liberal]] [[bourgeoisie]] to compromise with Monarchist forces ‚Äî policies which Marx and his comrades believed would have negative impacts upon the German revolution. More than three decades after the publication's termination, Marx's close associate [[Frederick Engels]] recalled that the NRZ had a political program with two main points: "a single, indivisible, democratic German republic, and War with [[Russian empire|Russia]], including the restoration of [[Poland]]."Frederick Engels, "Marx and the ''Neue Rheinische Zeitung'' (1848-49)," ''Der Sozialdemokrat,'' No. 11 (March 13, 1884), reprinted in ''Marx-Engels Collected Works: Volume 26: Frederick Engels, 1882-89.'' New York: International Publishers, 1990; pp. 123-124. With respect to foreign affairs, Engels recalled that the NRZ sought "to support every revolutionary people and to call for a general war of revolutionary Europe against the mighty bulwark of European reaction ‚Äî Russia."Engels, "Marx and the ''Neue Rheinische Zeitung'' (1848-49)," pg. 126. This policy was intended to undermine both the authority of Prussia and Tsarist Russia, both considered reactionary and militaristic powers, with war against Russia seen as a necessary prerequisite for establishment of a unified and democratic Germany.Engels, "Marx and the ''Neue Rheinische Zeitung'' (1848-49)," pg. 124. Marx and Engels believed that "if Germany could be successfully brought to make war against Russia, it would be the end for the [[Hapsburg dynasty|Habsburgs]] and [[Hohenzollern dynasty|Hohenzollerns]] and the revolution would triumph along the whole line."Engels, "Marx and the ''Neue Rheinische Zeitung'' (1848-49)," pg. 127. The tone of the newspaper was described by Engels as "by no means solemn, serious, or enthusiastic," instead treating political opponents with "mockery and derision" in a manner entertaining to readers. The paper sought to foster the idea that the German events of the spring of 1848 were the starting point of a long revolutionary process akin to the [[French Revolution]] of 1789-1794.Engels, "Marx and the ''Neue Rheinische Zeitung'' (1848-49)," pg. 125. The paper attempted to undermine the notion that the formal resolutions of various "National Assemblies" were capable of changing state policy in any fundamental way. Throughout its existence the NRZ was persecuted by the Prussian government, which brought lawsuits against it charging the NRZ with having "slandered" government officials. As the revolutionary upsurge of 1848 ebbed, the government's hindrance of the publication became steadily more effective, culminating in Karl Marx's expulsion from Germany ‚Äî a move which effectively killed the paper. ===Suppression=== On 2 March 1849, Prussian soldiers came to Marx's home to arrest one of the writers. Marx refused to turn over the writer, and the soldiers eventually left. On 16 May 1849 Marx received an official note from the royal government declaring:
"The tendency of the ''Neue Rheinische Zeitung'' to provoke in its readers contempt for the present government, and incite them to violent revolution and the setting up of a social republic has become stronger in its latest pieces.... The right of hospitality which he has so disgracefully abused is therefore to be withdrawn from its editor-in-chief, Dr. Karl Marx, and since he has not obtained permission to prolong his stay in these states, he is ordered to leave them within 24 hours. If he should not comply voluntarily with this demand, he is to be forcibly conveyed across the frontier."First published in ''Neue Rheinische Zeitung,'' No. 301, 19 May 1849. Reprinted as "The Summary Suppression of the ''Neue Rheinische Zeitung,"'' ''Marx-Engels Collected Works: Volume 9.'' New York: International Publishers, 1977; pg. 451.
This expulsion order, combined with the growing threat of arrest or exile of its writers forced the NRZ to publish its last issue on 19 May 1849, known as the "red issue" as it was printed entirely in red ink. Marx closed with a sharp rebuttal against the suppression of the NRZ:
"Why these absurd phrases, these official lies? The trend and tone of the latest pieces of the ''Neue Rheinische Zeitung'' do not differ a whit from its first 'sample piece.' * * *

"And the 'social republic'? Have we proclaimed it only in the 'latest pieces' of the ''Neue Rheinische Zeitung?'' Did we not speak plainly and clearly enough for these dullards who failed to see the 'red' thread running through all our comments and reports on the European movement? * * *

"We have no compassion and we ask no compassion from you. When our turn comes, we shall not make excuses for the terror. But the royal terrorists, the terrorists by the grace of God and the law, are in practice brutal, disdainful, and mean, in theory cowardly, secretive, and deceitful, and in both respects disreputable."Karl Marx, "The Summary Suppression of the ''Neue Rheinische Zeitung,"'' ''Marx-Engels Collected Works: Volume 9.'' New York: International Publishers, 1977; pp. 451-453.
===Legacy=== In January 1850 Marx launched a new publication, a monthly magazine called ''[[Neue Rheinische Zeitung: Politsch-√∂konomische Revue]]'' ("New Rhenish Newspaper: Politico-Economic Review"). Edited in [[London]] and printed in [[Hamburg]], the periodical managed only six issues before folding.Hal Draper, "Neue Rheinische Zeitung: Politsch-√∂konomische Revue," in ''The Marx-Engels Glossary: Glossary to the Chronicle and Register, and Index to the Glossary.'' New York: Schocken Books, 1986; pg. 151. The best-known content of the NRZ were a series of five articles on economics published by Marx in April 1849 ‚Äî a series unfinished due to the suppression of the paper.Hal Draper, ''The Marx-Engels Register: A Complete Bibliography of Marx and Engels' Individual Writings: Volume 2 of the Marx-Engels Cyclopedia.'' New York: Schocken Books, 1985; pg. 91. First gathered under a single set of covers under the title ''[[Wage Labour and Capital|Wage-labor and Capital]]'' in 1880, this material was subsequently revised by Engels in 1891 and frequently reprinted thereafter as an accessible popularization of [[Marxist economics]]. The great bulk of the journalism of Karl Marx and Frederick Engels in the NRZ became systematically accessible to an English readership only in 1977, with the publication of volumes 7, 8, and 9 of the ''[[Marx-Engels Collected Works]].'' It was then that a total of 357 of the 422 articles contained therein were published in English for the first time.For individual counts of first English publications see: Vasilyeva, "Preface" to ''Marx-Engels Collected Works: Vol. 7,'' pg. xxxii. Vladimir Sazonov, "Preface" to Karl Marx and Frederick Engels, ''Collected Works: Volume 8: Marx and Engels, 1848-1849.'' New York: International Publishers, 1977; pg. xxix. Velta Pospelova, "Preface" to Karl Marx and Frederick Engels, ''Collected Works: Volume 9: Marx and Engels, 1849.'' New York: International Publishers, 1977; pg. xxxii. In 2005 an online newspaper calling itself ''Neue Rheinische Zeitung'' was established.[http://www.nrhz.de/ Neue Rheinische Zeitung (2005) website.] == See also == * [[Manifesto of the Communist Party]] ==Footnotes== {{reflist|2}} ==Editorial Board== '''Source:''' "Statement of the Editorial Board of the ''Neue Rheinische Zeitung,"'' no. 1, June 1, 1848. {{Orphan|date=October 2015}}
[[File:Don't Shred On Me.png|thumb|Don't Shred On Me Logo created by Pat Ramseur for the Open Carry Guitar Rally held July 4, 2014 in Dallas, Texas]]
'''Open Carry Guitar Rally''' is a concept created by Barry Kooda in response to the [[Open Carry]] gun movement. During an Open Carry Guitar Rally, citizens congregate in a public place while displaying their instruments, a parody of similar gatherings held by [[Gun politics in the United States|gun rights]] activists.
==Background== The event originated in [[Dallas, Texas]], where it received the support of the local Dallas art and music communities. Kooda is a member of the Dallas-based [[punk rock]] band [[The Nervebreakers]]. Since then, these rallies have occurred in several cities across the United States. These events are attended by people with varying degrees of opinions concerning gun rights and legislation; while some attendees express anti-gun sentiment, others view the gatherings simply as an opportunity to enjoy the camaraderie of fellow guitar enthusiasts.
The Open Carry Guitar Rally was organized using the [[open source]] concept. The idea, and all artwork and images are free for use for others to use to organize their own open carry guitar rallies, provided proper credit is given to the artists and contributors.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Open Carry Guitar Rally |title=Info |url=http://opencarryguitarrally.com/info/ |accessdate=October 20, 2014}}</ref>
==Events== ===Dallas, Texas=== [[File:Opencarryguitarrally.jpg|thumb|The first annual Open Carry Guitar Rally, July 4, 2014 in Dallas, Texas.]] The original Open Carry Guitar Rally occurred on July 4, 2014, at the Continental Avenue Bridge Park in [[Dallas, Texas]]. This event was conceived and coordinated by Barry Kooda, co-coordinated by Kyle Reynolds, and promoted by graphic designer Pat Ramseur with event coordination assistance from Mike Schwedler and Reid Robinson. Over 1,000 people RSVP'ed on the group's Facebook page.<ref>{{cite news |first=Lyndsay |last=Knecht |publisher=[[KERA-FM]] |location=[[Dallas, TX]] |title=In West Dallas, A New Open Carry Movement: Guitars, Not Guns |url=http://keranews.org/post/west-dallas-new-open-carry-movement-guitars-not-guns |date=July 7, 2014 |accessdate=October 21, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Teresa |last=Gubbins |work=Culture Map Dallas |location=[[Dallas, TX]] |title=Dallas musicians tweak Open Carry gun group with sly parody protest |url=http://dallas.culturemap.com/news/city-life/07-05-14-guitar-open-carry-event/ |date=July 5, 2014 |accessdate=October 21, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=David |last=Moye |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |title=DON'T SHRED ON ME! Join The Open-Carry Guitar Rally |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/06/24/open-carry-guitar-rally_n_5525712.html |date=June 24, 2014 |accessdate=October 21, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |work=Sensible Humanity |title=Open Carry a Tune: What We Can Learn from the Open Carry Guitar Movement |url=http://sensiblehumanity.com/open-carry-tune-can-learn-open-carry-guitar-movement/ |date=June 22, 2014 |accessdate=October 21, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Danny |last=Gallagher |newspaper=[[Dallas Observer]] |location=[[Dallas, TX]] |title=Open Carry Guitar Rally at Trinity River Walking Bridge, 7/4/14 |url=http://blogs.dallasobserver.com/dc9/2014/07/open_carry_guitar_rally_july_fourth.php |date=July 7, 2014 |accessdate=October 21, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Robert |last=Wilonsky |authorlink=Robert Wilonsky |newspaper=[[The Dallas Morning News]] |location=[[Dallas, TX]] |title=At Dallas‚Äô first Open Carry Guitar Rally over the Trinity River, plenty of jams but no loaded weapons |url=http://thescoopblog.dallasnews.com/2014/07/at-dallas-first-open-carry-guitar-rally-over-the-trinity-river-plenty-of-jams-but-no-loaded-weapons.html/ |date=July 5, 2014 |accessdate=October 21, 2014}}</ref>
The event was continued in 2015, 2016, and 2017 as well.
===Cleveland, Ohio=== Inspired by the Dallas event, an open carry guitar rally was held on July 13, 2014, in [[Public Square, Cleveland|Public Square]] in [[Cleveland, Ohio]]. This event was co-organized by Daniel McGraw and Ariel Clayton.<ref>{{cite news |first=Cory |last=Shaffer |newspaper=[[Cleveland Plain Dealer]] |location=[[Cleveland, OH]] |title=Group plans to meet gun-rights protestors with musical instruments on Public Square |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2014/07/group_plans_to_meet_gun-rights.html |date=July 9, 2014 |accessdate=October 20, 2014}}</ref>
===Fresno, California=== On August 30, 2014, a group gathered at [[KWDO|KJWL]] ("Jewel FM") radio station and exercised their right to bear guitars through the streets of downtown [[Fresno, California]].<ref>{{cite web |work=Downtown Fresno |publisher=Downtown Fresno Partnership |location=[[Fresno, CA]] |title=Fresno Open Carry Guitar Day |url=http://downtownfresnoblog.com/2014/08/30/fresno-open-carry-guitar-day/ |date=August 30, 2014 |accessdate=October 20, 2014}}</ref>
===Austin, Texas=== On August 30, 2014, a group assembled at the [[Texas State Capitol]] building in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]] in another iteration of the Open Carry Guitar Rally. This event was organized by Scott Carlin and attended by Dallas coordinators Barry Kooda and Kyle Reynolds.<ref>{{cite news |first=Laura |last=Skelding |newspaper=[[Austin American-Statesman]] |location=[[Austin, TX]] |title=Austin Open Carry guitar, 08.30.14 |url=http://www.statesman.com/gallery/news/local/austin-open-carry-guitar-083014/gCM6C/ |date=August 30, 2014 |accessdate=October 20, 2014}}</ref>
===Medford, Oregon=== The rally took place on October 5, 2014, at Vogel Plaza in downtown [[Medford, Oregon]]. The rally was organized by Roger Lemstrom.
===Bend, Oregon=== The "happening" was on June 30, 2014, at the corner of Wall Street and Franklin Avenue in [[Bend, Oregon]], and was organized by William L. Valenti.

[[File:Trauretten Bauern.jpg|thumb|Memorial to the fallen peasants in Nu√üdorf]]
The '''Palatine Peasants' War''' ({{lang-de|pf√§lzische Bauernkrieg}}) was part of the general [[German Peasants' War]] on the Middle and Upper [[Rhine]]. The uprising in the [[Electoral Palatinate|Palatine Electorate]] and its surrounding area took place in April to June 1525.
== History == The start of the German Peasants' War in West Rhenish Palatinate was marked by the gathering of a band of peasants, a so-called ''Haufe'', at [[Nu√üdorf (Landau)|Nu√üdorf]] near [[Landau in der Pfalz|Landau]] on 23 April 1525. The Palatine peasant mobs plundered several surrounding monasteries (including the [[Knights Hospitaller]] [[commandry]] of [[Heimbach]] near [[Zeiskam]] as well as [[H√∂rdt]], where the provost was killed) and castles, before they took [[Neustadt an der Weinstra√üe|Neustadt]] on 6 May without a fight. The peasants' programme was based on the [[Twelve Articles]], which were drawn up at [[Memmingen]] and of which 25,000 copies were printed. A second ''Haufe'' gathered near [[Bockenheim an der Weinstra√üe|Bockenheim]]. As a result, the Palatine [[prince-elector]], [[Louis V of the Palatinate|Louis V]] felt forced into negotiations with the Geilweiler and Bockenheim groups; these began on 10 May in [[Forst an der Weinstra√üe|Forst]]. The complaints were to be handled by a ''[[Landtag (historic)|Landtag]]''. The Elector finally resorted to military force against the peasants on 23 May with the support of troops from the Archbishop of [[Trier]], after other princes had defeated the uprisings in W√ºrttemberg and in the Alsace. The Palatine peasants mobs were crushingly defeated at the [[Battle of Pfeddersheim]] on 23/24 June. Eight thousand peasants were reported to have been killed in the battle.
== Literature == {{no footnotes|date=October 2014}} * Miller, Douglas (2003). ''Armies of the German Peasants' War 1524-26'', Oxford: Osprey, {{ISBN|1-84176-507-4}}. * Buzello, Horst et al. (ed.): ''Der deutsche Bauernkrieg.'' Sch√∂ningh, Paderborn etc., 1984, {{ISBN|3-506-99350-X}}, pp. 90ff. (''Uni-Taschenb√ºcher - Geschichte'' 1275)

{{About|the historical Australian party|current parliamentary groupings in the UK and Ireland|Parliamentary Labour Party|and|Parliamentary Labour Party (Ireland)}}
The '''Parliamentary Labor Party''' (also known as the '''Premiers' Plan Labor Party''' or '''Ministerial Labor Party''') was a [[political party]] active in [[South Australia]] from August 1931 until June 1934.
The party came into existence as a result of intense dispute, especially within the [[Australian Labor Party (South Australian Branch)|Australian Labor Party]], about the handling of the response to the [[Great Depression in Australia]]. In June 1931, a meeting of state premiers agreed on the [[Premiers' Plan]], which involved sweeping austerity measures combined with increases in revenue. When the Premiers' Plan came up for a vote in South Australia, 23 of Labor's 30 [[South Australian House of Assembly|House of Assembly]] members and two of Labor's four [[South Australian Legislative Council|Legislative Council]] members voted for it. In August 1931, the South Australian state conference of the Labor Party expelled all of the MPs who supported the Premiers' Plan, including Premier [[Lionel Hill]] and his entire Cabinet.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article35678760 |title=Labor Party Expels Five M.P.'s |newspaper=[[Advertiser and Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=14 August 1931 |accessdate=26 December 2014 |page=21 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article133068424 |title=WHERE PREMIER WILL STAND. |newspaper=[[The News (Adelaide)|The News]] |location=Adelaide |date=6 January 1933 |accessdate=5 June 2015 |page=1 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
Expelled MPs (23) in the [[South Australian House of Assembly|House of Assembly]]: *[[Frederick Birrell]] *[[Alfred Blackwell]] *[[Thomas Butterfield]] *[[Clement Collins]] *[[George Cooke (Australian politician)|George Cooke]] *[[Jack Critchley]] *[[Bill Denny (Australian politician)|Bill Denny]] *[[Thomas Edwards (Australian politician)|Thomas Edwards]] *[[Even George]] *[[William Harvey (1882‚Äì1954)|William Harvey]] *[[Lionel Hill]] *[[Leonard Hopkins]] *[[Robert Hunter (Australian politician)|Robert Hunter]] *[[Beasley Kearney]] *[[Arthur McArthur (politician)|Arthur McArthur]] *[[Sydney McHugh]] *[[John McInnes (politician)|John McInnes]] *[[John Pedler]] *[[Robert Richards (Australian politician)|Robert Richards]] *[[Eric Shepherd]] *[[Frank Staniford]] *[[Albert Thompson (Australian politician)|Albert Thompson]] *[[Walter Warne]]
Expelled MPs (2) in the [[Legislative Council]]: *[[James Jelley]] *[[Stanley Whitford]]
Upon the failure of a November appeal to the federal executive of the Labor Party, the expelled MPs definitively constituted themselves as a separate parliamentary party.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article90638215 |title=New State Labor Party? |newspaper=[[The Chronicle (Adelaide)|The Chronicle]] |location=Adelaide |date=26 November 1931 |accessdate=26 December 2014 |page=41 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
Having soundly lost its majority, the PLP ministry stayed in office until the [[South Australian state election, 1933|1933 election]] with the support of the conservative opposition--the [[Liberal Federation]] to 1932 and the [[Liberal and Country League]] afterward. Hill, facing increasing political challenges, had himself appointed Agent-General in London and abruptly quit politics in February 1932. [[Robert Richards (Australian politician)|Robert Richards]] briefly succeeded him as Premier, and led the party into the 1933 election.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/hill-lionel-laughton-6671 | title=Hill, Lionel Naughton (1881‚Äì1963) | publisher=Australian Dictionary of Biography | accessdate=26 December 2014}}</ref>
The party, along with the official Labor Party and the rival splinter [[Lang Labor Party (South Australia)|Lang Labor Party]], performed poorly at the 1933 election. Of the 23 MPs the party had going into the election, only five ‚Äì Blackwell, McInnes, Pedler, and Richards in the House of Assembly, and Whitford in the Legislative Council, were reelected. The three Labor factions won only 13 seats between them, against 29 for the LCL.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article37700501 |title=Labour Defeated. South Austrian Poll. |newspaper=[[Western Mail (Western Australia)|Western Mail]]|location=Perth |date=13 April 1933 |accessdate=26 December 2014 |page=19 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article32460490 |title=S.A. Elections |newspaper=[[The West Australian]]|location=Perth |date=12 April 1933 |accessdate=26 December 2014 |page=16 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article135546161 |title=S.A. UPPER HOUSE. |newspaper=[[Newcastle Morning Herald and Miners' Advocate]] |date=14 April 1933 |accessdate=26 December 2014 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
Two of the three Lang Labor Party MHAs elected at the [[South Australian state election, 1933|1933 state election]], [[Bob Dale (politician)|Bob Dale]] and [[Tom Howard (politician)|Tom Howard]], left the party in 1933 post-election after falling out with leader [[Doug Bardolph]] and formed their own party, the [[Lang Labor Party (South Australia)#South Australian Lang Labor Party (SALLP)|South Australian Lang Labor Party]] (SALLP).
The four Labor parties merged back into the official Labor Party in June 1934 under the leadership of [[Andrew Lacey]] of the official Labor faction, following a successful unity conference.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article58850868 |title=Reunion in Ranks of Labor |newspaper=[[The Mail (Adelaide)|The Mail]] |location=Adelaide |date=23 June 1934 |accessdate=26 December 2014 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Whitford, the party's sole upper house member, had left the party to sit as an independent by the time of the conference, and was not re-admitted.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article128435135 |title=Last Minute News. |newspaper=[[The News (Adelaide)|The News]] |location=Adelaide |date=15 June 1934 |accessdate=26 December 2014 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Australian Labor Party (South Australian Branch)]] *[[Members of the South Australian House of Assembly, 1930‚Äì1933]] *[[Members of the South Australian Legislative Council, 1930‚Äì1933]] *[[Richards Ministry]]
