2014‚Äìpresent{{cite news |author= |title=Mahdi Army military parade in Iraq |url=http://rt.com/in-motion/167516-iraq-parade-army-mahdi/ |newspaper=RT |location= |publisher= |date=June 21, 2014 |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171010060117/https://www.rt.com/in-motion/167516-iraq-parade-army-mahdi/ |archive-date=October 10, 2017 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} |leaders=[[Muqtada al-Sadr]] |clans= |headquarters=[[Najaf]], [[Kufa]], [[Sadr city]] |area=Iraq, [[Syria]]{{cite web|url=http://reuters.com/article/idUSBRE9390OB20130410?irpc=932|title=Iraqi Shi'ite militants start to acknowledge role in Syria|work=Reuters|accessdate=10 April 2015}} |strength=10,000‚Äì50,000 (2014, independent claims){{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/story/20146216504615669|title=Iraqi Shia groups rally in show of power - Al Jazeera English|publisher=|accessdate=21 January 2015}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iraq/10916360/Iraq-crisis-Isis-seize-Syria-border-crossing-as-Obama-blames-Iraqi-government-for-sectarian-divisions-latest.html|title=Iraq crisis: Isis allies 'turn on jihadists' as 17 killed in clashes near Kirkuk|date=21 June 2014|work=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=21 January 2015}} |status=depleted (2008 U.S. intelligence, current strength very low) |partof={{flagicon image|}} [[Popular Mobilization Forces]] |previous= |next= |religious ideology=[[Shia Islam]] |allies= {{flag|Syria|size=23px}} |opponents={{flag|Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|size=23px}}
{{flagicon image|Flag of Jihad.svg|size=23px}} [[Iraqi insurgency (Iraq War)#Sunni Islamist|Sunni Insurgents]] |battles= '''[[Iraq War]]''' *[[Siege of Sadr City]] *[[Battle of Al Kut]] *[[Battle of Najaf (2004)]] *[[Battle of Diwaniya]] *[[Battle of Amarah]] *[[Battle of Karbala (2007)]] *[[Siege of U.K. bases in Basra]] *[[Battle of Basra (2008)]] *[[Iraq spring fighting of 2008]] '''[[Iraqi Civil War (2014‚Äìpresent)]]''' *[[Second Battle of Tikrit (2014‚Äì15)|Second Battle of Tikrit]]{{cite web|url=http://observers.france24.com/content/20150311-video-shiite-militias-sunni-village-tikrit|title=Video shows burning village near Tikrit : "Shiite militias wanted revenge"|work=The Observers|accessdate=10 April 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/13/us-mideast-iraq-idUSKBN0M91DR20150313|title=Iraqi forces pause in battle to drive Islamic State from Tikrit|work=Reuters|accessdate=10 April 2015}} |Members killed=|active2=}} The '''Peace Companies''' ({{lang-ar|ÿ≥ÿ±ÿßŸäÿß ÿßŸÑÿ≥ŸÑÿßŸÖ}}, [[transliteration of Arabic|translit.]] ''SarƒÅyƒÅ al-SalƒÅm''), frequently mistranslated as '''Peace Brigades''' in US media, are an [[Iraq]]i armed group linked to Iraq's [[Shia]] community. They are a 2014 revival of the '''Mahdi Army''' (''JAM''; {{lang|ar|ÿ¨Ÿäÿ¥ ÿßŸÑŸÖŸáÿØŸä}} ''Jaish al-Mahdƒ´''){{cite web|url=http://web.stanford.edu/group/mappingmilitants/cgi-bin/groups/view/57|title=Mahdi Army|author=Daniel Cassman|publisher=|accessdate=10 April 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/shia-peace-brigades-killed-30-isis-militants-says-aqili/|title=Shia paramilitary 'Peace Brigades' kill 30 ISIS fighters says Akili - Iraqi News|work=Iraq news, the latest Iraq news|accessdate=10 April 2015}} that was created by the Iraqi Shia cleric [[Muqtada al-Sadr]] in June 2003 and disbanded in 2008. The Mahdi Army rose to international prominence on April 18, 2004, when it spearheaded the first major armed confrontation against the [[History of Iraq (2003‚Äì2011)|US forces in Iraq]] from the Shia community. This concerned an uprising that followed the ban of al-Sadr's newspaper and his subsequent attempted arrest, lasting until a truce on June 6. The truce was followed by moves to disband the group and transform al-Sadr's movement into a political party to take part in the 2005 elections; Muqtada al-Sadr ordered fighters of the Mahdi army to cease fire unless attacked first. The truce broke down in August 2004 after provocative actions by the Mahdi Army, with new hostilities erupting. The group was disbanded in 2008, following a crackdown by Iraqi security forces. At its height, the Mahdi Army's popularity was strong enough to influence local government, the police, and cooperation with Sunni Iraqis and their supporters. The group was popular among Iraqi police forces. The [[National Independent Cadres and Elites]] party that ran in the [[Iraqi legislative election, January 2005|2005 Iraqi election]] was closely linked with the army. Members of the Mahdi Army frequently carried out atrocities, particularly against Sunni civilians. The Mahdi Army were accused of operating [[death squads]].{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/iraqs-death-squads-on-the-brink-of-civil-war-467784.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080430151426/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/iraqs-death-squads-on-the-brink-of-civil-war-467784.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=30 April 2008|title=Iraq's death squads: On the brink of civil war|work=The Independent|accessdate=10 April 2015|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.jamestown.org/terrorism/news/article.php?articleid=2370161|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061016185308/http://jamestown.org/terrorism/news/article.php?articleid=2370161|dead-url=yes|archive-date=16 October 2006|title=Terrorism Monitor - The Jamestown Foundation|publisher=|accessdate=10 April 2015}} The group was armed with various [[light weapons]], including [[improvised explosive devices]] (IEDs). Many of the IEDs used during attacks on Iraqi Security Forces and Coalition Forces used infra-red sensors as triggers, a technique that was used widely by the [[Provisional IRA|IRA]] in [[Northern Ireland]] in the early-to-mid-1990s.{{cite news | url=http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/ulster/article320004.ece | work=The Independent | location=London | title=Revealed: IRA bombs killed eight British soldiers in Iraq | first1=Greg | last1=Harkin | first2=Francis | last2=Elliott | first3=Raymond | last3=Whitaker | date=October 16, 2005 | accessdate=May 12, 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080709005403/http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/ulster/article320004.ece | archivedate=July 9, 2008 | df= }} The group was re-mobilized in 2014 in order to fight against the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] and was still active as of 2016. It participated in the recapture of [[Jurf Al Nasr]] and the [[Second Battle of Tikrit (March‚ÄìApril 2015)|Second Battle of Tikrit]]. ==Nomenclature == In the [[Twelver]] school of [[Shia Islam]], the Mahdƒ´ is believed to have been a historical figure identified with the [[Imam|Twelfth ImƒÅm]], [[Muhammad al-Mahdi|Muhammad al-Mahdƒ´]], and is therefore called ''al-ImƒÅm al-Mahdƒ´''. It is believed that he is still present on earth "in occultation" (i.e., hidden), and will emerge again in the end times. Those Shi`ites of this school believe that the ImƒÅm Mahdƒ´ is the rightful ruler of the whole Islamic community (''[[ummah]]'') at any given time, and he is therefore also called ''ImƒÅm al-ZamƒÅn'', meaning "ImƒÅm of the Age/Time." ==History== ===Early history=== Created by [[Muqtada al-Sadr]] and a small faction of Shi'ites, the Mahdi Army began as a group of roughly 500 [[seminary]] students connected with Muqtada al-Sadr in the [[Saddam City|Sadr City]] district of [[Baghdad]], formerly known as Saddam City. The group moved in to fill the security vacuum in Sadr City and in a string of southern Iraqi cities following the [[Battle of Baghdad (2003)|fall of Baghdad]] to U.S-led coalition forces on April 9, 2003. The group was involved in dispensing aid to Iraqis and provided security in the Shi'ite [[slum]]s from looters. Gradually, the militia grew and al-Sadr formalized it in June 2003.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/feb/15/iraq.iran | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Mahdi army commanders withdraw to Iran to lie low during security crackdown | first=Michael | last=Howard | date=February 15, 2007 | accessdate=May 12, 2010}} The Mahdi Army grew into a sizable force of up to 10,000 who even operated what amounted to a shadow government in some areas. Al-Sadr's preaching is critical of the US occupation, but he did not initially join the [[Sunni]] Islamist and Baathist [[guerrilla warfare|guerrillas]] in their attacks on coalition forces. ===2004 Shi'ite Uprising=== {{main|Iraq spring fighting of 2004}} ====Uprising begins==== Sadr's position changed dramatically, however, by the beginning of April 2004. Following the closure of the Sadr-owned newspaper ''al-Hawza'' and the arrest of one of his senior aides, Sadr gave an unusually heated sermon to his followers on April 2. The next day, violent protests occurred throughout the Shi'ite south that soon spilled over into a violent uprising by Mahdi Army militiamen, fully underway by April 4. ====April hostilities==== The Mahdi Army forces began an offensive in [[Najaf]], [[Kufa]], [[Kut]], and Sadr City, seizing control of public buildings and police stations while clashing with coalition forces. The militants gained partial control of [[Karbala]] after fighting there. Other coalition forces came under attack in [[Nasiriyah]], [[Amarah]] and [[Basra]]. Najaf and Kufa were quickly seized after a few firefights with Spanish troops, and Kut was seized after clashes with Ukrainian troops soon afterwards. After sporadic clashes, coalition forces temporarily suppressed most militia activity in Nasiriyah, Amarah, and Basra. Mahdi rebels expelled Iraqi police from three police stations and ambushed U.S. forces in Sadr City, killing seven U.S. troops and wounding several more. U.S. forces subsequently regained control of the police stations after running firefights with the fighters, killing dozens of Mahdi militiamen. However, Mahdi Army members still maintained some influence over many of the slum areas of Sadr City. On April 16, Kut was retaken by US forces, and several dozen Mahdi Army members were killed in the battle. However, the area around Najaf and Kufa along with Karbala remained under the control of Sadr's forces. Sadr himself was believed to be in Najaf. Coalition troops cordoned off Najaf with 2,500 troops, but reduced the number of forces to pursue negotiations with the Mahdi Army. At the beginning of May, coalition forces estimated that there were 200‚Äì500 militants still present in Karbala, 300‚Äì400 in [[Diwaniyah]], an unknown number still left in Amarah and Basra, and 1,000‚Äì2,000 still in the Najaf-Kufa region. On May 4, coalition forces began a counter-offensive to eliminate the Mahdi Army in southern Iraq following a breakdown in negotiations. The first wave began with simultaneous raids in Karbala and Diwaniyah on militia forces, followed by a second wave on May 5 in Karbala and more attacks that seized the governor's office in Najaf on May 6. 86 militiamen were estimated killed in the fighting along with 4 U.S. soldiers. Several high-ranking militia commanders were also killed in a separate raid by US [[Special Operations]] units. On May 8, U.S. forces launched a follow-up offensive into Karbala, launching a two-pronged attack into the city. U.S. tanks also launched an incursion into Sadr City. At the same time, perhaps as a diversionary tactic, hundreds of Mahdi Army members swept through Basra, firing on British patrols and seizing parts of the city. Two militants were killed and several British troops were wounded. On May 24, after suffering heavy losses in weeks of fighting, Mahdi Army forces withdrew from the city of Karbala. This left the only area still under their firm control being the Najaf-Kufa region, also under sustained American assault. Several hundred Mahdi Army militia in total were killed. Unfazed by the fighting, Muqtada al-Sadr regularly gave Friday sermons in Kufa throughout the uprising. ==== June truce ==== On June 6, 2004, Muqtada al-Sadr issued an announcement directing the Mahdi Army to cease operations in Najaf and Kufa. Remnants of the militia soon ceased bearing arms and halted the attacks on U.S. forces. Gradually, militiamen left the area or went back to their homes. On the same day, [[Brigadier General]] [[Mark Hertling]], a top US [[commander]] in charge of [[Najaf]], [[Iraq]], stated "The Muqtada militia is militarily defeated. We have killed scores of them over the last few weeks, and that is in Najaf alone. [...] The militia have been defeated, or have left."[https://web.archive.org/web/20080410051925/http://www.stripes.com/article.asp?section=104&article=43036&archive=true] June 6 effectively marked the end of Shi'ite uprising. The total number of Mahdi Army militiamen killed in the fighting across Iraq is estimated at between 1,500 and 2,000. {{Citation needed|date=March 2008}} The return of Najaf to Iraqi security forces following the cease-fire left Sadr City as the last bastion of Mahdi Army guerrillas still pursuing violent resistance. Clashes continued periodically in the district following the end of the Najaf-Kufa battles. On June 24, Mahdi Army declared an end to operations in Sadr City as well, effectively ending militia activity, at least for the time being. After the June 4 truce with the occupation forces, al-Sadr took steps to disband the Mahdi Army. In a statement, he called on militia members from outside Najaf to "do their duty" and go home. US forces in Najaf were then replaced by Iraqi police. Al-Sadr told supporters not to attack Iraqi security forces and announced his intention to form a party and enter the 2005 elections. He said the interim government was an opportunity to build a unified Iraq. Interim President [[Ghazi Yawer]] gave assurances that al-Sadr could join the political process provided he abandoned his militia. Iraqi officials also assured al-Sadr that he was not to face arrest.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/3811215.stm|title=BBC NEWS - Middle East - Sadr orders militia to quit Najaf|publisher=|accessdate=21 January 2015}} ==== August hostilities ==== {{main|Battle of Najaf (2004)}} After Sadr's militia besieged a police station in Najaf and the local governor called for assistance, the US military intervened again. US troops arrested Sadr's representative in Karbala, Sheikh Mithal al Hasnawi on July 31{{cite web|url=http://www.greenleft.org.au/back/2004/593/593p15.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040819101827/http://www.greenleft.org.au/back/2004/593/593p15.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=19 August 2004|title=Back issues for 2004|publisher=|accessdate=21 January 2015|df=}} and surrounded al-Sadr's home on August 3.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/3528992.stm|title=BBC NEWS - Middle East - Fighting flares around Sadr home|publisher=|accessdate=21 January 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/middleeast/articles/2004/08/08/iraqi_bid_to_arrest_al_sadr_fails/|title=Iraqi bid to arrest al-Sadr fails|publisher=|accessdate=21 January 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.democracynow.org/article.pl?sid=04/08/03/1359246|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040805005932/http://www.democracynow.org/article.pl?sid=04%2F08%2F03%2F1359246|dead-url=yes|archive-date=5 August 2004|title=Headlines for August 03, 2004|work=Democracy Now!|accessdate=21 January 2015|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/Iraq/Story/0,2763,1278178,00.html|title=US troops kill 300 in Najaf raid|author=Michael Howard|work=the Guardian|accessdate=21 January 2015}} British troops in [[Basra]] also moved against al-Sadr followers, arresting four on August 3. After the expiration of a noon deadline to release them on August 5, the Basra militiamen declared [[Jihad|holy war]] on British forces.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2004/08/06/wirq06.xml|title=News|work=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=21 January 2015}} On August 5, via his spokesman Ahmed al-Shaibany, al-Sadr re-affirmed his commitment to the truce and called on US forces to honour the truce. He announced that if the restoration of the cease-fire failed "then the firing and igniting of the revolution will continue".{{cite web|url=http://edinburghnews.scotsman.com/index.cfm?id=902792004|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040830123359/http://edinburghnews.scotsman.com/index.cfm?id=902792004|dead-url=yes|archive-date=30 August 2004|title=Clashes in holy city as truce plea ignored|date=6 August 2004|publisher=The Scotsman|accessdate=2 February 2013|df=}} The offer was rejected by the governor of Najaf, [[Adnan al-Zurufi]] ("There is no compromise or room for another truce") and US officials ("This is one battle we really do feel we can win").{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2004/08/07/wirq07.xml|title=News|work=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=21 January 2015}} In the days that followed fighting continued around the old city of Najaf, in particular at the [[Imam Ali shrine]] and the cemetery. The Mahdi Army, estimated at 2,000 in Najaf, was outnumbered by some 2,000 US troops and 1,800 Iraqi security forces, and at a disadvantage due to the vastly superior American tactics, training, firepower and air power, such as helicopters and [[AC-130 gunship]]s. On August 13, the militia was trapped in a cordon around the Imam Ali shrine. While negotiations continued between the interim government and the Mahdi Army, news came that al-Sadr had been wounded.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/3560662.stm|title=BBC NEWS - Middle East - Radical cleric 'wounded' in Najaf|publisher=|accessdate=21 January 2015}} On August 12, British journalist [[James Brandon (journalist)|James Brandon]], a reporter for the [[Sunday Telegraph]] was kidnapped in Basra by unidentified militants. A video tape was released, featuring Brandon and a hooded militant, threatening to kill the British hostage unless US forces withdrew from Najaf within 24 hours. In a feature, Brandon describes being beaten, pistol-whipped, and forced to participate in mock executions. He said he escaped after holding a woman at knife-point, to a government building where guards found him, but they phoned his kidnappers, who arrived to collect him. Despite telling them repeatedly that he was a journalist, they assumed he was a spy or agent for the [[Post-invasion Iraq, 2003‚Äìpresent|occupation]] until they saw a report about the kidnap on [[al-Arabiya]] television. Afterward, Brandon's treatment improved markedly and he was released after less than a day, following intervention by al-Sadr. At a press conference, Brandon commented on his treatment and thanked his kidnappers: "Initially I was treated roughly, but once they knew I was a journalist I was treated very well and I want to say thank you to the people who kidnapped me." A spokesman for al-Sadr said: "We apologise for what happened to you. This is not our tradition, not our rules. It is not the tradition of Islam."{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/3560892.stm|title=BBC NEWS - Middle East - UK journalist kidnapped in Basra|publisher=|accessdate=21 January 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/3563032.stm|title=BBC NEWS - UK - Kidnapped UK journalist released|publisher=|accessdate=21 January 2015}} Brandon was delivered to the British military police who gave him medical treatment and escorted him to [[Kuwait]] the following day. Brandon planned to see his family and go on holiday, but said he wanted to return to Iraq : "Only next time, I just want to do the reporting. I have no desire to be the story again."{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/3566348.stm |title=UK | 'Mock executions' for UK hostage |publisher=BBC News |date=2004-08-15 |accessdate=2012-05-13}} The fact that American troops surrounded the Shrine led to an impasse as the Mahdi army could not leave the shrine and US troops did not want to offend Islam by setting foot inside the shrine. The standoff did not end for three weeks until [[Ali al-Sistani|Sistani]] emerged from convalescence in London and brokered an agreement between the two forces.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2004/WORLD/meast/08/27/iraq.main/index.html|title=CNN.com - Al-SadrÁàâilitia swaps prisoners with Iraq - Aug 28, 2004|publisher=|accessdate=21 January 2015}} ====Iraqi reactions==== The uprising seemed to draw an ambivalent reaction from the Iraqi population, which for the most part neither joined nor resisted the rebels. Many Iraqi security forces melted away, wishing to avoid confrontation. In a sign of Mahdi Army's unpopularity in Najaf, however, which follows more traditionalist clerics, a small covert movement sprung up to launch attacks on the militants. The uprising did receive a good deal of support from Shiite radicals in Baghdad, however, who were galvanized by the simultaneous siege of the city of [[Fallujah]]. ===2005=== {{Expand section|date=March 2008}} Loyalists to al-Sadr ran under the [[National Independent Cadres and Elites]] banner in the [[Iraqi parliamentary election, January 2005|2005 Iraqi election]]. Though a number of the movements supporters felt that the election was invalid. The party finished sixth overall in the election and was represented in the transitional legislature. Another twenty or so candidates aligned with al-Sadr ran for the [[United Iraqi Alliance]]. The movement is believed to have infiltrated the Iraqi police forces, and to have been involved in the [[Basra prison incident|September 2005 arrest]] of two British soldiers by Iraqi police.{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2005/0921/p01s03-woiq.html|title=Sadr militia's new muscle in south|author=The Christian Science Monitor|work=The Christian Science Monitor|accessdate=21 January 2015}} On December 4, 2005, former Prime Minister [[Iyad Allawi]] was assaulted by a mob in Najaf, where the Mahdi Army is influential.[https://web.archive.org/web/20060114124157/http://www.cnn.com/2005/WORLD/meast/12/04/iraq.main/ Ex-Iraqi leader claims assassination attempt | CNN.com] === October 2006 battle === {{main|Battle of Amarah}} In mid October, a roadside bomb killed Qassim al-Tamimi, the chief of investigations for the provincial police force and a member of the rival [[Badr Organization]]. Badr fighters blamed the Mahdi Army for the killing and in response to this, the police captured a brother of the suspected bomber, who was a member of the Mahdi Army. Fighting began on October 17, when 800 masked members of the Mahdi army stormed three police stations in [[Amarah]]. Several firefights occurred between the militia and police over the course of the next four days. By the morning of October 20, 2006, local leaders and residents said that victorious Mahdi fighters were patrolling the city on foot and in commandeered police vehicles and were setting up roadblocks. Sheik al-Muhamadawi stated early October 20 that "there is no state in the city. Policemen do not have enough weapons and ammunition compared with the militia, which has all kinds of weapons."{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/20/world/middleeast/21iraqcnd.html?ex=1318996800&en=a542d37a1dff56f9&ei=5088&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss | title = Attack on Iraqi City Shows Militia's Power | publisher = New York Times| date = 2006-10-20 | accessdate = 2006-10-20 | first=Kirk | last=Semple}} At least 27 people were killed and 118 wounded in the clashes. The Mahdi Army eventually withdrew from their positions in Amarah following negotiations between local tribal and political leaders and representatives from the [[Baghdad]] offices of Prime Minister [[Nouri al-Maliki|Nuri Kamal al-Maliki]]. A battalion from the [[Iraqi Army]] sent from [[Basra]] then took control of the city. The stunning and defiant display of militia strength underscored the weaknesses of the Iraqi security forces and the potency of the Mahdi Army, which had been able to operate virtually unchecked in [[Iraq]]. This caused many to accuse the Mahdi Army of starting the [[Civil war in Iraq (2006‚Äì07)|Civil War in Iraq]]. ===August 2007 ‚Äì March 2008 ceasefire=== In August 2007, during [[Battle of Karbala (2007)|fighting]] between the Mahdi Army and Iraqi police in Karbala, [[Muqtada al-Sadr]] called for a ceasefire and urged Mahdi Army members to stop fighting. The cease-fire has been credited with helping to reduce violence in [[Iraq]] between the Mahdi Army and Iraqi Army since August 2007.{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/meast/08/28/iraq.main/index.html#cnnSTCText|title=Al-Sadr calls for calm after Shiite militias clash in Karbala, Baghdad|publisher=|accessdate=21 January 2015}} Amid fears of the ending of the ceasefire in February 2008,{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/meast/02/20/iraq.main/index.html?iref=newssearch|title=Iraqi militia to hear Saturday whether to resume fighting|publisher=|accessdate=21 January 2015}} it was extended for a further six months by al-Sadr on February 22, 2008.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/meast/02/22/iraq.main/index.html|title=Al-Sadr extends Mehdi Army cease-fire|publisher=|accessdate=21 January 2015}} ===March 2008 Iraqi security forces crackdown=== {{main|Battle of Basra (2008)|Siege of Sadr City}} On 25 March 2008, thousands of Iraqi troops carried out a military strike against the Mahdi Army in their stronghold of Basra. This operation, code named Operation Charge of the Knights, was the first of its kind since British troops withdrew from the city centre. Clashes took place between security forces and the militants loyal to Muqtada al-Sadr after a dawn military offensive in the southern city.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/mar/25/iraq|title=Sadr urges 'civil revolt' as battles erupt in Basra|author=Matthew Weaver|work=the Guardian|accessdate=21 January 2015}} In Al-Sadr's headquarters of Najaf, the cleric ordered the field commanders of his Mahdi Army militia to go to 'maximum alert' and prepare "to strike the occupiers".{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2008-03-25-4110462503_x.htm|title=Militiamen holding out in Basra fighting - USATODAY.com|publisher=|accessdate=21 January 2015}} Gunmen also reportedly clashed with Iraqi police in the southern city of [[Kut]].{{cite web|url=http://alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L25165911.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090220131507/http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L25165911.htm|archivedate=2009-02-20|title=Iraqi forces battle gunmen in oil city |author=Thomson Reuters Foundation|work=alertnet.org}} The Mahdi Army launched a nationwide civil disobedience campaign across [[Iraq]] to protest raids and detentions against the Mahdi Army. The discord threatened to unravel al-Sadr's ceasefire, spark renewed sectarian violence, and prompt the [[United States]] to delay troop withdrawals. Violent rivalries among Shiites had been predicted by many observers ahead of the [[Iraqi governorate elections, 2008]], which were to be held by October 1, 2008.{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/meast/03/25/iraq.main/index.html|title=Peaceful Iraq protests spark clashes; 50 reported dead|publisher=|accessdate=21 January 2015}} Concurrently, on April 6, Iraqi and U.S. forces moved into the southern third of Sadr City to prevent rocket and mortar fire from the area against the [[Green Zone]]. U.S. engineers began construction of a concrete barrier along al-Quds Street to seal the southern third of the city off and allow reconstruction to take place. Over the next month, the Mahdi Army launched a number of attacks on the troops building the barrier, but sustained heavy losses. On May 11, al-Sadr concluded a cease-fire agreement with Iraqi security forces, ending the battle. Mahdi Army losses were estimated at between 700 and 1,000 casualties.{{cite book|title=The Encyclopedia of Middle East Wars|author=Spencer Tucker|page=1060|publisher=ABC-CLIO|year=2010|isbn=9781851099481|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U05OvsOPeKMC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false}} ===Disbandment and resurgence in 2014=== On August 28, 2008, al-Sadr ordered the Mahdi Army to suspend military activity indefinitely.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=S6oP3Y9ZM3sC&pg=PA45&dq=Mahdi+Army+disbanded#v=onepage&q=Mahdi%20Army%20disbanded&f=false|title=Withdrawal from Iraq: Assessing the Readiness of Iraqi Security Forces|author1=Anthony Cordesman|author2=Adam Mausner|year=2009|publisher=Center for Strategic and International Studies|isbn=9780892065530|page=45}} Later, however, al-Sadr created either two or three new organizations to take the place of the Mahdi Army: the [[Promised Day Brigades]], established in November 2008 as a militia,{{cite web|url=http://www.stanford.edu/group/mappingmilitants/cgi-bin/groups/view/249|title=Mapping Militant Organizations: Promised Day Brigades|date=27 August 2012|accessdate=19 October 2013|publisher=Stanford University}} and the Muhamidoon, which focuses on social work and religious education.{{cite news|title=Sadr's Path Could Determine How Iraq Turns|newspaper=New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/22/world/middleeast/sadrs-path-could-determine-how-iraq-turns.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|date=21 September 2011|accessdate=19 October 2013|author=Tim Arango}} A 2010 Associated Press report also mentioned a third wing, the Monaseroun, responsible for "the mobilization of supporters."{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2010/05/04/feared-shiite-mahdi-army-militia-led-hardline-cleric-reviving-post-election/|newspaper=Fox News|date=4 May 2010|title=Feared Shiite Mahdi Army militia led by hardline cleric reviving in post-election Iraq|accessdate=19 October 2013}} Since 2008, rumors of a Mahdi Army resurgence have cropped up periodically. In April 2010, after winning 40 of 325 seats in the [[Iraqi parliamentary election, 2010|2010 parliamentary elections]], Sadr called for its reestablishment.{{cite web|title=The Return of Moqtada al-Sadr and the Revival of the Mahdi Army|date=3 June 2010|accessdate=19 October 2013|url=http://www.ctc.usma.edu/posts/the-return-of-moqtada-al-sadr-and-the-revival-of-the-mahdi-army|author=Babak Rahimi|publisher=Combating Terrorism Center |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130226005826/http://www.ctc.usma.edu/posts/the-return-of-moqtada-al-sadr-and-the-revival-of-the-mahdi-army |archivedate=2013-02-26}} In 2014 al-Sadr called for the formation of "Peace Companies", often mistranslated "Peace Brigades", to protect Shia shrines from the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]].{{cite web | title = Anti-U.S. Cleric Muqtada al-Sadr Retakes Stage Amid Iraq Turmoil - NBC News | author = Cassandra Vinograd | work = NBC News | date = 23 June 2014 | accessdate = 1 August 2015 | url = http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/iraq-turmoil/anti-u-s-cleric-muqtada-al-sadr-retakes-stage-amid-n138406 }} In June 2014, these Peace Companies marched in [[Sadr City]], a slum in Baghdad infamous for being the prime Mahdi Army center of operations during the Iraq War.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/06/iraqi-shia-groups-rally-show-power-20146216504615669.html|title=Iraqi Shia groups rally in show of power|publisher=|accessdate=10 April 2015}} In addition to guarding shrines, the Peace Companies participated in offensive operations such as the recapture of [[Jurf Al Nasr]] in October 2014.{{cite web | title = Iraqi Shiite cleric recalls militiamen from fight against Islamic State | author1 = Loveday Morris | author2 = Mustafa Salim | work = Washington Post | date = 17 February 2015 | accessdate = 1 August 2015 | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/iraqi-shiite-cleric-recalls-militiamen-from-fight-against-islamic-state/2015/02/17/9e85321a-b6bb-11e4-bc30-a4e75503948a_story.html}} They suspended their activities temporarily in February 2015, but were active in the [[Second Battle of Tikrit (March‚ÄìApril 2015)|Second Battle of Tikrit]] in March.{{cite web | title = Iraqi militia loyal to radical cleric al-Sadr joins fight for IS-held Tikrit | author = Staff | work = Global News | date = 15 March 2015 | accessdate = 1 August 2015 | url = http://globalnews.ca/news/1883845/iraqi-militia-loyal-to-radical-cleric-al-sadr-joins-fight-for-is-held-tikrit/ }} ==Iran's influence== Although Muqtada Al-Sadr has historically had close ties to Iran, he has generally opposed Iranian clerical and political influence in Iraq. Unlike the Al-Hakim family, of the Supreme Iraqi Islamic Council and many leaders of the Dawa party who fled to Iran following the [[Gulf War|Persian Gulf War]] and remained there in exile until the [[2003 invasion of Iraq|American invasion in 2003]], Muqtada al-Sadr and his family remained in Iraq throughout Saddam's rule. The refusal to leave Iraq garnered the Sadr family much support during and after the collapse of Saddam's regime. Early 2006, al-Sadr pledged military support to Iran and other neighboring Islamic countries if they were to be attacked by a foreign nation.[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1137605892424&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull Cleric says militia would defend Iran if attacked | Jerusalem Post]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Since then, however, Al-Sadr has opposed the [[Dawa Party]], and In 2006 Prime Minister [[Nouri al-Maliki]] ordered a major offensive targeting the Mahdi Army in Basra.[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/29/world/middleeast/29iraq.html?ex=1314504000&en=de6a827d26b0fcd4&ei=5088&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss Radical Militia and Iraqi Army in Fierce Battle] 29 August 2006 In late 2007 or 2008, Muqtada al-Sadr moved to Iran and spent several years studying Shia jurisprudence in [[Qom]] before returning to [[Najaf]] in 2011.[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/20111872647305497.html Al-Sadr calls on Iraqis 'to resist']. English.aljazeera.net (2011-01-08). Retrieved on 2012-06-04. ==Activities== As of August 2006, the Mahdi Army rarely challenged coalition troops on a wide scale. Neither the coalition nor the Iraqi government made any move to arrest al-Sadr. The Mahdi Army participated in battles against Sunni insurgents and operated its own justice system in the areas it controlled.{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2005/11/35b8bb23-2a15-4275-99ee-b368fde58b0a.html|title=Iraq: Al-Sadr Militia Taking Law Into Own Hands|work=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|accessdate=21 January 2015}}The Economist magazine. May 29th, 2010 edition. Article "A well-locked closet". p. 62. The Mahdi army operated death squads that frequently killed Sunni civilians particularly during the [[Iraqi insurgency (2003‚Äì11)|civil war]] phase of the Iraq war.{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.de/the-mahdi-army-turbans-kalashnikovs-and-plans-to-slaughter/a-17728487|title=The Mahdi Army: Turbans, Kalashnikovs and plans to ‚Ä≤slaughter‚Ä≤ - World - DW.DE - 22.06.2014|work=DW.DE|accessdate=10 April 2015}} ==Structure== {{Expand section|date=March 2008}} When reporting on an early October 2006 clash between the Mahdi Army and Coalition troops in [[Diwaniyah]], BBC news suggested that at the time, the Mahdi Army was not a homogeneous force, with local groups apparently acting on own initiative.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/4801705.stm|title=BBC NEWS - Middle East - Battle rages in Shia Iraqi town|publisher=|accessdate=21 January 2015}} In September 2006, a senior coalition intelligence official had remarked to reporters how there were political fractures within Al-Sadr's organization in protest of his relatively moderate political course of action,{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/Iraq/Story/0,,1883854,00.html|title=US: Iraq failing to tackle death squads|author=Peter Beaumont|work=the Guardian|accessdate=21 January 2015}} with one coalition intelligence official claiming that at least six major leaders no longer answer to al-Sadr and as many as a third of the army was now out of his direct control.[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/28/world/middleeast/28sadr.html?ex=1317096000&en=5f9450eeea4966f8&ei=5088&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss Cleric Said to Lose Reins of Parts of Iraqi Militia | New York page.title: Predicting the timing of peak oil
