{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} [[File:Yasin al-Qadi.JPG|thumb|300px|Yassin Kadi]] '''Yassin Abdullah Kadi''' (also transliterated from Arabic as '''Yasin Abdullah Ezzedine al-Qadi''' or '''Yasin A. Kahdi''') (b. 23 February 1955) is a Saudi Arabian businessman who has been described by friends and associates as a philanthropist.<ref name="nytimes-philanthropist">Gerth, Jeff and Judith Miller, "[https://www.nytimes.com/2001/10/13/world/a-nation-challenged-on-the-list-philanthropist-or-fount-of-funds-for-terrorists.html On The List: Philanthropist or Fount of Funds for Terrorists?]" New York Times, 13 October 2001</ref> A multi-millionaire from Jeddah, Kadi trained as an architect in [[Chicago]], Illinois.<ref name="chicagotribune-money-trail">Jackson, David et al. "[http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/sns-worldtrade-kadi-ct,0,6501196.story U.S.: Money Trail Leads to Saudi]," Chicago Tribune, 29 October 2001</ref> He is the son-in-law of Sheikh Ahmed Salah Jamjoom, a former Saudi Arabian government minister with close ties to the Saudi royal family.<ref name="bangladesh-threat">Blackburn, Chris "[http://www.secularvoiceofbangladesh.org/Jamaat%20i%20Islami%20%20A%20threat%20to%20Bangladesh%20by%20Chris%20Blackburn.htm Jamaat-i-Islam: A Threat to Bangladesh?]" Secular Voice of Bangladesh website {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321132425/http://www.secularvoiceofbangladesh.org/Jamaat%20i%20Islami%20%20A%20threat%20to%20Bangladesh%20by%20Chris%20Blackburn.htm |date=21 March 2012 }}</ref><ref name="wsj-well-connected">Simpson, Glenn R. "[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB118835025334911761 Well Connected, A Saudi Mogul Skirts Sanctions]," Wall Street Journal, 29 August 2007</ref><ref name="whos-who-arab-world">Who's Who in the Arab World: 1981-1982 (University of Michigan: Publitec, 1981) p. 820</ref>
The UN placed sanctions against Kadi in 1999 and 2000, when he was named by [[United Nations Security Council Resolution]]s [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1267|1267]] and [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1333|1333]] as a suspected associate of Osama bin Laden's terror network, [[al-Qaeda]].<ref name="unsc-aq-sanctions">[https://www.un.org/sc/committees/1267/aq_sanctions_list.shtml UN Security Council Consolidated List "established and maintained by the Committee pursuant to resolutions 1267 (1999) and 1989 (2011) with respect to individuals, groups, undertakings and other entities associated with Al-Qaida," United Nations website]</ref> On 12 October 2001, the U.S. Department of Treasury's [[Office of Foreign Assets Control]] (OFAC) ordered his assets in the United States to be frozen.<ref name="nytimes-mired-limbo">Thomas Jr., Landon "[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/13/world/middleeast/13kadi.html?pagewanted=all A Wealthy Saudi, Mired in Limbo over an Accusation of Terrorism]," New York Times, 12 December 2008</ref><ref> {{cite news| url=https://www.forbes.com/2008/01/24/turkey-yasin-al-qadi-biz-cz_rm_0124alqadi.html| title=The Al Qadi Affair| work=[[Forbes]]| author1=Richard C. Morais| author2=Denet C. Tezel| date=24 January 2008| accessdate=23 October 2008| archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.forbes.com%2F2008%2F01%2F24%2Fturkey-yasin-al-qadi-biz-cz_rm_0124alqadi.html&date=2008-10-23| archivedate=23 October 2008| deadurl=yes| df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="AssociatedPress2008-10-22">{{cite news| url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5iCSbGyLPOYbpf-Io3G-FoUhzDgYAD93VU8800| title=UN expert wary of handling of suspected terrorists| publisher=[[Associated Press]]| author=John Heilprin| date=22 October 2008| accessdate=22 October 2008| quote=| deadurl=bot: unknown| archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fap.google.com%2Farticle%2FALeqM5iCSbGyLPOYbpf-Io3G-FoUhzDgYAD93VU8800&date=2008-10-23| archivedate=23 October 2008| df=dmy-all}} </ref> The [[European Union]] also applied sanctions to Kadi.<ref>Marty, Dick, "United Nations Security Council and European Union Blacklists," Doc. 11454 Report, Committee on Legal Affairs and Human Rights, Parliamentary Assembly, Council of Europe, 16 November 2007, http://assembly.coe.int/documents/workingdocs/doc07/edoc11454.htm, provides hyperlinks to relevant documents, namely "Council Decision 2001/927/EC Establishing the List Provided for in Article 2(3) of Council Regulation (EC) No. 2580 on specific restrictive measures directed against certain persons and entities with a view to combating terrorism, 27 December 2001, "Council Common Position 2001/930/CFSP of 27 December 2001," "Council Common Position 2001/931/CFSP of 27 December 2001," etc.</ref><ref>Posch, Albert, "The Kadi Case: Rethinking the Relationship between EU Law and International Law?" Columbia Journal of European Law, 15 Colum. J. Eur. L. F. 1 (2009), {{cite web |url=http://www.cjel.net/online/15_2-posch/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-10-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121231151342/http://www.cjel.net/online/15_2-posch |archivedate=31 December 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>European Union, "Consolidated list of persons, groups and entities subject to EU financial sanctions," Updated 13 October 2012, http://eeas.europa.eu/cfsp/sanctions/consol-list_en.htm</ref> In response, Kadi's lawyers brought two lawsuits now considered landmarks in [[public international law]], known as ''Kadi I'' (2008) and ''Kadi II'' (2010). The case for which he is best known, a 2008 decision by the [[European Court of Justice]], ''Kadi I'',<ref>The fuller name is ''Kadi and Al Barakaat International Foundation v Council of the European Union and Commission of the European Communities'' (2008) [http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:62005J0402:EN:HTML C-402/05 P]</ref> is thought to have challenged "the core framework of UN terrorist sanctions and forces UN member states to tackle difficult legal questions or else face possible collapse of the UN‚Äôs terrorist sanctions regime."<ref>Fromuth, Peter "The European Court of Justice Kadi Decision and the Future of UN Counterterrorism Sanctions," American Society for International Law website, ASIL Insights, Vol. 13, Issue 20, 30 October 2009, http://www.asil.org/insights091030.cfm</ref>
Kadi's listing as a terrorist was overturned by several European courts, and his name was removed from blacklists by Switzerland (2007),<ref name="Ghafour, P.K. Abdul 2007">Ghafour, P.K. Abdul. "Yassin al Qadi Exonerated," Arab News, 24 December 2007.</ref> the European Union (2008 and 2010),<ref name="ReferenceC">Carter-Ruck Press Release: "General Court Orders Annulment of European Regulation Freezing Funds of Sheik Yassin Abdullah Kadi," 30 September 2010</ref><ref>"[http://www.eubusiness.com/news-eu/justice-attacks.6cn EU Court Annuls Funds Freeze Against Saudi 'Terror' Suspect]," EUBusiness 30 September 2010</ref> and the United Kingdom (2008 and 2010).<ref>"[http://www.law-essays-uk.com/resources/sample-essays/UK-Law/her-majestys-treasury-v-ahmed.php Her Majesty's Treasury v. Ahmed [2010<nowiki>]</nowiki> UKSC2]" Law Essays and Dissertation Experts website citing London Times online</ref><ref>MacDonald, Alison. "Case Comment: HM Treasury v Ahmed [2010] UKSC2" FreeLegalWeb.org, syndicated from UKSC weblog.</ref> In September 2010, Kadi "succeeded in having dismissed in their entirety the civil claims brought against him in the United States on behalf of the families of the 9/11 victims",<ref name="carter-ruck.com">Carter-Ruck Law Firm, "[http://www.carter-ruck.com/International%20Law/Recent_Work.asp 9/11-related U.S. Civil Claims Against Prominent Saudi Businessman Dismissed,]" Carter-Ruck International Law: Recent Work webpage, 13 September 2010</ref> when a U.S. District Judge ruled that the District Court for the Southern District of New York had no jurisdiction over Kadi, a Saudi Arabian citizen.<ref name="carter-ruck.com"/>{{Update inline|date=August 2016}} In October 2012, the UN Security Council committee monitoring sanctions against al-Qaeda granted Kadi's petition to be removed from its blacklist.<ref>Associated Press, "UN removes Saudi businessman from al-Qaida sanctions blacklist," Washington Post, 5 October 2012</ref><ref>Rubenfeld, Samuel "UN Removes Saudi Businessman from Al Qaeda Blacklist," Wall Street Journal (Blog), 8 October 2012,https://blogs.wsj.com/corruption-currents/2012/10/08/un-removes-saudi-businessman-from-al-qaeda-blacklist/</ref> The ''Kadi II'' decision by the European Court of Justice in July 2013 declined appeals by the EU and the UK against the earlier annulment of European sanctions against Kadi, saying that there was no evidence to substantiate the allegations of his being linked to terrorism. On 26 November 2014, the United States Department of the Treasury removed Kadi's name from its Specially Designated Nationals list.<ref>U.S. Department of the Treasury. [http://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/OFAC-Enforcement/Pages/20141126.aspx "Counter Terrorism Designation Removals"], 26 November 2014.</ref>
==Early Life and Family== [[Image:Saudi Arabia map.png|thumb|left|300px|Present Saudi Arabia]] Kadi was born 23 February 1955 in Cairo, Egypt.<ref name="federal-register-blocked-2007">"[http://regulations.vlex.com/vid/blocked-terrorists-narcotics-traffickers-28406885 Sanctions, Blocked Persons, Specially Designated Nationals]," Foreign Assets Control Office Report, 21 June 2007</ref><ref name="unsc-sanctions-amended">"[https://www.un.org/News/Press/docs/2010/sc10125.doc.htm Individuals Associated with Al-Qaida: Security Council Al-Qaida and Taliban Sanctions Committee Amends Entries of Thirteen Individuals on its Consolidated List,]" Department of Public Information, News and Media Division, New York, 15 December 2010</ref> His father became a successful businessman in [[Jeddah]], [[Saudi Arabia]].<ref name="chicagotribune-money-trail" /><ref name="wsj-well-connected" /> He has six sisters and no brothers.<ref name="johnson-clifton-bio-stmt">{{cite book|title=Biographical statement provided by Kadi's attorneys, Johnson & Clifton LLP In Re Yassin Abdullah Kadi, OFAC Department of Treasury FAX Petition 175|author=staff|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/18487799/Petition-175 |date=21 December 2001 |ref=harv}}</ref>
Around 1977, Kadi earned a bachelor's degree in architectural engineering from Alexandria University in Cairo, Egypt,{{sfn|staff|p=4}} and subsequently became an intern at the architectural firm [[Skidmore, Owings & Merrill]] in Chicago from July 1979 to February 1981.<ref name="chicagotribune-money-trail" /> He helped the firm develop a master plan and contract documentation for the Mecca Campus of the [[King Abdulaziz University]].<ref>Yassin Abdullah Kadi, Claimant, and HM Treasury, Defendant, In the High Court of Justice, Queen's Bench Division, Administrative Court, In the Matter of Yassin Abdullah Kadi, CO/4528/01 and CO/4532/01, [https://www.scribd.com/doc/18487799/Petition-175 Petition 175], page 3, footnote 3.</ref>
Yassin Kadi married a daughter of Sheikh Ahmed Salah Jamjoom sometime before 1981.<ref name="bangladesh-threat" /><ref name="wsj-well-connected" /><ref name="whos-who-arab-world"/> He and his wife have seven children,<ref name="johnson-clifton-bio-stmt" /> including a son who is a U.S. citizen.<ref name="wsj-well-connected" />
==Business and nonprofit ventures== In the 1980s, Kadi became a vice president of the Jamjoom Group, a multi-national conglomerate headquartered in Jeddah.<ref name="chicagotribune-money-trail" /><ref name="wsj-well-connected" />{{sfn|staff|p=4}} Around 1986, Yassin Kadi became one of the principal investors in BMI Inc., a Shariah-compliant investment bank based in New Jersey.<ref>"[http://www.investigativeproject.org/case/249 U.S. v. Biheiri, Soliman]" The Investigative Project on Terrorism website</ref><ref name="kane-declaration">Kane, David. "Declaration in Support of Pretrial Detention," USA v. Soliman S. Biheiri, U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, Alexandria Division, Case No. 03-365-A, 14 August 2003. Retrieved via FindLaw.com August 2012</ref>
Kadi inherited "several million dollars" in 1988.<ref name="wsj-well-connected" /> In 1990, he began to establish close business associations with Saudi billionaire [[Khalid bin Mahfouz]], whose family owned a majority interest in Saudi Arabia's largest bank, the [[National Commercial Bank]]. Kadi said that he was brought in to maintain good financial relations with pious Muslims throughout the Islamic world, by building a more [[shariah]]-compliant banking network for the bank. "We devised systems of leasing and ways to borrow money" that could be used by pious Muslims, who are not allowed to charge interest, Kadi told the ''Chicago Tribune''.<ref name="jackson-cohen-manor-money-trail">David Jackson, Laurie Cohen and Robert Manor, "[http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/sns-worldtrade-kadi-ct,0,1961940.story?page=1 U.S.: Money Trail Leads to Saudi: Financier Denies Sending Funds to Bin Laden,]" Chicago Tribune, 29 October 2001, posted on LA Times website</ref>
In May 1992, Kadi created the Muwafaq Foundation, an Islamic charity incorporated for the stated purpose of providing famine relief and education in the Islamic world, particularly Pakistan.<ref name="johnson-clifton-bio-stmt"/><ref name="guardian.co.uk">Pallister, David and Jamie Wilson. "[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2001/sep/26/afghanistan.terrorism13 Untangling the Financial Web: Raising Money, Muslim Relief Groups Caught in Cross-fire,]" The Guardian, Tuesday 25 September 2001</ref> The charity was incorporated as a trust on the island of [[Jersey]], an off-shore tax haven located near the coast of Normandy, France.<ref name="guardian.co.uk"/> Officials on the island told the Guardian that Jersey "does not appear to maintain any public record of the Muwafaq Foundation." They said "if it was structured as a financial trust, it would not require to be registered at all."<ref name="guardian.co.uk"/> Kadi personally donated about $15 to $20 million from his fortune, and solicited donations from bin Mahfouz and other wealthy Saudi families.<ref name="jackson-cohen-manor-money-trail"/> Bin Mahfouz became a principal donor but later said that he was not involved in the operation of the charity after its establishment.<ref>Bin Mahfouz Family, "[http://www.binmahfouz.info/faqs_2.html What was the connection between Khalid bin Mahfouz and the Blessed Relief charity?]" FAQ Tab, The Events of 11 September 2001 and Their Aftermath, Bin Mahfouz Information website</ref>
A similarly named organization, the "Muwaffaq Society" or "Muwaffaq Ltd.," was registered in the Isle of Man in June 1991, but Kadi denied any relationship to this entity.{{sfn|staff|loc=page 10, paragraph 17.2}} Plaintiffs who have filed suit against Kadi and his associates claim that Muwafaq was a charitable front used to funnel money to al-Qaeda, an allegation Mr Kadi has repeatedly denied.<ref name="burr-collins-alms">Burr, J. Millard and Robert O. Collins, ''Alms for Jihad: Charity and Terrorism in the Islamic World'' (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2006, pp. 121-123. The authors claim that the Muwafaq Foundation opened an office in Mogadishu, Somalia, in 1992, at a time when al-Qaeda was assisting militants fighting U.S. soldiers there, and "its purpose [there] consisted of transporting weapons and ammunition to Islamists in the city."</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Cohen|first=Laurie |date=2001-10-16 |title=Assets frozen, Saudi businessman demands evidence |url= http://www.chicagotribune.com/chi-0110160282oct16-story.html |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |access-date=2016-02-18}}</ref>
In 1996, Kadi became one of the original founders and financial supporters of the [[Dar Al-Hekma College|Dar Al-Hekma Private College for Girls]], a "path-breaking Saudi women's college" based in Jeddah.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.daralhekma.edu.sa/ABOUT/admin.asp|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010408021952/http://www.daralhekma.edu.sa/ABOUT/admin.asp|title=About Us|archivedate=8 April 2001|publisher=}}</ref> At the time of the September 11 attacks, he was serving as the Secretary-General of the college.<ref name="samman-treasury-action">Samman, Muhammad. "[http://arabnews.com/node/215491 Treasury action smacks of arrogance, violates human rights, says Al-Qadi]," Arab News, 14 October 2001</ref>
===Business activity after 2001=== According to Victor D. Comras, "Al Kadi is believed to have acted swiftly after 9/11 to restructure many of his business interests and, while retaining actual control, placed many of his own assets into the hands of nominal managers and directors."<ref name="comras-flawed-diplomacy">[https://books.google.com/books?id=iB_rdh_udG4C&pg=PA111&lpg=PA111&dq=Victor+D.+Comras+Yasin+al+Qadi&source=bl&ots=jFDiWfpO93&sig=a2NXoZHD8aV7CO-8_XYHa87uw9g&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_A81UOz0M6S1ygH72ICAAg&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Victor%20D.%20Comras%20Yasin%20al%20Qadi&f=false Comras, Victor D. Flawed Diplomacy: The United Nations & the War on Terrorism.] (Potomac Books, Inc., 2010). P. 98</ref> In 2005, the New York Times estimated that Kadi‚Äôs net worth "exceeds $65 million."<ref name="nytimes-mired-limbo" /> In 2010, Comras described him as a billionaire, citing his extensive international business holdings.<ref name="comras-flawed-diplomacy" />
==Terrorism blacklist==
===Meetings with Osama bin Laden=== In an October 2001 interview with the Chicago Tribune, Kadi said that he met with Osama bin Laden at religious gatherings in the 1980s, but "he said the encounters were unremarkable at a time when bin Laden's battle against the Soviets in Afghanistan attracted US government support and donations from Mosques around the United States."<ref name="chicagotribune-money-trail" />
In a December 2008 interview with the New York Times, Kadi added that he once met Osama bin Laden in Chicago. He gives the date as 1981.<ref name="nytimes-mired-limbo quote">"Qadi told the Times that Bin Laden "came to Chicago to recruit American-trained engineers for his family‚Äôs construction business. As Mr. Kadi remembers it, he put Mr. bin Laden in touch with a group of engineers, several of whom were eventually hired." Thomas Jr., Landon "[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/13/world/middleeast/13kadi.html?pagewanted=all A Wealthy Saudi, Mired in Limbo over an Accusation of Terrorism]," New York Times, 12 December 2008</ref> Steven Coll, a biographer of the Bin Laden family<ref>Coll, Steven, ''[https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Bin_Ladens.html?id=M8dSD-CQOTYC The Bin Ladens: An Arabian Family in the American Century]'' (New York: Penguin Books, 2009)</ref> discovered that the date of the visit was 1979. Osama "was here for two weeks in 1979, it seems, and he visited Los Angeles and Indiana, among other places."<ref name="Osama in America: The Final Answer">Coll, Steven. "[http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/stevecoll/2009/06/osama-in-america-the-final-answer.html Osama in America: The Final Answer,]" The New Yorker, 30 June 2009.</ref>
The date coincides with Kadi's arrival in Chicago in July 1979. Coll gives as his source a 2009 biography written by Osama's first wife, Najwa Bin Laden.<ref>Bin Laden, Omar and Najwa bin Laden. [https://www.amazon.com/Growing-Up-bin-Laden-Osamas/dp/0312560168 Growing Up Bin Laden: Osama's Wife and Son Take Us Inside Their Secret World], (New York: St. Martin's Press, 2009).</ref>
===1991: Loan Linked to Hamas=== In 1991, Kadi loaned $820,000 to the Quranic Literacy Institute (QLI) of Oak Lawn, IL, a group formed to disseminate the Koran and Muslim texts but later allegedly linked to Hamas. Kadi told the Chicago Tribune he made the loan because of his friendship with the literacy institute's president, whom he met at a Sunday lecture in the Chicago area.<ref name="chicagotribune-money-trail"/>
Kadi said the money was intended to allow the institute to make a land investment, which would yield profits that would support its charitable work.<ref name="chicagotribune-money-trail"/>
=== 1998: Funds Al-Iman University === In 1998, Kadi donated money toward the construction of housing for students at Al-Iman University in Sanaa, Yemen.<ref name="ReferenceA">"January ‚Äì August 1998: Saudi Businessman pays money to Al Qaeda front," History Commons website, citing Wall Street Journal</ref> The university‚Äôs name is also translated as [[Iman University]] or Al-Eman.
A 2010 New York Times profile of the university<ref>Erlanger, Steven. "[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/19/world/middleeast/19yemen.html?pagewanted=all&_moc.semityn.www At Yemen College, Scholarship and Jihadist Ideas,]" New York Times, 18 January 2010</ref> indicates it is run by Muslims who follow Salafist practice, that is, a strict and puritanical form of Islam practiced by the [[Salafi]] ("ancestors" or first Muslims ). Al-Iman is "not a typical college," says [[Glenn R. Simpson]] of the Wall Street Journal. "Its curriculum primarily concerns the study and propagation of radical Islam."<ref>Simpson, Glenn R. "[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB108086163406272221 Terror Probe Follows the Money: Investigators Say Bank Records Link a Saudi Investor to al Qaeda]," Wall Street Journal, 2 April 2004</ref>
===January - August 1998: Linked to Maram=== According to Glenn R. Simpson of the Wall Street Journal, Kadi's bank records show that, between January and August 1998, he transferred $1.25 million from his Geneva bank account through an associate to an alleged al-Qaeda front company in Turkey known as Maram.<ref>Simpson, Glenn R. "Terror Probe Follows the Money: Investigators Say Bank Records Link Saudi Investor to al Qaeda" Wall Street Journal, 2 April 2004</ref> Founded as a travel agency and import-export business, the company Maram was reportedly established by [[Mamdouh Mahmud Salim]], said to be one of al-Qaeda‚Äôs founding members and to have a history of moving money and shopping for weapons for the organization.<ref name="NYT">[http://www.historycommons.org/searchResults.jsp?searchtext=al-Qadi&events=on&entities=on&articles=on&topics=on&timelines=on&projects=on&titles=on&descriptions=on&dosearch=on&search=Go#events History Commons] website citing Douglas Frantz,"Front Companies Seen to Keep Financing Terrorists," New York Times, 19 September 2002</ref>
A few months later, in December 1998, Kadi reportedly transferred shares in the company to two other men. One was Wael Hamza Julaidan, a Saudi businessman said to be a founder of al-Qaeda (the US officially designated Julaidan a financial supporter of al-Qaeda in 2002). The other was reported to be Mohammed Bayazid, another alleged founder of al-Qaeda.<ref name="NYT" />
On 20 December 1998 Salim was extradited to the United States, where he was charged with participating in the [[1998 United States embassy bombings]].<ref>^ Copy of indictment USA v. Usama bin Laden et al., Center for Nonproliferation Studies, Monterey Institute of International Studies</ref> In 2010, USA Today reported that he is an inmate of the ADX Florence facility in Florence, Colorado (reg.nr. 42426-054), sentenced to life without parole for stabbing a federal prison guard in the eye.<ref>"[https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2010-08-31-bin--laden-aide-prison_N.htm Ex-bin Laden aide gets life for prison stabbing]," USA Today, 31 August 2010</ref>
=== Blocked by Executive Order 13224 === On 12 October 2001 Kadi was listed as one of several dozen individuals that the United States "determined to have committed or to pose a significant risk of committing or providing material support for acts of terrorism" under Executive Order 13224.<ref>"[https://fas.org/irp/news/2002/10/dos101102.html Fact Sheet: Office of the Coordinator for Counterterrorism, U.S. Department of State, October 11, 2002]" reproduced at FAS.org</ref><ref>U.S. Department of State, Chronology, The Office of the Coordinator for Counterterrorism, "[http://www.ratical.org/ratville/CAH/terrorOrgsID.pdf Comprehensive List of Terrorists and Groups Identified under Executive Order 13224]," 31 December 2001.</ref> His U.S. assets were frozen.<ref>U.S. Department of Treasury "[http://www.treasury.gov/press-center/press-releases/Pages/po689.aspx Treasury Department Releases List of 39 Additional Specially Designated Global Terrorists]," 12 October 2001, Press Center page, Treasury Department website</ref> On 15 October, OFAC sent a letter to Kadi notifying him of his rights to request reconsideration.<ref>U.S. Office of Management and Budget, OMB Watch Timeline of Kadi Litigation in EU and U.S. "[http://www.charityandsecurity.org/litigation/Kadi_Timeline The Kadi Case: Court Decisions on Due Process for Terror Listing Differ in EU, U.S,]" 3 April 2012, Charity & Security Network website</ref> Kadi was added to the UN list shortly afterward, which also resulted in his assets being frozen in [[European Union]] countries. Saudi Arabia "supported the addition of the Jeddah-based terrorist financier, Yasin al-Qadi, to the UN's consolidated list in October 2001," according to an official press release of the U.S. Treasury.<ref>Office of Public Affairs, U.S. Department of Treasury, "[http://www.treasury.gov/press-center/press-releases/Pages/js1108.aspx Treasury Announces Joint Action with Saudi Arabia Against Four Branches of Al Haramain in the Fight Against Terrorist Financing]," 22 January 2004.</ref><ref name="federal-register-blocked-2001">Federal Register, [https://www.federalregister.gov/articles/2001/10/26/01-27076/blocked-persons-specially-designated-nationals-specially-designated-terrorists-foreign-terrorist Alphabetical List of Blocked Persons], U.S. Department of Treasury, Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC)</ref>
==="Not found guilty of anything"=== Yassin Kadi was never formally charged with a crime by the U.S. Department of Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control. "As is customary in such cases, Washington has presented no direct evidence linking Mr. Kadi to terrorism," the New York Times reported in 2008. "But it has made public a dense labyrinth of associations and business and personal ties that it says establishes Mr. Kadi‚Äôs relationship with Mr. bin Laden and his allies."<ref name="nytimes-mired-limbo" />
"We have not found Mr. Kadi guilty of anything," Adam J. Szubin, director of OFAC, told the Times. "But we have found that he is a supporter of terror."<ref name="nytimes-mired-limbo"/>
"The post-911 credo became one of pre-emption and acting on suspicion," says Marieke DeGoede in her 2012 book ''Speculative Security: The Politics of Pursuing Terrorist Monies''. OFAC uses its new powers to freeze assets "during the pendancy of an investigation," which means, effectively, that the government is able to stop the operations of charities suspected of being terrorist fronts "without any formal determination of wrongdoing."<ref>DeGoede, Marieke. ''Speculative Security: The Politics of Pursuing Terrorist Monies'' (University of Minnesota Press, 2012) p. 133</ref>
Kadi, who has repeatedly claimed that he has given no support to terrorism, told the Times that the result was a legal paradox. When no criminal charge has been brought and the evidence on which the charges are based has been classified, "there is no way to defend yourself."<ref name="nytimes-mired-limbo"/>
Kadi denied all the allegations as totally untrue. "I don‚Äôt have any connection, be it close or distant, with Al-Qaeda or its leader Bin Laden, either directly or indirectly," he told Asharq Al-Awsat, a sister publication of Arab News, in an interview.<ref>Ghafour, P.K. Abdul "[http://www.arabnews.com/node/255770 Yassin Al-Qadi Wins Case Against Swiss Prosecutor,]" Arab News, 26 September 2004</ref>
==Legal action==
===December 2001: Appeals listing and asset freeze=== In December 2001, Kadi filed a challenge to the EU listing and asset freeze in the European Court of First Instance (General Court). His appeal was based on a claim that he had been denied fundamental due process.<ref name="omb-watch-timeline">OMB Watch Timeline of Kadi Litigation in EU and U.S. "The Kadi Case: Court Decisions on Due Process for Terror Listing Differ in EU, U.S," 3 April 2012, Charity & Security Network website</ref> The same month, he also petitioned the U.S. Department of Treasury (OFAC) for reconsideration of his listing and asset freeze.<ref name="omb-watch-timeline" />
===Move to Turkey=== After 11 September 2001, Yassin Kadi moved many of his operations to Istanbul, Turkey and Switzerland. ''Forbes'' reported that Kadi is a friend of Turkish Prime Minister [[Recep Tayyip Erdogan]].<ref name="Forbes2008-01-24">
On 5 October 2012, the [http://www.foxnews.com/us/2012/10/05/united-nations-removes-saudi-businessman-from-blacklist/?test=latestnews UN Security Council] committee monitoring sanctions removed Kadi from its blacklist as a suspected financier of Al-Queda.
{{cite news |url = https://www.forbes.com/2008/01/24/turkey-yasin-al-qadi-biz-cz_rm_0124alqadi.html |title = The Al Qadi Affair |work = [[Forbes]] |author = Richard C. Morais, Denet C. Tezel |date = 24 January 2008 |accessdate = 23 October 2008 |quote = |deadurl = bot: unknown |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.forbes.com%2F2008%2F01%2F24%2Fturkey-yasin-al-qadi-biz-cz_rm_0124alqadi.html&date=2008-10-23 |archivedate = 23 October 2008 |df = dmy-all }} </ref> Erdogan is quoted as having said "I know Mr. Kadi. I believe in him as I believe in myself. For Mr. Kadi to associate with a terrorist organization, or support one, is impossible."<ref name="Rubin">Rubin, Michael "[http://www.commentarymagazine.com/2012/06/15/gaza-flotilla-sponsor-funding-al-qaeda/ Gaza Flotilla Sponsor Funding Al-Qaeda?]" Commentary Magazine, 15 June 2012</ref><ref name="H√ºrriyet2013-12-28">{{cite news | url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25457802.asp | title=‚ÄòKaza‚Äô suikast | publisher=[[H√ºrriyet]] | author=Toygun ATƒ∞LLA | date=28 December 2013 | accessdate=24 February 2014 | quote= }} </ref>
===November 2002: Defendant in 911 lawsuit=== On 15 August 2002, firefighters, rescue workers and more than 600 relatives of victims of the [[September 11 attacks]] filed a $116 trillion lawsuit against Osama bin Laden, the Saudi Bin Laden Group, three Saudi princes, the government of Sudan, seven international banks, eight Islamic foundations, charities and subsidiaries, and many other defendants.<ref>Schmidt, Susan "September 11 families join to sue Saudis," Washington Post, 16 August 2002</ref><ref name="auto">CNN "$116 trillion lawsuit filed by 9/11 families," 15 August 2002</ref><ref>Kellman, Laurie "More than 600 Sept. 11 victims' families sue Saudis, banks," Associated Press, 15 August 2002</ref> Kadi was added to the list of defendants on 22 November 2002, along with 50 more people and organizations, bringing the total number of defendants to 186.<ref>Geyelin, Milo. "Sept.11 Suit to Add Defendants, Including Saudi Bank, Minister" Wall Street Journal, 22 November 2002</ref><ref>Weinstein, Henry "9/11 Victims' Suit Expanded," Los Angeles Times, 23 November 2002</ref> The amount of money sought was reduced to $1 trillion, but the number of plaintiffs soon increased to 2,500 after the suit was widely publicized.<ref name="auto" /> Technically, Kadi was part of the "Third Amended Complaint" in the case of ''[http://uniset.ca/other/cs5/349FSupp2d765.html Thomas E. Burnett, Sr., et al. v. Al Baraka Investment and Development Corporation, et al.]'', originally filed in the District of Columbia.<ref name="motleyrice.com">"[http://www.motleyrice.com/anti-terrorism-and-human-rights/9-11-families-united-to-bankrupt-terrorism 9/11 Families United to Bankrupt Terrorism,]" Motley Rice Law Firm web page. Retrieved 15 August 2012.</ref>
Informally, the case is called the "911 Lawsuit," and it is a landmark case that has been examined in great detail by legal scholars.<ref>"[http://law.about.com/library/weekly/aa090402a.htm A Guide to the 9-11 Lawsuit, Part I: Overview of the Suit,]" About.com Legal Management website. Retrieved 15 August 2012</ref> In 2005 the case was combined with several other lawsuits to become ''[http://www.uniset.ca/other/cs5/2005WL2872113.html In re Terrorist Attacks on September 11, 2001, MDL 1570],'' filed in the Southern District of New York. The case grew to more than 6,500 plaintiffs, collectively called "9/11 Families United to Bankrupt Terrorism."<ref name="motleyrice.com" />
===March 2004: Delisting request denied by OFAC=== On 12 March 2004, OFAC issued a 20-page unclassified memorandum denying Kadi‚Äôs request for reconsideration.<ref name="The Kadi Case 2012">OMB Watch Timeline of Kadi Litigation in EU and U.S. "The Kadi Case: Court Decisions on Due Process for Terror Listing Differ in EU, U.S," 3 April 2012, Charity & Security Network website</ref><ref name="kadi-v-paulson-opinion">{{ cite book|publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office |title=Kadi v. Paulson et al, Civil Action No. 09-0108 (JDB), Document 56 Memorandum Opinion, 19 March 2012, citing "OFAC Memorandum" of March 2004 |first=John D. |last=Bates|url=https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/USCOURTS-dcd-1_09-cv-00108/pdf/USCOURTS-dcd-1_09-cv-00108-0.pdf|ref=harv}}</ref> It determined that Kadi played "a significant leadership role" in the Muwafaq ("Blessed Success") Foundation, as one of six trustees, and the others "delegated . . . the running and the operation of the Foundation" to Kadi, who "was the driving force behind the administration of the foundation." He "effectively conceded that he directly supervised the individual country offices."{{sfn|Bates|p=16}} OFAC relied on Kadi's involvement in Muwafaq and, in particular, activities claimed to have occurred in Bosnia, Albania, Sudan and Pakistan, to conclude that "Kadi financially supported terrorist activities, primarily through Muwafaq, but also through other Kadi-owned entities." It considered Kadi's "relationship with and financial transfers to, designated terrorists Abdul Latif Saleh, Wa'el Julaidan, and Chariq Ayadi -- who were all involved in Muwafaq."{{sfn|Bates|p=16}}
According to OFAC's findings, "Muwafaq gave logistical and financial support to Al-Gama'at Al-Islamiya, a mujahadin battalion in Bosnia that was designated as SGDT on October 31, 2001. The organization also transferred $500,000 to terrorist organizations in the Balkans in the mid-1990s."{{sfn|Bates|p=17}} OFAC found that Muwafaq "was involved in arms trafficking from Albania to Bosnia," and concluded that "as of late 2001, Kadi had continued to finance institutions and organizations in the Balkans after Muwafaq had ceased operations there, including two entities that were designated as SDGTs in early 2002 -- the Revival of Islamic Heritage Society's Pakistan and Afghanistan offices, and the Bosnia-Herzegovina branch of the Al-Haramain Foundation."{{sfn|Bates|p=17}}
===September 2004: Complaint against Swiss prosecutor=== On 21 September 2004, the Swiss Federal Criminal Court ruled in Kadi's favor with regard to complaints brought by Kadi's lawyers against the Swiss prosecutor, Deputy Swiss Attorney General Claude Nicati. The Swiss court ordered that Kadi's lawyers be given full access to Nicati's entire file, including all notes taken by Nicati of his meeting with Jean-Charles Brisard.<ref name="auto1">Ghafour, P.K. Abdul "Yassin Al-Qadi Wins Case Against Swiss Prosecutor," Arab News, 24 September 2004</ref>
"Brisard is the lead investigator for the US lawyers in the civil action brought in the US courts on behalf of the families of the victims of the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks and cannot therefore be regarded as independent," his lawyers said. "Of particular concern to Al-Qadi was his discovery that Brisard passed to US lawyers documents he received from Nicati‚Äôs file in his capacity as expert."<ref name="auto1"/>
On 27 March 2006, an extraordinary prosecutor appointed to investigate the matter concluded that Kadi's allegations were baseless and dismissed the action, finding that there was no evidence that Brisard or his assistants had improperly passed on information to Nicati.<ref>Brisard, Jean-Charles. "[http://blog.jean-charles-brisard.com/en/2006/03/swiss_decision_/ Swiss decision dismissing SDGT Yassin Al Kadi Complaint,]" The Blog of Jean-Charles Brisard, citing [http://blog.jean-charles-brisard.com/wp-content/Uploads/2006/03/Jomini_YAK_JCB_US.pdf Swiss court documents posted in PDF format]</ref>
===September 2005: EU denies request for delisting=== In September 2005, the EU Court of First Instance (General Court) denied Kadi‚Äôs appeal, saying that compliance with EU law need not be considered because the UN Security Council has primacy. Kadi appealed to the EU Court of Justice.<ref name="The Kadi Case 2012"/>
===December 2005: Wins case in Switzerland=== The Federal Criminal Court in Berne, Switzerland, "cleared Al-Qadi of any wrongdoing in a case stemming from the 9/11 attacks," his lawyers announced on 12 December 2005. The charges had alleged that Kadi gave money in 1998 ostensibly to construct student housing at Al-Iman University in Yemen while knowing that the funds may have ended up supporting Al-Qaeda‚Äôs plan to attack New York City.<ref name="Mirza 2005">Mirza, Abdul Maqsood "Saudi Execs Praise Swiss Decision in Al-Qadi Case," Arab News, 25 December 2005.</ref>
"I am very happy to know that my friend Al-Qadi has been cleared of all charges by the Swiss court," [[Zuhair Hamed Fayez|Zuhair Fayez]], a Jeddah-based architect, told Arab News on 25 December. He described Kadi as a reputable businessman and said the individuals and agencies that falsely accused Kadi of funding terrorism must be held responsible for damaging his reputation and interests.<ref name="Mirza 2005"/>
===December 2007: Delisted by Switzerland=== On 13 December 2007, based on the results of its own six-year investigation, a Swiss court removed Kadi from the country's list of blocked terrorists. [[Arab News]] reported that Kadi was exonerated "on all charges" and said that his money in Swiss banks and the Geneva-based Faisal bank would be unfrozen.<ref name="Ghafour, P.K. Abdul 2007"/> Switzerland is not a member of the European Union and therefore had no obligation to comply with the EU listing.<ref name="The Kadi Case 2012" />
===September 2008: EU Court of Justice rules in favor of Kadi=== In 2008 the [[European Court of Justice]] overturned sanctions against Kadi by individual [[European Union]] governments, on the grounds the EU nations had not offered those sanctioned a chance for the judicial review of their matter.<ref name=AssociatedPress2008-10-22/>
On 3 September 2008, the EU Court of Justice (higher court) ruled in favor of Kadi, "saying UN agreements cannot have the effect of prejudicing constitutional principles agreed to in the treaty establishing the European Community. The court found the EU regulation allowing listing and asset freezes to breach fundamental human rights, since no evidence was communicated to Kadi, and the right of defence and effective judicial review were prejudiced. It gave EU authorities three months to remedy these defects, leaving the sanctions in place during that time."<ref name="The Kadi Case 2012"/><ref>Posch, Albert "[http://www.cjel.net/online/15_2-posch/ The Kadi Case: Rethinking The Relationship Between EU Law and International Law?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121231151342/http://www.cjel.net/online/15_2-posch |date=31 December 2012 }}" 15 Colum. J. Eur. L. F. 1 (2009) citing "[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:62005J0402:EN:HTML Yassin Abdullah Kadi and Al Barakaat International Foundation v Council of the European Union and Commission of the European Communities]" European Union Legal Documents website</ref><ref>European Court of Justice "[https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/20695879?uid=3739560&uid=2129&uid=2&uid=70&uid=4&uid=3739256&sid=21101145360201 Yassin Abdullah Kadi and Al Barakaat International Foundation v. Council of the European Union and Commission of the European Communities,]" 3 September 2008, Cited as 47 ILM 927(2008), reproduced by American Society of International Law, JSTOR: International Legal Materials website</ref>
According to ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine, none of the bodies that have sanctioned Kadi have made public any of the evidence upon which the sanctions were and continued to be based.<ref name=Forbes2008-01-24 />
On 22 October 2008, [[Martin Scheinin]], in a report to the [[United Nations Security Council]], suggested greater openness and transparency for making known the reasons individuals and organizations were being sanctioned.<ref name=AssociatedPress2008-10-22/> He stated: :{| class="wikitable" border="1" | :"Leaving things as they are at the U.N. level ... is the least preferred option, as it would result in a wave of litigation and the credibility of the overall United Nations counterterrorism framework would be at risk." |}
=== November 2008: EU Commission renews listing and asset freeze === In October 2008, the EU Commission (sanctions agency) provided to Kadi‚Äôs attorneys a brief summary of the UN‚Äôs reasons for listing Kadi, and they gave Kadi an opportunity for comment. On 28 November 2008, the EU Commission renewed its listing and assets freeze against Kadi.<ref name="The Kadi Case 2012"/>
===December 2008: Partially delisted by UK Treasury=== In December 2008, the UK Treasury removed Yassin Kadi from its list of persons designated as terrorists under its Terrorism (United Nations Measures) Order 2001 (the "2001 Order"), but left him on a second list of persons designated as terrorists under separate UK legislation, the Al Qaeda and Taliban (United Nations Measures) Order 2006 (the "2006 Order"), which contained different listing criteria.<ref name="Yassin Abdullah Kadi v p. 2">Yassin Abdullah Kadi v. Timothy Geithner et al., U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, Civil Action 09-0108 (JDB), "Plaintiff's Request for Judicial Notice," Document 42, Filed 6/22/10, p. 2, Case 1:09-cv-00108-JDB, PDF copy retrieved 15 August 2012</ref>
According to his UK lawyers at [[Carter-Ruck]], "this delisting followed a comprehensive review by the UK Treasury of the case against Mr. Kadi, including a review of the materials which had been used to support Mr. Kadi's original designation, after which the UK Treasury concluded that "the case against (Mr. Kadi) no longer meets the test set out in ... the Terrorism Order."<ref name="Yassin Abdullah Kadi v p. 2"/>
===January 2009: Kadi v Timothy Geithner et al=== On 16 January 2009, Kadi filed suit against officers of the U.S. Department of Treasury (OFAC) in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia (''Yassin Abdullah Kadi v. Timothy Geithner et al.'', Civil Action No. 09-0108; and ''Kadi v. Paulson et al.'', a request for agency decision review assigned to Judge John D. Bates, Case 28-1331).<ref>{{Cite Pacer | plaintiff = Kadi | defendant = Paulson | title = Memorandum Opinion | date = 20 March 2012 | case-division = 1 | case-year = 2009 | case-type = cv | case-sequence = 00108 | case-state = dc | doc-number = 56 | pacer-number = 134774 | access-date = 1 August 2012 | use-pacer = no | use-recap = yes | case-title = Kadi v. Paulson et. al. }}</ref><ref>{{Cite Pacer Docket | plaintiff = Kadi | defendant = Paulson | date = 16 January 2016 | case-division = 1 | case-year = 2009 | case-type = cv | case-sequence = 00108 | case-state = dc | pacer-number = 134774 | access-date = 1 August 2012 | use-pacer = yes | use-recap = yes | case-title = Kadi v. Paulson et. al. }}</ref>
The lawsuit and request for agency review challenged Kadi‚Äôs designation as a terrorist and the asset freeze. Kadi raised "constitutional claims regarding due process, free speech, and protection from unreasonable seizure of assets."<ref>OMB Watch Timeline of Kadi Litigation in EU and U.S. "[http://www.charityandsecurity.org/litigation/Kadi_Timeline The Kadi Case: Court Decisions on Due Process for Terror Listing Differ in EU, U.S.]," 3 April 2012, Charity & Security Network website</ref>
===February 2009: Second challenge to EU listing and EU freeze=== In February 2009, Kadi filed a new lawsuit with the EU General Court (formerly the Court of First Instance), challenging the EU‚Äôs 28 November 2008 decision to renew his listing and assets freeze.<ref name="The Kadi Case 2012"/>
===August 2009: UN clarifies reasons for listing Kadi=== On 13 August 2009, the United Nations Security Council Committee concerning Al-Qaida and associated individuals and entities (the "Al-Qaida Sanctions Committee") posted additional information and a narrative summary of their reasons for listing Yasin Abdullah Ezzeddine Kadi.<ref name="unsc-narrative-summary">UN Security Council "[https://www.un.org/sc/committees/1267/NSQI02201E.shtml Narrative Summary of Reasons for Listing: Yasin Abdullah Ezzedine Qadi]" Security Council Committee pursuant to resolutions 1267 (1999) and 1989 (2011) concerning Al-Qaida and associated individuals and entities, 13 August 2009</ref><ref>[https://www.un.org/sc/committees/1267/NSQI02201E.shtml]</ref> The reasons included: *Kadi's acknowledgement of his role as founding trustee and director of the actions of the Muwafaq Foundation, a foundation which historically operated under the umbrella of the Makhtab al-Khidamat, an organization which was the predecessor of Al-Qaida and which was founded by Usama bin Ladin *Kadi's decision in 1992 to hire Shafiq ben Mohamed ben Mohamed al-Ayadi as head the European offices of the Muwafaq Foundation *The 1995 testimony of Talad Fuad Kassem, who said that the Muwafaq Foundation had provided logistical and financial support for a fighters‚Äô battalion in Bosnia and Herzegovina and that the Muwafaq Foundation was involved in providing financial support for terrorist activities of the fighters, as well as arms trafficking from Albania to Bosnia and Herzegovina *Kadi's role as a major shareholder in the now closed Sarajevo-based Depositna Banka, where planning sessions for an attack against a United States facility in Saudi Arabia may have taken place *Kadi's ownership of several firms in Albania which funneled money to extremists or employed extremists in positions where they controlled the firm‚Äôs funds *Evidence that Bin Laden provided the working capital for up to five of Kadi‚Äôs companies in Albania.
Based on these reasons, the U.N. Security Council resolved to continue listing Yassin Kadi as a suspected supporter of al-Qaeda terrorists and the United States Department of Treasury has continued to classify Kadi as a Specially Designated Global Terrorist.
===January 2010: UK Supreme Court delists Kadi=== On 27 January 2010, the [[Supreme Court of the United Kingdom]] (the highest appellate court for the UK) annulled the listing criteria of "the 2006 Order," the Al Qaeda and Taliban (United Nations Measures) Order 2006. In the case of ''[[Her Majesty's Treasury v Ahmed]]''<ref>[2010] [http://www.bailii.org/uk/cases/UKSC/2010/2.html UKSC 2]</ref> the court struck down the operative part of the legislation, and ruled that it must be quashed as being ''[[ultra vires]]'', or beyond the powers of the government which were conferred under the UK's [[United Nations Act 1946]], which allowed the UK to implement UN Security Council Resolutions.<ref name="Yassin Abdullah Kadi v p. 2"/><ref>MacDonald, Alison. "[http://freelegalweb.org/6992/2010/02/case-comment-hm-treasury-v-ahmed-2010-uksc-2/ Case Comment: HM Treasury v Ahmed [2010<nowiki>]</nowiki> UKSC2]" FreeLegalWeb.org, syndicated from UKSC weblog, which "brings together barristers at Matrix Chambers, solicitors at Olswang LLP and wider contributions from academics and other interested parties to report the work of the UK Supreme Court in a suitably 21st century style."</ref>
Thus Kadi's removal from a second UK list of persons designated as terrorists "was done as the result of the finding of the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom that any such designation (as was done in Mr. Kadi's case in contravention of his fundamental rights) was illegal."<ref name="Yassin Abdullah Kadi v p. 2"/>
===September 2010: EU Court rules in Kadi‚Äôs favor, faults UN procedures=== On 30 September 2010, the EU General Court once again ruled in favor of Kadi, "noting that the UN procedure, despite improvements in the establishment of an Ombudsman Office to make recommendations on delisting requests, lacks fundamental due process protections, including sufficient notice of the charges and denying ‚Äòmost minimal access to the evidence against him.‚Äô" It said: "In essence the Security Council has still not deemed it appropriate to establish an independent and impartial body responsible for hearing ... decisions taken by the Sanctions Committee." (Paragraph 128).<ref name="The Kadi Case 2012"/>
According to Kadi's [[solicitor]]s at Carter-Ruck, the ruling had the effect of striking down the European asset-freezing regulation that was imposed on Kadi on 28 November 2008 after he had won his appeal to the European Court of Justice.<ref name="ReferenceC"/>
===8 September 2011: Sued by Lloyd's=== Kadi was among nine defendants sued by the [[Lloyd's of London]] insurance syndicate on 8 September 2011 in a "landmark legal case against Saudi Arabia, accusing the kingdom of indirectly funding al-Qa'ida and demanding the repayment of ¬£136m [$215 million] it paid out to victims of the 9/11 attacks."<ref>Milmo, Cahal, "[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/lloyds-insurer-sues-saudi-arabia-for-funding-911-attacks-2356857.html Lloyd's insurer sues Saudi Arabia for 'funding 9/11 attacks,]' " The Independent (UK), 19 September 2011</ref><ref name="auto2">Pearson, Sophia, "Lloyd's Underwriters Sue Saudi Bank Over September 11 Claims," Bloomberg Business Week, 12 September 2011</ref><ref name="mcauley-lloyds">McAuley,Erin. "[http://www.courthousenews.com/2011/09/12/39682.htm Lloyd's Says Saudis Should Pay $215 Million for Sept. 11 Claims]," Courthouse News website, 12 September 2011</ref> Formally titled ''[http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/pdf/201109/20110909pdf_underwriters-v-saudi.pdf Underwriting Members of Lloyd's Syndicate 3500 v. Kingdom of Saudi Arabia et al.]'', the civil suit was filed in Pittsburgh (the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania).<ref name="lloyds-v-saudi">pg. 127, citing British intelligence report of 22 November 1999 and USA Today article.</ref><ref>Goldhaber,Michael D. "[http://amlawdaily.typepad.com/amlawdaily/2011/09/the-global-lawyer-the-kingdom-and-the-911-plaintiffs.html The Global Lawyer: The Kingdom and the 9/11 Plaintiffs,]" The AmLaw Daily, 8 September 2011.</ref>
"Absent the sponsorship of al Qaeda‚Äôs material sponsors and supporters, including the defendants named herein, al Qaeda would not have possessed the capacity to conceive, plan and execute the September 11th attacks," according to the 154-page complaint.<ref name="auto2"/>
Yassin Kadi is listed along with the following defendants: *The Kingdom of [[Saudi Arabia]] (KSA) *The Saudi High Commission for Relief of Bosnia and Herzegovina (SHCR)<ref>"[http://www.historycommons.org/entity.jsp?entity=khalil_ziyad_1 Profile: Saudi High Commission,]" History Commons website</ref> *The Saudi Joint Relief Committee for Kosovo and Chechnya (SJRC)<ref>"Profile: Saudi Joint Relief Committee," History Commons website</ref><ref>Central Intelligence Agency "[[s:CIA Report on NGOs With Terror Links|CIA Report on NGOs with Terror Links]]," 1996, Wikisource</ref> *The [[Saudi Arabian Red Crescent Society]] (SRCS) *The [[National Commercial Bank]] (NCB)<ref>"[http://www.historycommons.org/entity.jsp?entity=national_commercial_bank Profile: National Commercial Bank]" History Commons website</ref> *The [[Al-Rajhi Bank]] and Investment Company (ARABIC) *Prince Salman Bin Abdul-Aziz al Saud *[[Sulaiman Abdul Aziz Al Rajhi]] (SAAR)<ref>"[http://www.historycommons.org/entity.jsp?entity=abdel_aziz_al-rajhi Profile: Sulaiman Abdul Aziz al-Rajhi]" History Commons website</ref>
===March 2012: U.S. Judge denies Kadi's motion to delist === On 19 March 2012, the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia dismissed Kadi‚Äôs 2009 lawsuit against the officers of the U.S. Department of Treasury (OFAC). Judge John D. Bates brushed off Kadi's claim that OFAC "simply ignored" his explanation that Muwafaq was an organization engaged in charitable activities. Kadi had said the government believes Muwafaq is a front for bin Laden because [[USA Today]] reported that. "To the extent Kadi contends that newspaper articles cannot be relied upon by the government at all, that proposition is not well-grounded," Bates wrote. "As already stated, reliance on hearsay is plainly allowed. Furthermore, reliance on newspaper articles has been permitted to 'fill in evidentiary gaps when there is corroboration,' as well as to provide background information", Bates explained in his judgement.<ref>"[http://docs.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/district-of-columbia/dcdce/1:2009cv00108/134774/56/0.pdf?ts=1376948974]</ref>
Bates stated "the Court finds that this claim must be dismissed because (1) the bill of attainder clause does not apply to acts taken by a regulatory agency and (2) even if it did, the clause is not triggered here, because there was no action constituting 'punishment'".<ref>KADI v. PAULSON et al Civil Action No. 09-0108 (JDB) page 67 "[http://docs.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/district-of-columbia/dcdce/1:2009cv00108/134774/56/0.pdf?ts=1376948974]"</ref>
===October 2012: UN Security Council delists Kadi === The U.N. Security Council created an independent ombudsman in 2009 to handle requests to get off the blacklist. The decision to delist Kadi came following his request for removal, according to a UN statement.
It stated that "after concluding its consideration of the delisting request submitted by this individual through the Ombudsperson established pursuant to Security Council resolution 1904 (2009), and after considering the Comprehensive Report of the Ombudsperson on this delisting request. Therefore, the assets freeze, travel ban and arms embargo set out in paragraph 1 of Security Council resolution 1989 (2011) no longer apply to the following individual."<ref>"[https://www.un.org/News/Press/docs//2012/sc10785.doc.htm]"</ref>
=== July 2013: European Court of Justice upholds annulment of terrorism designation === The European Commission, the European Council, and the United Kingdom appealed against the 2010 ruling of the EU General Court which had struck down the freezing of Kadi's European assets. The [[European Court of Human Rights|Grand Chamber]] of the Court of Justice of the European Union declined the appeal. According to Maya Lester, the decision hinged upon the court having gone through "each reason for the decision to re-list Yassin Kadi in 2008, and Mr Kadi‚Äôs evidence in response, and found none of the reasons to have been substantiated with evidence".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://europeansanctions.com/2013/07/21/the-ecjs-judgment-in-kadi-ii/|title=THE ECJ‚Äôs JUDGMENT IN KADI II|last=Lester|first=Maya|date=21 July 2013|website=European Sanctions|publisher=|access-date=27 August 2016}}</ref> The court stated that "since no information or evidence has been produced to substantiate the allegations, roundly refuted by Mr. Al-Qadi, of his being involved in activities linked to international terrorism, those allegations are not such as to justify the adoption, at European Union level, of restrictive measures against him."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.arabnews.com/news/458410|title=Court says EU wrongly froze assets of Saudi man|last=|first=|date=19 July 2013|website=|publisher=Arab News|access-date=27 August 2016}}</ref>
===September 2014: US Unblocks Property and Interests === On September 11, 2014, OFAC unblocked the property and interests in property of Yassin Kadi pursuant to E.O. 13224, "Blocking Property and Prohibiting Transactions With Persons Who Commit, Threaten To Commit, or Support Terrorism."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.federalregister.gov/articles/2014/12/05/2014-28598/unblocking-of-a-specially-designated-global-terrorist-pursuant-to-executive-order-13224|title=Federal Register - Unblocking of a Specially Designated Global Terrorist Pursuant to Executive Order 13224|publisher=}}</ref>
